DT Article
TI A review of the metallipennis-group and fuscinata-group of Fannia
   Robineau-Desvoidy (Diptera: Fanniidae).
AU Wang, Mingfu (wangmingfu403@163.com) 
   Dong, Yanjie
   Ao, Hu
SO Annales de la Societe Entomologique de France
VL 47
IS 3-4
PS 487-500
PD 2011
PY 2011
LA English
U1 0
U2 4
AB On the basis of comparative morphology study and the group definition
   put forward by Chillcott (1961a), the conception of fuscinata-group is
   proposed for the first time. So former metallipennis-group is divided
   into 2 groups, namely metallipennis-group and fuscinata-group. Earlier
   studies on the former metallipennis-group are stated. The external
   morphology and terminalia differences between the two groups are
   discussed. The characters and distinguishable features of the two groups
   are given. To facilitate comparisons of the groups, a male key of the
   two groups and their resemblant groups is provided. A catalogue of
   fuscinata-group including 12 species is given. The known distributions
   of this group are China and Japan of Asia. In this paper, we put
   emphasis on the study of metallipennis-group, including characters, a
   male key, review of species, redescription, the analysis of systematic
   evolution and biogeography. 23 genitalia figures is given. Up to date, 6
   species belong to metallipennis-group, occurring in Holarctic Region.
   One new species, Fannia medogensis Wang, n. sp., is described. Type
   specimens of the new species are deposited in the Institute of
   Entomology, Shenyang Normal University.
C1 Wang, Mingfu; Institute of Entomology, Sheyang Normal University, 253
   North Huanghe Street, Sheyang 110034, Liaoning, PR, China, China.
EM wangmingfu403@163.com

SN 0037-9271

   Key; Land zones; Palaearctic region; Eurasia; Asia; China
DE Fannia medogensis [Xizang /  / New species]. 
TN Arthropods; Insects; Invertebrates; True Flies
ST Animalia, Arthropoda, Insecta, Diptera, Brachycera, Cyclorrhapha,
   Fanniidae
OR Fannia fuscinata species group (Fanniidae): [New species group, P. 488;
   Key, To resemblant groups, Males, p. 489]. 
   Fannia grandicornus - Xue & Zhang 2005 (Fanniidae): [Redescription, P.
   491]. 
   Fannia ipinensis - Chillcott 1961 (Fanniidae): [Redescription, P. 492]. 
   Fannia medogensis - Wang 2011 (Fanniidae): [Sp nov, Xizang, P. 493]. 
   Fannia metallipennis - Zetterstedt 1838 (Fanniidae): [Redescription, P.
   494]. 
   Fannia metallipennis species group (Fanniidae): [Diagnostic characters,
   P. 490; Key to species, Males, p. 491]. 
   Fannia pigeonisternita - Xue & Wang 1998 (Fanniidae): [Redescription, P.

TI Review of the genus Aturbina Lugo-Ortiz & McCafferty (Ephemeroptera:
   Baetidae).
AU Salles, Frederico Falcao (ffsalles@gmail.com) 
   Boldrini, Rafael
   Shimano, Yulie
   Cabette, Helena R.S.
SO Annales de Limnologie
VL 47
IS 1
PS 21-44
PD 2011
PY 2011
LA English
U1 0
U2 3
AB In the present work, based on material from several localities in
   Brazil, the genus Aturbina is reviewed. Two new species, A. maculata,
   sp. nov. and A. nigra, sp. nov. are described based on nymphs and
   adults; the type-species, A. georgei, is redescribed based on nymphs and
   reared adults; the nymphs and adults of A. beutrixae are respectively
   described and redescribed, as well as recorded from Brazil for the first
   time. Based on these findings, an updated key to nymphs and adults of
   the genus is provided.

   1920 (Ephemeroptera: Leptophlebiidae: Atalophlebiinae).
AU Mariano, Rodolfo (rodolfomls@gmail.com) 
   Flowers, R. Wills
   Froehlich, Claudio G.

VL 47

PS 387-393

PY 2011
LA English
U1 0
U2 2
AB Four new species of Thraulodes Ulmer (Ephemeroptera: Leptophlebiidae),
   Thraulodes amanda sp. n., Thraulodes pelicanus sp. n., Thraulodes
   xavantinensis sp. n. and Thraulodes sinuosus sp. n are described based
   on imagos. A new synonymy (Thraulodes lepidus (Ulmer) = Thraulodes
   cryptodrilus Nieto&Dominguez) is proposed and the distribution of
   Thraulodes schlingeri is expanded based on a new record from western
   Brazil.

DT Article
TI A new micropterous species of Embolemus Westwood from Baltic amber
   (Hymenoptera: Embolemidae).
AU Perrichot, Vincent (vincent.perrichot@univ-rennes1.fr) 
   Engel, Michael S.
SO Annales de Paleontologie
VL 97
IS 1-2
PS 1-7
PD Jan 2011
PY 2011
LA English
U1 0
U2 1
AB A micropterous female embolemid is recorded in middle Eocene Baltic
   amber. Embolemus excitus Perrichot and Engel, sp. nov., is easily
   distinguished from other extinct and living species by the pronotum with
   only a weak mediolongitudinal furrow and with a lateral carina along the
   edge anterior to tegula, the mesopleuron with a pronounced medial
   dorsoventral carina, and the propodeum with dorsoposterior corners
   tuberculate. The new species also uniquely combines greatly reduced
   compound eyes, a scape distinctly elongate, the pronotum twice as long
   as mesoscutum, and the forewings extending at most to the anterior
   border of the second metasomal tergum. [copyright]2011 Elsevier Masson
   SAS. All rights reserved.
C1 Perrichot, Vincent; Univ Rennes 1, CNRS, Campus Beaulieu,Batiment 15,263
   Ave Gen Leclerc, Rennes, F-35042, France, France.
EM vincent.perrichot@univ-rennes1.fr
RI Engel, Michael S/C-5461-2012; Perrichot, Vincent/I-4134-2019
OI Engel, Michael S/0000-0003-3067-077X; Perrichot,
   Vincent/0000-0002-7973-0430

SN 0753-3969; 1778-3666

DT Article
TI A new iguanodontian dinosaur from the Khok Kruat Formation (Early
   Cretaceous, Aptian) of northeastern Thailand.
AU Buffetaut, Eric (eric.buffetaut@sfr.fr) 
   Suteethom, Varavudh
SO Annales de Paleontologie
VL 97
IS 1-2
PS 51-62
PD Jan 2011
PY 2011
LA English
U1 0
U2 6
AB A new taxon of ornithopod dinosaur is described as Siamodon nimngami
   nov. gen, nov. sep., on the basis of a well-preserved maxilla from the
   Khok Kruat Formation (Aptian) of northeastern Thailand. An isolated
   tooth and a braincase are referred to this taxon, and the status of
   other ornithopod specimens from Thailand and Laos is discussed. S.
   nimngami nov. gen, nov. sep. is considered as an advanced iguanodontian,
   apparently close to Probactrosaurus, from which it differs by various
   characters of the maxilla. Siamodon is an addition to the already long
   list of advanced iguanodontian taxa from the late Early Cretaceous of
   Asia. The diversity and abundance of these forms may suggest that
   advanced iguanodontians first appeared in Asia, before spreading to
   other parts of the world. [copyright] 2011 Elsevier Masson SAS. All
   rights reserved.
C1 Buffetaut, Eric; Ecole Normale Super, Geol Lab, 23 Rue Lhomond, Paris,
   F-75231, France, France.
EM eric.buffetaut@sfr.fr
SC Zoology
SN 0753-3969; 1778-3666

   Eurasia; Asia; Geological time periods; Mesozoic
DE Siamodon [Cretaceous /  / New genus]. 
   Siamodon nimngami [Thailand /  / new species] [Cretaceous /  / ]. 
TN Chordates; Reptiles; Vertebrates

   Ornithopoda

   nimngami, p. 52, Cretaceous; Fossil].

   Masumoto, 2006, and Malayaplamius sakaii Masumoto, 1986 are added.

PT J
AN ZOOR14802012999
DT Article
TI Notes on the "borrowed" specimens and names for Charles De Geer's
   darkling beetles (Insecta: Coleoptera: Tenebrionidae).
AU Ferrer, Julio
   Holston, Kevin
SO Annales Zoologici (Warsaw)
VL 61
IS 2
PS 241-257
PD 2011
PY 2011
LA English
U1 0
U2 3
AB The status of 23 species-group names used by Charles De Geer, for
   beetles classified in Pyrochroa Geoffroy, 1762, and Tenebrio Linnaeus,
   1758, is assessed. Thirteen of these species-group names are unavailable
   (ten were published in synonymy, three are subsequent usages of
   available names): Pyrochroa rubra De Geer, 1775 = Pyrochroa coccinea
   (Linnaeus, 1760); Pyrochroa bimaculata De Geer, 1775 = Apalus
   bimaculatus (Linnaeus, 1760); Tenebrio acuminatus De Geer, 1775 = Blaps
   mortisaga (Linnaeus, 1758); Tenebrio variolosus De Geer, 1775 = Upis
   ceramboides (Linnaeus, 1758); Tenebrio molitor De Geer, 1775 = Tenebio
   molitor Linnaeus, 1758; Tenebrio rugosus De Geer, 1775 = Opatrum
   sabulosum (Linnaeus, 1760); Tenebrio villosus De Geer, 1775 = Lagria
   hirta (Linnaeus, 1758); Tenebrio hirticornis De Geer, 1775 = Orthocerus
   clavicornis (Linnaeus, 1758); Tenebrio boleti De Geer, 1775 = Diaperis
   boleti (Linnaeus, 1758); Tenebrio gibbus De Geer, 1775 = Psammodes
   gibbus (Linnaeus, 1761); Tenebrio maurus De Geer, 1775 = Tenebrioides
   mauritanicus (Linnaeus, 1758); Tenebrio aeneus De Geer, 1775 = Tenebrio
   chalybeus Linnaeus, 1767, a misidentification of Xylopinus saperdiodes
   (Olivier, 1775); and Tenebrio surinamensis De Geer, 1775 = Oryzaephilius
   surinamensis (Linnaeus, 1758). The holotype of Pyrochroa tomentosa De
   Geer, 1775, and specimens described under the name Tenebrio maurus, De
   Geer, 1775, from the De Geer Collection were rediscovered within the
   Paykull Collection, Swedish Natural History Museum. Pyrochroa nigra De
   Geer, 1775, is a junior synonym of Prionychus ater (Fabricius, 1775); a
   recently reported synonymy with Schizotus pectinicornis (Linnaeus,
   1758), is an error. The holotypes of Pyrochroa nitida De Geer, 1775, and
   Tenebrio lardarius De Geer, 1775, are considered lost. Tenebrio gibbus
   De Geer, 1778, a junior primary homonym of Tenebrio gibbus Linnaeus,
   1760, has the replacement name Tenebrio striatus Retzius, 1783, and is a
   synonym of Zophosis reticulatus Say, 1824, syn. nov., making the valid
   combination of this North American species Discodemus striatus (Retzius,
   1783), comb. nov.
C1 Ferrer, Julio; Department of Entomology, The Swedish Museum of Natural
   History, 10405 Stockholm, Sweden, Sweden.
SC Zoology
SN 0003-4541; 1734-1833
BD Systematics; Nomenclature; Combination; Synonymy; Taxonomy; Taxonomic
   position
TN Arthropods; Beetles; Insects; Invertebrates
ST Animalia, Arthropoda, Insecta, Coleoptera, Polyphaga, Tenebrionoidea,
   Pyrochroidae, Tenebrionidae
OR Pyrochroa - Geoffroy 1762 (Pyrochroidae): [Taxonomy, Status of
   species-group names used by De Geer, p. 241]. 
   Discodemus striatus - (Retzius 1783) (Tenebrionidae): [Comb nov,
   Transferred from Tenebrio, p. 252; Syn nov, Zophosis reticulatus Say
   1824, p. 252]. 
   Pseudocistela ceramboides - (Linnaeus 1758) (Tenebrionidae): [Syn nov,
   Pyrochroa rufa De Geer 1775, p. 245]. 
   Tenebrio - Linnaeus 1758 (Tenebrionidae): [Taxonomy, Status of
   species-group names used by De Geer, p. 241]. 
   Tenebrio striatus - Retzius 1783 (Tenebrionidae): [Referred to,
   Discodemus, p. 252]. 
UT ZOOREC:ZOOR14802012999
DA 2020-09-17

DT Article
TI Two new species of the tribe Helopini (Coleoptera: Tenebrionidae) from
   Artvin Province, Turkey.
AU Nabozhenko, Maxim V. (nalassus@mail.ru) 
SO Annales Zoologici (Warsaw)
VL 61
IS 2
PS 335-338
PD 2011
PY 2011
LA English
U1 0
U2 4
AB Cylindrinotus tchorokhicus sp. nov. and Probaticus (Pelorinus)
   banaszkiewiczae sp. nov. are described from northeastern Turkey (Artvin
   Province). The first species is similar to C. constrictus (Seidlitz,
   1896), but differs from it by flattened lateral sides of pronotum,
   strongly thickened outer margins and base of pronotum, more shining body
   and structure of aedeagus. The new species of Probaticus Vauloger, 1900
   is close to P. corrugatus (Seidlitz, 1896), but differs from it by the
   structure and punctation of pronotum and propleura, structure of elytra
   and genitalia of male, and pubescence on anal sternite.
C1 Nabozhenko, Maxim V.; Azov Branch of Murmansk Marine Biological
   Institute, Kola Scientific Centre RAS, Institute of arid zones, Southern
   Scientific Centre of RAS, Chekhov str., 41, Rostov-on-Don, 344006,
   Russia, Russia.
EM nalassus@mail.ru
RI Nabozhenko, Maxim/M-6109-2014
OI Nabozhenko, Maxim/0000-0001-7914-7942
SC Zoology
SN 0003-4541; 1734-1833
BD Systematics; Nomenclature; New taxa; Diagnosis; Land zones; Palaearctic
   region; Eurasia
DE Cylindrinotus tchorokhicus; Probaticus (Pelorinus) banaszkiewiczae
   [Turkey /  / New species]. 
TN Arthropods; Beetles; Insects; Invertebrates
ST Animalia, Arthropoda, Insecta, Coleoptera, Polyphaga, Tenebrionoidea,
   Tenebrionidae
OR Cylindrinotus tchorokhicus (Tenebrionidae): [Sp nov, Turkey, P. 336]. 
   Probaticus (Pelorinus) banaszkiewiczae (Tenebrionidae): [Sp nov, Turkey,
   P. 337]. 
   Probaticus corrugatus - (Seidlitz 1896) (Tenebrionidae): [Diagnostic
   characters, P. 338].

PT J

DT Article
TI Contribution to the knowledge of the Cyphagogini from SE-Asia, with
   description of two new species of Calodromus Guerin-Meneville, 1832
   (Coleoptera: Brentidae: Cyphagoginae).
AU Bartolozzi, Luca (luca.bartolozzi@unifi.it) 
SO Annales Zoologici (Warsaw)
VL 61
IS 2
PS 375-380
PD 2011
PY 2011
LA English
U1 0
U2 0
AB Calodromus kosteliae sp. nov. from Malaysia is described based on a
   single male specimen. The new taxon is closely related to Calodromus
   vethi Kleine, 1915 but can be distinguished by the different shape of
   the hind legs and by the absence of an apical tubercle on the first
   tarsal article of the male posterior legs. Calodromus malgosiae sp. nov.
   from Myanmar is also described based on a single male specimen; it is
   close to Calodromus amabilis Kleine, 1916 but can be distinguished by
   the different shape of the hind legs and by the absence of a tuft of
   hair on the apical tubercles of the first tarsal article of the male
   posterior legs. The following new synonymy is also established: C.
   horishanus Kano, 1930 = C. ito Heller, 1910. A key is provided for the
   identification of the males of the known species of Calodromus
   Guerin-Meneville, 1832. Some locality records are provided; Calodromus
   simplex Heller, 1910 and Calodromus amabilis Kleine, 1916 are recorded
   for the first time from Malaysia.
C1 Bartolozzi, Luca; Museo di Storia Naturale dell'Universita di Firenze,
   Sezione di Zoologia "La Specola", Via Romana 17, 50125 Firenze, Italy,
   Italy.
EM luca.bartolozzi@unifi.it
OI Bartolozzi, Luca/0000-0002-9119-2540
SC Zoology
SN 0003-4541; 1734-1833
BD Systematics; Nomenclature; New taxa; Synonymy; Taxonomy; Key; Land
   zones; Oriental region; Eurasia; Asia
DE Calodromus amabilis; Calodromus simplex [Malaysia /  / New record]. 
   Calodromus kosteliae [Malaysia /  / New species]. 
   Calodromus malgosiae [Myanmar /  / New species]. 
TN Arthropods; Beetles; Insects; Invertebrates
ST Animalia, Arthropoda, Insecta, Coleoptera, Polyphaga, Curculionoidea,
   Brentidae
OR Calodromus - Guerin-Meneville 1832 (Brentidae): [Key to species, Males,
   p. 379]. 
   Calodromus amabilis (Brentidae): [New record]. 
   Calodromus ito - Heller 1910 (Brentidae): [Syn nov, Calodromus
   horishanus Kano 1930, p. 378]. 
   Calodromus kosteliae (Brentidae): [Sp nov, Malaysia, P. 376]. 
   Calodromus malgosiae (Brentidae): [Sp nov, Myanmar, P. 377]. 
   Calodromus simplex (Brentidae): [New record].

PT J

DT Article
TI A new Acanthocyclops Kiefer, 1927 (Copepoda: Cyclopidae) from caves in
   Apuseni Mountains (North-Western Romania).
AU Iepure, Sanda (sanda.iepure@iser-cluj.org) 
   Oarga, Andreea
SO Annales Zoologici (Warsaw)
VL 61
IS 2
PS 427-438
PD 2011
PY 2011
LA English
U1 0
U2 3
AB A new stygobite species Acanthocyclops transylvanicus sp. nov. is
   described from the north-western Romanian Carpathians (Apuseni
   Mountains) and is accommodated in the subterranean kieferi-group.
   Acanthocyclops transylvanicus sp. nov. resembles closely A.
   biarticulatus Monchenko, 1972 in the segmentation pattern of the
   swimming legs (3.2/3.2/3.2/3.2), but differs by the following
   characters: antennary second endopodite segment with 7 setae; distal
   articles of endopodites of P1 and P3 with 4 and 5 setae, respectively;
   absence of coxopodite ornamentation pattern in leg 4; leg 4 endopodite
   with 3-segmented appearance, but lacking a functional articulation
   between the second and third segment. We assume that the 2-segmented
   nature of the leg 4 endopodite as observed in both species is a
   convergent acquisition. The adult shape of the leg 4 endopodite in A.
   transylvanicus sp. nov. results from the simple suppression of an
   arthrodial membrane formation. A. transylvanicus is the ninth
   representative known in Romania which is accommodated in the
   kieferi-group. An identification key for the species of kieferi-group
   known to occur in Romania is given.
C1 Iepure, Sanda; Institutul de Speologie "Emil Racovipa", Cluj Department,
   Clinicilor 400006, Cluj, Romania, Romania.
EM sanda.iepure@iser-cluj.org
RI Iepure, Sanda/AAA-6388-2019
OI Iepure, Sanda/0000-0002-3748-3478
SC Marine &Freshwater Biology; Environmental Sciences &Ecology; Zoology
SN 0003-4541; 1734-1833
BD Systematics; Nomenclature; New taxa; Taxonomy; Key; Habitat; Freshwater
   habitat; Land zones; Palaearctic region; Eurasia; Europe
DE Acanthocyclops kieferi group [Subterranean water / Groundwater habitat /
   Distribution] [Romania /  / Key to species] [ /  / ]. 
   Acanthocyclops transylvanicus [Romania /  / New species]. 
TN Arthropods; Crustaceans; Invertebrates
ST Animalia, Arthropoda, Crustacea, Copepoda, Cyclopoida
OR Acanthocyclops kieferi group (Cyclopoida): [Key to species, Romania, P.
   437]. 
   Acanthocyclops transylvanicus (Cyclopoida): [Sp nov, Romania, P. 429]. 
UT ZOOREC:ZOOR14802013055
DA 2020-09-17

DT Article
TI The tribe Cossyphodini (Coleoptera: Tenebrionidae: Pimeliinae) of the
   Arabian Peninsula, with notes on biology and ecology.
AU Schawaller, Wolfgang (wolfgang.schawaller@smns-bw.de) 
   Sharaf, Mostafa R.
   Aldawood, Abdulrahman S.
SO Annales Zoologici (Warsaw)
VL 61
IS 3
PS 439-444
PD 2011
PY 2011
LA English
U1 0
U2 1
AB Cossyphodes asiricus sp. nov. is described from an isolated relict
   mountainous forest in the Asir Mts. in south-western Saudi Arabia. This
   myrmecophilous species was found in a debris chamber of a Pheidole ant
   nest. It differs from the Palaearctic and adjacent Ethiopian congeners
   mainly by the development and orientation of the pronotal and elytral
   keels. Paranrellon sociale was collected on the eastern side of the
   Arabian Peninsula in the United Arab Emirates in a completely different,
   but not isolated, and distinctly drier habitat. Both species are
   photographed, the localities are mapped, and some notes on biology and
   ecology are given.
C1 Schawaller, Wolfgang; Staatliches Museum fuer Naturkunde, Rosenstein 1,
   D-70191 Stuttgart, Germany, Germany.
EM wolfgang.schawaller@smns-bw.de
RI Aldawood, Abdulrahman Saad/M-3657-2019
SC Zoology; Environmental Sciences &Ecology
SN 0003-4541; 1734-1833

   region; Palaearctic region; Eurasia; Asia; India

   New nest associate species] [Saudi Arabia /  / New species from
   hymenopteran nest]. 
   Cossyphodini [Asia / Arabian Peninsula & adjacent regions / Biology;
   distribution; systematics]. 
   Paramellon sociale [Rajasthan /  / New record] [Iran /  / ] [United Arab
   Emirates /  / ]. 
   Pheidole [Nest and burrow fauna / Cossyphodes asiricus (Coleoptera) /
   New nest associate species] [Saudi Arabia /  / New nest associated
   coleopteran species].

   Arabia, Nest associate of Pheidole (Hymenoptera), p. 440]. 
   Cossyphodini - Wasmann 1899 (Tenebrionidae).

TI On the subgenus Lasiocassis Gressitt (Coleoptera: Chrysomelidae:
   Cassidinae), with description of a new species from South Korea.
AU Borowiec, Lech (cassidae@biol.uni.wroc.pl) 
   Cho, Hee-Wook
SO Annales Zoologici (Warsaw)
VL 61
IS 3
PS 445-451
PD 2011
PY 2011
LA English
U1 0
U2 0
AB The hitherto monotypic subgenus Lasiocassis Gressitt, 1952 of the genus
   Cassida Linnaeus, 1758 is redefined and reviewed. Cassida vespertina
   Boheman, 1862 is redescribed and a new species, Cassida koreana, is
   described from South Korea. The subgenus is distributed in the eastern
   part of Palaearctic Region south to Taiwan.

   Zoological Institute, University of Wroclaw, Przybyszewskiego 63/77,

TI New and little known species of the tribe Quasimusini Schimmel et
   Tarnawski, 2009 (Coleoptera: Elateridae) from Palaearctic and Oriental
   regions.
AU Schimmel, Rainer (rainer.schimmel@gmx.de) 
   Tarnawski, Dariusz
SO Annales Zoologici (Warsaw)
VL 61
IS 3
PS 453-462
PD 2011
PY 2011
LA English
U1 0
U2 2
AB Eight new species of the tribe Quasimusini Schimmel et Tarnawski, 2009
   from China, Indonesia, and Himalaya (Bhutan and Sikkim) are described
   and illustrated. New records on two known species from Laos are given.
   Wittmeroquasimus irianjayensis sp. nov. is the first of the genus
   Wittrrreroquasimus, and Striatoquasimus carinatissimus sp. nov. is the
   second species of the genus Striatogaasimus recorded from Indonesia.
   Keys to the species of the genus Wittmeroquasimus from China and from
   Himalaya are provided. New species: Qua.simas rrrasei sp. nov.,
   Striatoquasimus carinatissimus sp. nov., Wittmerogrursinrus fujianensis
   sp. nov., W. holzschuhi sp. nov., W. irianjayensis sp. nov., W.
   shiniushanensis sp. nov. and W. sikkimensis sp. nov.

DT Article
TI Taxonomic study on the genus Pselaphodes Westwood (Coleoptera:
   Staphylinidae: Pselaphinae) from China, Part II.
AU Yin, Zi-Wei (yin_ziwei@yahoo.com) 
   Li, Li-Zhen
   Zhao, Mei-Jun
SO Annales Zoologici (Warsaw)
VL 61
IS 3
PS 463-481
PD 2011
PY 2011
LA English
U1 0
U2 1
AB This is the second paper of a series dealing with the Chinese fauna of
   the large genus Pselaphodes Westwood, 1870. Twelve new species and a new
   synonym are presented: P. bomiensis sp. nov. (Xizang); P. biwenxuani sp.
   nov. (Xizang); P. condylus sp. nov. (Guizhou); P. cuonaus sp. nov.
   (Xizang); P. fengtingae sp. nov. (Zhejiang); P. gongshanensis sp. nov.
   (Yunnan); P. hanmiensis sp. nov. (Xizang); P. jizushanus sp. nov.
   (Yunnan); P. meniscus sp. nov. (Sichuan); P. parvus sp. nov. (Guizhou);
   P. pectinatus sp. nov. (Hainan); P. wuyinus Yin et al., 2010 syn. nov. =
   P. tianmuensis Yin et al., 2010; and P. yanbini sp. nov. (Guizhou). New
   distributional data and discussion on intraspecific variations of P.
   tianmuensis and P. aculeus are provided. An updated key is given to
   assist in distinguishing all so far known Chinese species of
   Pselaphodes. A checklist of world species of Pselaphodes is also
   provided.

DT Article
TI Review of the Oriental species of the genus Hister Linnaeus, 1758
   (Coleoptera: Histeridae).
AU Mazur, Slawomir (slawomir.mazur@wl.sggw.pl) 
SO Annales Zoologici (Warsaw)
VL 61
IS 3
PS 483-512
PD 2011
PY 2011
LA English
U1 0
U2 2
AB The taxonomical and systematic status of the Oriental species of Hister
   was analyzed. Hister bitimineus is newly described herein. The following
   new synonyms have been established: H. apicelaeris Desbordes, 1919 = H.
   metallicus: Lewis, 1885, syn. nov., H. eneaustus Marseul, 1854 = H.
   duplicatus Marseul, 1854, syn. nov., H. inexspectatus Desbordes, 1923 =
   H. aheneus Cooman, 1938, syn. nov., H. japonicus Marseul, 1854 = H.
   fessus Marseul, 1862, syn. nov., H. pransus Lewis, 1892 = H. pauli
   Desbordes, 1916., syn. nov., H. pteromalus Marseul. 1862 = H.
   dirvisifrons Schmidt, 1895, syn. nov. = H. brahminius Lewis, 1900, syn.
   nov. and H. thibetanus Marseul, 1857 = H. sohieri Marseul, 1870, syn.
   nov. = H. dauphini Lewis, 1905, syn. nov. Lectotypes for some species
   are designated. All the species are keyed and a general distribution is
   given for each of them. H. congener Schmidt, 1885 is new to the Oriental
   (Bhutan) and H. pullatus Erichson, 1834 to the Ethiopian (Ivory Coast)
   Region.
C1 Mazur, Slawomir; Katedra Ochrony Lasu i Ekologii, SGGW, Nowoursynowska
   159/34, 02-776 Warszawa, Poland, Poland.
EM slawomir.mazur@wl.sggw.pl
SC Zoology
SN 0003-4541; 1734-1833

   Key; Land zones; Afrotropical region; Oriental region; Palaearctic
   region; Africa; Eurasia; Asia; China; India

DT Article
TI Two new species of Xorides Latreille from Crete with a checklist of
   Greek Xoridinae Shuckard (Hymenoptera: Ichneumonidae).
AU Hilszczanski, Jacek (hilszezj@ibles.waw.pl) 
   Plewa, Radoslaw
SO Annales Zoologici (Warsaw)
VL 61
IS 3
PS 513-517
PD 2011
PY 2011
LA English
U1 0
U2 0
AB Xorides (Moerophora) dorotae Hilszczanski sp. nov. and X. (Xorides)
   winos Hilszczanski sp. nov. from Crete are newly described and figured.
   Species of Xoridinae (Hymenoptera: Ichneumonidae) from Greece are
   listed. Only X. corcyrensis (Kriechbaumer) and Odontocolon
   append/en/alum (Gravenhorst) had been known so far from the country.
   Odontocolon quercinune Thomson, X. herlandi Clement, X. propinquus
   (Tschek), X. praeeatorius (F.) and X. grarenhorstii Curtis are new for
   the Greek fauna. Aegomorphus krueperi Kraatz (Coleoptera: Cerambycidae)
   is recorded as a host for X. propinquus.

   for the first time.

DT Article
TI Leptus phalangii (De Geer, 1778) (Acari: Actinotrichida: Prostigmata) -
   redescription, ecology and taxonomic notes on its relatives.
AU Makol, Joanna (joanna.makol@up.wroc.pl) 
   Gabrys, Grzegorz
   Laydanowicz, Joanna
SO Annales Zoologici (Warsaw)
VL 61
IS 3
PS 535-546
PD 2011
PY 2011
LA English
U1 0
U2 9
AB A redescription of Leptus phalangii (De Geer, 1778) (= L. nemorunt (C.
   L. Koch, 1836), syn. nov., = L. berwii Fain, 1991, syn. nov.) based on
   adults, deutonymphs and larvae, is supplemented with data on life cycle
   and ecology of the species. Larvae of L. phalangii developed, under
   laboratory conditions, into deutonymphs of L. nemorum, species hitherto
   known only from active postlarval forms. A field-collected female of L.
   phalangii is designated as the neotype.
C1 Makol, Joanna; Institute of Biology, Department of Invertebrate
   Systematics and Ecology, Wroclaw University of Environmental and Life
   Sciences, Kozuchowska 5B, 51-631 Wroclaw, Poland, Poland.
EM joanna.makol@up.wroc.pl
RI Makol, Joanna/A-8681-2017; Gabrys, Grzegorz/AAP-6208-2020
OI Makol, Joanna/0000-0001-8791-4670; Gabrys, Grzegorz/0000-0002-5141-1008
SC Zoology; Developmental Biology; Environmental Sciences &Ecology
SN 0003-4541; 1734-1833

   cycle and development; Ecology; Land zones; Palaearctic region; Eurasia;
   Europe

    / biology]. 
TN Arachnids; Arthropods; Chelicerates; Invertebrates
ST Animalia, Arthropoda, Arachnida, Acari
OR Acarus phalangii - De Geer 1778 (Acari): [Neotype designated, P. 540]. 
   Leptus phalangii - (De Geer 1778) (Acari): [Redescription, P. 537; Syn

TI A new species of the genus Spatulaphorus (Acari: Heterostigmatina:
   Pygmephoridae) phoretic on Geotrupes spiniger (Coleoptera: Geotrupidae)
   from Iran.
AU Rahiminejad, Vahid (hajiqanbar@modares.ac.ir) 
   Hajiqanbar, Hamidreza
   Fathipour, Yaghoub
SO Annales Zoologici (Warsaw)
VL 61
IS 3
PS 547-551
PD 2011
PY 2011
LA English
U1 0
U2 2
AB The mite Spatulaphorus gorganica Rahiminejad et Hajiqanbar sp. nov.
   (Acari: Heterostigmatina: Pygmephoridae) collected under elytra of the
   host beetle, Geotrupes spin /gel. (Marsham, 1802) (Col.: Geotrupidae) is
   described and illustrated from Oak forests of Golestan province, North
   of Iran. Moreover, host range of the genus is reviewed and a key to
   world species of the genus Spatulaphorus is provided.

DT Article
TI Jumping spiders (Araneae: Salticidae) from Southern Nigeria.
AU Wesolowska, Wanda (tomwes@biol.uni.wroc.pl) 
   Russell-Smith, Anthony
SO Annales Zoologici (Warsaw)
VL 61
IS 3
PS 553-619
PD 2011
PY 2011
LA English
U1 0
U2 0
AB Seventy three species of jumping spiders are listed from Nigeria in this
   paper. Among these, the following 26 species are described as new to
   science: Aelu, illns jocgnei sp. nov. ([male] [female] ), Ajaraneola
   mastigophora sp. nov. ([male] [female] ), Brancus occidentalis sp. nov.
   ([male] ), Evarcha grandis sp. nov. ( [female] ), Evarcha idanrensis sp.
   nov. (4 ), Habrocestum personatum sp. nov. ( [female]), Hyllus remotus
   sp. nov. (Y ), Icius olokomei sp. nov. ( [female]), Langelurillus
   quadrirnaculatus sp. nov. ([male] [female]), Menemerus nigeriensis sp.
   nov. (6), Neaetha maxima sp. nov. ( 4 ), Pachyballus oyo sp. nov.
   ([male] [female]), Schenkelia ibadanensis sp. nov. ([male]),
   Stenaeluriellus glaber sp. nov. (d), Stenaelurillus irrbatus sp. nov.
   ([male] [female]), Stenaelurillus pilosus sp. nov. ([male] [female]),
   Stenaelurillus striolatus sp. nov. (d), Thiratoscirtus alveolus sp. nov.
   (4 ), Thiratoscirtus bipaniculus sp. nov. ([female]), Thiratoscirtus
   gambari sp. nov. ([male] [female]), Thiratoscirtus harpago sp. nov.
   ([male]), Thiratoscirtus mirabilis sp. nov. ([male] [female]),
   Thiratoscirtus monstrum sp. nov. (Y ), Thiratoscirtus obudu sp. nov.
   (d), Thiratoscirtus vilis sp. nov. ([female]) and Thiratoscirtus
   yorubanus sp. nov. ([male]). A new species of Baryphas is described but
   not formally named here. One new genus, Ajaraneola gen. nov. is
   described and diagnosed. The female sex of Evarcha bakorensis,
   Heliophanus robustas, Phlegra gagnoa and Thyene hesperia is described
   for the first time. Brancus brevisi Lessert, 1925 is proposed as a
   junior synonym of Brancus muticus Simon, 1902. Two new combinations are
   proposed, Viciria besanconi Berland & Millot, 1941 and Viciria fuseimana
   Simon, 1903 are transferred to the genus Brancus. Baryphas albicinctus
   Berland & Millot, 1941 is removed from synonymy with B. jullierri Simon,
   1902. Mithion hesperius Simon, 1910 is removed from synonymy with
   Modanda aperta Peckham et Peckham, 1903 and transferred to the genus
   Thyene. The composition of the salticid fauna of this region of West
   Africa is discussed and compared to that of other regions of Africa.
C1 Wesolowska, Wanda; Institute of Zoology, Wroclaw University,
   Sienkiewicza 21, 50-335 Wroclaw, Poland, Poland.
EM tomwes@biol.uni.wroc.pl
SC Zoology
SN 0003-4541; 1734-1833
BD Systematics; Nomenclature; New taxa; Description; Combination; Synonymy;
   Taxonomy; Taxonomic position; Land zones; Afrotropical region; Africa
DE Aelurillus jocquei; Thiratoscirtus gambari [Ivory Coast /  / New
   species] [Nigeria /  / ]. 
   Ajaraneola mastigophora; Brancus occidentalis; Evarcha grandis; Evarcha
   idanrensis; Habrocestum personatum; Hyllus remotus; Icius olokomei;

TI THE GENUS CAENOPHANES FOERSTER, 1862 (HYMENOPTERA: BRACONIDAE:
   DORYCTINAE) IN THE WESTERN PALAEARCTIC.
AU Belokobylskij, Sergey A. (doryctes@yahoo.com) 
   Falco-Gari, J. Vicente
   Jimenez-Peydro, Ricardo
SO Annales Zoologici (Warsaw)
VL 61
IS 4
PS 773-787
PD 2011
PY 2011
LA English
U1 0
U2 2
AB The Western Palaearctic species of the genus Caenophanes Foerster are
   reviewed. A new species from the Canary Islands, C. lapalmaensis sp.
   nov., is described. The name C. rugosifrons (Picard) is restored from
   synonymy (stat. resurr.). The redescriptions of C. incompletus
   (Ratzeburg) and C. rugosifrons are given. A key to the Western
   Palaearctic species of Caenophanes is suggested.

AU Radchenko, Alexander (agradchenko@hotmail.com) 
   Dubovikoff, Dmitry
SO Annales Zoologici (Warsaw)
VL 61
IS 4
PS 807-810
PD 2011
PY 2011
LA English
U1 0
U2 1
AB The socially-parasitic ant genus Strongylognathus is reported for
   Afghanistan for the first time, and a new species, S. kabokovi, is
   described based on the single queen. It belongs to the huberi
   species-group and is characterized by the small size. It differs from
   the latter species by the distinctly concave occipital margin, by the
   fines body sculpture, and by the less developed standing pilosity on the
   body.

DT Article
TI DESCRIPTIONS OF TWO NEW SPECIES OF THE FAMILY ORIBOTRITIIDAE (ACARI:
   ORIBATIDA: EUPHTHIRACAROIDEA).
AU Liu, Dong
   Niedbala, Wojciech (niedbala@amu.edu.pl) 
   Stary, Josef
SO Annales Zoologici (Warsaw)
VL 61
IS 4
PS 811-816
PD 2011
PY 2011
LA English
U1 0
U2 3
AB Two new species of the family Oribotritiidae, Mesotritia solhoyi sp.
   nov. from Tibet, China and Oribotritia krivolutskyi sp. nov. from
   Azerbaijan, are described and illustrated. Mesotritia solhoyi is
   distinguished from the related species by the presence of one pair of
   anal setae, three pairs of adanal setae, and 8-10 pairs of long genital
   setae; weakly fusiform head of sensilli; rostral and lamellar setae
   situated at the same level. Oribotritia krivolutskyi is similar to O.
   submolesta, but differs by different number of lateral carinae; much
   longer aggenital setae; longer sensilli, interlamellar and lamellar
   setae; shorter notogastral setae; setae ps2 and ps3 thick and rigid;
   setae ad2 placed more close to ad3 than to setae ad1; slightly different
   shape of sensilli.
C1 Niedbala, Wojciech; Adam Mickiewicz Univ, Dept Anim Taxon & Ecol,
   Umultowska 89, Poznan, PL-61614, Poland, Poland.
EM niedbala@amu.edu.pl

OI Liu, Dong/0000-0001-5009-2466;

PT J
AN ZOOR14907024810
DT Article
TI A synthesis of the present knowledges on the genus Allegrettia Jeannel,
   1928 (Coleoptera, Carabidae, Trechinae).
FT Sintesi delle attuali conoscenze sul genere Allegrettia Jeannel, 1928
   (Coleoptera, Carabidae, Trechinae).
AU Monguzzi, Riccardo (riccardo.monguzzi@tin.it) 
SO Annali del Museo Civico di Storia Naturale "Giacomo Doria"
VL 103
PS 1-70
PD 2011
PY 2011
LA Italian
U1 0
U2 0
AB This paper consists in a substantial review from different points of
   view of the genus Allegrettia Jeannel, 1928, endemic to the Central
   Pre-Alps, one among the most distinctive troglobitic elements of the
   Italian fauna, immediately recognizable from all the other cave dwelling
   Trechinae by its very big size combined with an unusual "pterostichoid
   facies". In effect, of the actually known four species (A. boldorii
   Jeannel, 1928; A. zavattarii Ghidini, 1934; A. pavani Bari & Rossi,
   1965; A. tacoensis Comotti, 1989) the first three have never been easily
   distinguishable because of their great morphological homogeneity, so
   that lately the considerable but chaotic increasing of our faunistic
   knowledges gave rise to the present inextricable accumulation of
   doubtful or indefinite data, without contributing in return to clear
   this uncertain systematic situation. Therefore, a critical revision of
   all the complex of these new known populations, of which several still
   undetermined, could not be longer deferred and the Author studied the
   rich and various material sampled in the course of very long personal
   researches. After a detailed historical reconstruction of the
   biospeleological researches starting from the discovery of the first
   representative of the genus, in this work many observations on general
   ecology, based especially on personal experience and bringing up for
   discussion again any consolidated suppositions on the real subterranean
   environment colonized by Allegrettia, are produced. In the systematic
   part, besides a careful critical examination of all the diacritical
   characters till now considered, a new key to the species, up-to-date and
   based on new principles too, is supplied. Furthermore all species at
   present known, whose a list of all the verified localities is made, are
   discussed in detail, and the following two important taxonomical
   variations are introduced: a description of two new taxa from Val
   Seriana, Bergamo (A. comottii n. sp. and A. pavani rossii n. ssp.) and a
   new synonymy (Allegrettia boldorii Jeannel, 1928 = Allegrettia
   zavattarii Ghidini, 1934 n. syn.). Particular care and attention are
   dedicated to iconography, almost always original and of great importance
   not only in order to distinguish the different species (whose the
   principal diacritical characters - habitus, aedeagus, gonapophysis,
   ligula, labrum - are illustrated) but also to verify the internal
   variability of the species by examining their principal populations.
   Lastly the systematic position of this genus, traditionally related to
   Speotrechus and Boldoriella, is reconsidered and discussed taking in
   account also the larval morphology (compared with that one of some other
   Alpine hypogean Trechinae and mainly of Italaphaenops, whose cephalic
   capsule for the first time is figured) and the metendosternite
   (Crowson's structure), a support element proved to be very important for
   the systematic purposes. On the ground of these indications, it is
   possible conclude that: 1) the two South-Alpine and vicariant genera
   Allegrettia (Central-eastern Lombard Pre-Alps) and Italaphaenops
   (Western Venetian Pre-Alps), because of very important morphological
   synapomorphic features of their larvae and adults, can be regarded as a
   valid and isolated monophyletic unit; 2) because of the larval
   relationships too, also the Caucasian genus Jeannelius, previously
   related with Neotrechus, may probably be connected to this same phyletic
   lineage; 3) although reversing old consolidate taxonomic hypotheses, the
   examination of the Crowson's structure might lead to suppose on the
   contrary that the genus Allegrettia could be perhaps in a still more
   independent position, approaching more to the phyletical line of
   Duvalius than to that one of Aphaenops, assigned by tradition.
C1 Monguzzi, Riccardo; Via M Malpighi 8, Milan, I-20129, Italy, Italy.
EM riccardo.monguzzi@tin.it
SC Zoology
SN 0365-4389
BD Systematics; Nomenclature; New taxa; Description; Synonymy; Taxonomy;
   Key; Land zones; Palaearctic region; Eurasia; Europe
DE Allegrettia [Italy / Alps / Review]. 
   Allegrettia comottii [Italy /  / New species]. 
   Allegrettia pavani rossii [Italy /  / New subspecies]. 
TN Arthropods; Beetles; Insects; Invertebrates
ST Animalia, Arthropoda, Insecta, Coleoptera, Adephaga, Caraboidea,
   Carabidae
OR Allegrettia - Jeannel 1928 (Carabidae): [Taxonomic position, P. 38; Key
   to species, P. 15; Key to subspecies, P. 15]. 
   Allegrettia boldorii - Jeannel 1928 (Carabidae): [Syn nov, Allegrettia
   zavattarii Ghidini 1934, p. 17]. 
   Allegrettia comottii (Carabidae): [Sp nov, Italy, P. 35]. 
   Allegrettia pavani rossii (Carabidae): [Subsp nov, Italy, P. 29]. 
   Italaphaenops - Ghidini 1964 (Carabidae): [First time figured, Cephalic
   capsule, p. 66]. 
UT ZOOREC:ZOOR14907024810
DA 2020-09-17

DT Article
TI A REVIEW OF THE MEDITERRANEAN GENUS ANOMIUS MULSANT & REY, 1870 WITH THE
   DESCRIPTION OF A NEW SPECIES FROM ISRAEL (COLEOPTERA, SCARABAEOIDEA,
   APHODIIDAE).
AU Ziani, Stefano (stefanoziani@alice.it) 
SO Annali del Museo Civico di Storia Naturale "Giacomo Doria"
VL 103
PS 93-132
PD 2011
PY 2011
LA English
U1 0
U2 0
AB A review of the thirteen species belonging to the genus Anomius Mulsant
   & Rey, 1870 is presented. Type specimens were examined for nearly all
   the species. Keys to all the species treated are given. Two groups of
   species inside the genus are proposed, based on characters of supposed
   phylogenetic significance. A new Israeli species (Anomius saturnalis n.
   sp.) is described, a new synonymy (Anomius lekefensis (Baraud, 1981) =
   Anomius baeticus (Mulsant & Rey, 1870)) is proposed and the lectotype of
   Anomius antii (Gridelli, 1930) is designated.

DT Article
TI The species of Malthodes Kiesenwetter, 1852 from Maritime and Ligurian
   Alps (Coleoptera, Cantharidae).
FT Le specie di Malthodes Kiesenwetter, 1852 delle alpi marittime e liguri
   (coleoptera, Cantharidae).
AU Liberti, Gianfranco (gianfrancoliberti@alice.it) 
SO Annali del Museo Civico di Storia Naturale "Giacomo Doria"
VL 103
PS 147-246
PD 2011
PY 2011
LA Italian
U1 0
U2 0
AB The territory here considered includes: on the French side the whole
   Department "Alpes Maritimes"; on the Italian side the Imperia, Cuneo (in
   part) and Savona (in part) provinces. The paper includes 24 Malthodes
   species and subspecies personally observed by the Author (a certanly
   incomplete list), however two more species have been added: one
   (discicollis) because - being very common in the nearby Var Department -
   it is supposedly present in the "Alpes Maritimes" as well; a further one
   (cognatus) for comparison with nigriceps to justify its change of state.
   After an introduction and a species list, a short paragraph on Malthodes
   general morphology has been included, to make clear the meaning of the
   terms used in descriptions: its English translation can be found in
   Appendix. Determination keys follow, separately for males and females
   (but females determination may be not always possible): their English
   translation can be also found in Appendix. In the catalogue a short
   description, known distribution and general notes are supplied, for each
   species, together with the complete list of all collecting localities
   actually studied by the Author and deemed to be known with certainty.
   For all the species here considered, accurate drawings of the last male
   abdominal segments and aedeagi have been included. By no means the 24
   Malthodes species (plus one) here included complete the list: four more
   species have been reported in the literature and, no doubts, future
   researches and findings will allow further additions. Two new species
   are described: Malthodes coryli n. sp. e Malthodes militalpium n. sp.
   Three changes of state are proposed: Malthodes atratus ssp. peyerimhoffi
   n. stat., not a subspecies of M. trifurcatus; Malthodes neglectus
   Mulsant, 1863, n. stat.: good species, not a synonym of dispar Germar,
   1824; Malthodes nigriceps Mulsant, 1863, n. stat.: good species, not a
   synonym of cognatus Costa, 1858. Lastly Malthodes hexacanthus is
   reported as new for Greece.

   Italy.

DT Article
TI Ecologically and Morphologically Remarkable New Cosmet Moth Species of
   the Genus Hyposmocoma (Lepidoptera: Cosmopterigidae) Endemic to the
   Hawaiian Islands, With Reference to the Spectacular Diversity of Larval
   Cases.
AU Schmitz, Patrick (pschmitz@hawaii.edu) 
   Rubinoff, Daniel
SO Annals of the Entomological Society of America
VL 104
IS 1
PS 1-15
PD January 2011
PY 2011
LA English
U1 0
U2 11
AB Hyposmocoma is an endemic Hawaiian moth genus with >330 recognized
   species occupying a remarkable range of ecological habits and exhibiting
   a high degree of variation typical of adaptive radiations. Within this
   diverse genus, some species have evolved intriguing and globally rare
   lifestyles, such as predatory or aquatic caterpillars. There are still
   many undescribed species in the genus, and no current work succinctly
   covers the range of their diversity. We describe nine new species in an
   attempt to demonstrate some of the remarkable ecological and phenotypic
   diversity displayed by species in the genus in a concise format:
   Hyposmocoma carnivora sp. nov. from the island of Hawaii; Hyposmocoma
   eliai sp. nov. Hyposmocoma nohomaalewa sp. nov., and Hyposmocoma
   waikamoi sp. nov. from the island of Kauai; and Hyposmocoma papaiili sp.
   nov., Hyposmocoma pukoa sp. nov., Hyposmocoma pupumoehewa sp. nov.,
   Hyposmocoma opuulaau sp. nov., and Hyposmocoma waikamoi sp. nov. from
   the island of Maui. Although the taxa presented here do not represent a
   monophyletic group with respect to the rest of Hyposmocoma, they
   represent some of the most striking aspects of Hyposmocoma diversity as
   a whole.
C1 Schmitz, Patrick; Department of Plant and Environmental Protection
   Sciences, 310 Gilmore Hall, University of Hawaii, 3050 Maile Way,
   Honolulu, HI 96822, USA, USA.
EM pschmitz@hawaii.edu
SC Zoology
SN 0013-8746; 1938-2901

   Pacific Ocean islands

   Hyposmocoma opuulaau; Hyposmocoma papaiili; Hyposmocoma pukoa;
   Hyposmocoma pupumoehewa; Hyposmocoma wahikanake; Hyposmocoma waikamoi
   [Hawaii /  / New species]. 
TN Arthropods; Insects; Invertebrates; Lepidopterans

   Gelechioidea, Cosmopterigidae

   Hyposmocoma eliai (Cosmopterigidae): [Sp nov, Hawaii, P. 6]. 
   Hyposmocoma nohomaalewa (Cosmopterigidae): [Sp nov, Hawaii, P. 9].

DT Article
TI A New Specimen of the Genus Octodontobradys (Orophodontidae,
   Octodontobradyinae) From the Late Miocene-Pliocene of the Southwestern
   Amazon Basin, Brazil.
AU Guilherme, Edson (guilherme@ufac.br) 
   Bocquentin, Jean
   Porto, Alice S.
SO Anuario do Instituto de Geociencias
VL 34
IS 2
PS 38-45
PD 2011
PY 2011
LA English
U1 0
U2 0
AB This study presents an almost complete mandible of Octodontobradys sp.
   from the late Miocene-Pliocene of the Solimoes Formation from a locality
   on the border between Brazil and Bolivia, in southwestern Amazonia. The
   two almost complete mandibular rami, together with fragments of fossils
   from other taxa, were found on the left bank of the Abuna River, upriver
   from the town of Placido de Castro, in the Brazilian state of Acre. The
   form of the symphyseal region of the mandible, and the elongated and
   bilobated outline of the alveoli of the m2-3-4 molariforms place the
   specimen clearly in the genus Octodontobradys. However, the new specimen
   differs from O. puruensis in (a) the anterior position of the posterior
   external aperture of the mandibular canal, and (b) the wider and more
   anteriorly inclined symphyseal region. The mandible described here
   represents the first specimen of the genus Octodontobradys found outside
   of the holotype locality, Talisma, in the Brazilian state of Amazonas
   and enabled us to emend the diagnoses of Subfamily Octodontobradyinae.
C1 Guilherme, Edson; Universidade Federal do Acre, Laboratorio de Pesquisas
   Paleontologicas (LPP), BR 364, Km 04, 69.915-900. Rio Branco, AC,
   Brazil, Brazil.
EM guilherme@ufac.br

PT J

DT Article
TI Epibiotic sponges on the hairy triton Fusitriton magellanicus in the SW
   Atlantic Ocean, with the description of Myxilla (Styloptilon) canepai
   sp. nov.
AU Schejter, Laura (schejter@inidep.edu.ar) 
   Bertolino, Marco
   Calcinai, Barbara
   Cerrano, Carlo
   Bremec, Claudia
SO Aquatic Biology
VL 14
IS 1
PS 9-20
PD 2011
PY 2011
UR http://www.int-res.com/journals/ab/ab-home/
AW http://www.int-res.com/abstracts/ab/v14/n1/p9-20/
LA English
U1 0
U2 2
AB In the present study we identified a total of 26 sponge taxa, to be
   added to the 4 sponge species previously registered, living epizoically
   on Fusitriton magellanicus shells, an abundant and frequent gastropod in
   the shelf-break frontal area of the Argentine Sea, SW Atlantic Ocean.
   The majority of the recorded sponges were encrusting living specimens of
   this gastropod, the most frequent ones being Hymedesmia (Stylopus)
   antarctica (20%), Clathria spp. (18%), Dictyonella spp. (13%) and
   Tedania spp. (9%) We described one species, Myxilla (Styloptilon)
   canepai sp. nov., and extended the distribution of Clathria (Microciona)
   antarctica and Stelodoryx cribri-gera northwards. We also registered,
   for the second time after its description, the species Stelo-doryx
   argentinae. Considering that the study area is a soft bottom and the
   only available substrates for settlement of sessile species are either
   external mineralized skeletons of living organisms, empty shells or
   crustacean carapaces, we conclude that shells of the gastropod F.
   magellanicus play a very important role for settlement of sponge species
   in the area. Moreover, possibly only living F. magellanicus (not the
   empty or pagurized shells) are important as a settlement substrate
   because the few specimens found in empty shells could be considered as
   rare occurrences.
C1 Schejter, Laura; Consejo Nacional de Investigaciones Cientificas y
   Tecnicas (CONICET), Instituto Nacional de Investigacion y Desarrollo
   Pesquero (INIDEP), Paseo Victoria Ocampo 1, 7600 Mar del Plata,
   Argentina, Argentina.
EM schejter@inidep.edu.ar
RI Cerrano, Carlo/AAF-3557-2019; Schejter, Laura/AAR-1106-2020
OI Schejter, Laura/0000-0001-5443-4048; BERTOLINO,

DT Article; Meeting paper
TI The first fossil cyphophthalmid harvestman from Baltic amber.
AU Dunlop, Jason A. (jason.dunlop@mfn-berlin.de) 
   Mitov, Plamen G.
SO Arachnologische Mitteilungen
VL 40
PS 47-54
PD January 2011
PY 2011
LA English
U1 0
U2 2
AB The first fossil cyphophthalmid harvestman (Opiliones: Cyphophthalmi)
   from Palaeogene (Eocene) Baltic amber is described. This is only the
   third fossil example of this basal harvestman lineage; the others being
   from the probably slightly younger Bitterfeld amber and the much older,
   early Cretaceous, Myanmar (Burmese) amber. Although incomplete and
   lacking most of the appendages, the new Baltic amber fossil can be
   identified as a female. The somatic characters preserved, especially
   spiracle morphology and the coxo-genital region, allow it to be assigned
   with some confidence to the extant genus Siro Latreille, 1796
   (Sironidae). This fossil is formally described here as Siro balticus sp.
   nov. It resembles modern North American Siro species more than modern
   European ones, and can be distinguished principally on its relatively
   large size and the outline form of the body.
C1 Dunlop, Jason A.; Humboldt Univ, Museum Nat Kunde, Invalidenstr 43,
   Berlin, Germany, Germany.
EM jason.dunlop@mfn-berlin.de
SC Zoology
SN 1018-4171
BD Systematics; Nomenclature; New taxa; Geological time periods; Caenozoic;
   Tertiary; Palaeogene
DE Siro balticus [Eocene /  / New species; Described from amber]. 
TN Arachnids; Arthropods; Chelicerates; Invertebrates
ST Animalia, Arthropoda, Arachnida, Opiliones
OR Siro balticus (Opiliones): [Sp nov, Type locality not given, Eocene, P.
   49, Described from amber; Fossil].

OA DOAJ Gold

TI TWO NEW PSEUDOSCORPIONS FROM THE UN ADMINISTERED PROVINCE OF KOSOVO AND
   CROATIA.
AU Curcic, B.P.M.
   Radja, T.
   Dimitrijevic, R.N.

   Milincic, M.

SO Archives of Biological Sciences
VL 63
IS 1
PS 235-244
PD 2011
PY 2011
LA English
U1 0
U2 5
AB Two new epigean pseudoscorpion species belonging to the family
   Chthoniidae - Chthonius (Ephippiochthonius) metohicus n. sp. and
   Chthonius (Ephippiochthonius) civitatisveti n. sp. from the UN
   Administered Province of Kosovo and Southern Croatia, respectively, are
   described. The newly erected taxa are endemic to each of the areas
   studied. Their taxonomic relationship with their phenetically close
   congeners Chthonius (Ephippiochthonius) bidentatus Beier, 1939,
   Chthonius (Ephippiochthonius) kemza Curcic Lee et Makarov, 1993 and
   Chthonius (Ephippiochthonius) tetrachelatus (Preyssler, 1790) and
   comparative morphological traits are described.

   Serbia, Serbia.

TI CHTHONIUS (GLOBOCHTHONIUS) MEDEONIS N. SP.: A NEW CAVE FALSE SCORPION
   FROM MONTENEGRO.
AU Curcic, B.P.M.
   Curcic, S.B.
   Curcic, Nina B.
   Ilic, B.S.
SO Archives of Biological Sciences
VL 63
IS 1
PS 245-250
PD 2011
PY 2011
LA English
U1 0
U2 3
AB The pseudoscorpion sample from a cave in Montenegro has been studied. A
   new species, Chthonius (Globochthonius) medeonis n. sp. is described. A
   reanalysis of the type material of Chthonius (Ephippiochthonius)
   polychaetus Hadzi supports its transfer to the subgenus Chthonius
   (Globochthonius Beier). The species studied is considered to be endemic
   to the Balkan Peninsula. The diagnostic characteristics of the analyzed
   taxon are thoroughly described or figured. Taxonomic interrelationships
   and geographic distribution are briefly discussed.

PT J
AN ZOOR14708058281
DT Article
TI Oscheius amsactae n. sp (Nematoda: Rhabditida), a necromenic associate
   of red-hairy caterpillar, Amsacta moori (Lepidoptera: Arctiidae) from
   Kanpur district, India.
AU Ali, Syed Sharafat
   Pervez, Rashid (rashid_pervez@rediffmail.com) 
   Andrabi, Riyaz
   Sharma, Ruchika
   Verma, V.
SO Archives of Phytopathology and Plant Protection
VL 44
IS 9
PS 871-881
PD 2011
PY 2011
LA English
U1 0
U2 2
AB Oscheius amsactae n. sp. is described as a necromenic associate of
   red-hairy caterpillar Amsacta moori (Lepidoptera: Arctiidae) from Vigna
   radiata ((L.) Wilczek) cultivated field at Indian Institute of Pulses
   Research, Kanpur, India. This new species resembles with Rhabditis (O.)
   columbiana (Stock et al. 2005), however, it differs in having smaller
   body length ([female] L = 1100-1288 [mu]m), lesser b value (b =
   4.9-6.1), much smaller body length (c = 14-20.5), smaller spicule length
   (56-57 [mu]m) and small gubernaculum length (20-27 [mu]m), number of
   genital papillae and position of excretory pore. O. amsactae n. sp. can
   be compared with R. (O.) guentheri (Sudhaus and Hooper 1994) but differs
   in having a leptoderan bursa, different shape of spicule, number and
   arrangement of genital papillae. It also differs from R. (O.) necromena
   (Sudhaus and Schulte 1989) in having longer and narrower stoma and
   difference in shape of glottoid apparatus, smaller body length and shape
   of bursa. The new species closely resembles O. shamimi (Tahseen and Nisa
   (2006)) but differs in having narrower lip region (lip region diameter
   7.1-7.9 [mu]m vs. 11-12 [mu]m in O. shamimi); shorter males (L = 594-804
   [mu]m vs. L = 1012 [mu]m in O. shamimi). Moreover, the shape of spicule
   is also different, O. amsactae n. sp. has crochet-needle shaped tip of
   spicule whereas it is slightly curved in O. shamimi. Bursa is leptoderan
   in O. amsactae n. sp. whereas it is pseudopeloderan in O. shamimi.
   Additionally, molecular characterisation and electron microscopic
   studies confirm that it is distinctive from other species of the genus
   and it is a new species.
C1 Pervez, Rashid; Indian Inst Pulses Res, Kanpur, Uttar Pradesh, India,
   India.
EM rashid_pervez@rediffmail.com
SC Parasitology; Zoology
SN 0323-5408
BD Systematics; Nomenclature; New taxa; Parasites diseases and disorders;
   Parasites; Helminth parasites; Hosts; Insect hosts; Land zones; Oriental
   region; Eurasia; Asia; India
DE Amsacta moori [Nematode parasites / Oscheius amsactae / New parasite
   species] [Uttar Pradesh /  / New nematode parasite species]. 
   Oscheius amsactae [Lepidopteran hosts / Amsacta moori / New parasite
   species] [Uttar Pradesh /  / New species from lepidopteran host]. 
TN Arthropods; Insects; Invertebrates; Lepidopterans; Nematodes
ST Animalia, Arthropoda, Insecta, Lepidoptera, Glossata, Heteroneura,
   Noctuoidea, Arctiidae, Nematoda
OR Amsacta moori (Arctiidae): [Host]. 
   Oscheius amsactae (Nematoda): [Sp nov, Uttar Pradesh, Parasite of
   Amsacta moori (Lepidoptera), p. 873; Parasite]. 
UT ZOOREC:ZOOR14708058281

PT J
AN ZOOR14809063825
DT Article
TI Acrobeloides ishraqi sp n. and Acrobeloides mushtaqi sp n. (Nematoda:
   Rhabditida) from chickpea rhizosphere, Uttar Pradesh, India.
AU Pervez, Rashid (rashid_pervez@rediffmail.com) 
SO Archives of Phytopathology and Plant Protection
VL 44
IS 15
PS 1438-1446
PD 2011
PY 2011
LA English
U1 0
U2 1
AB Two new species of nematode in the genus Acrobeloides were found from
   rhizosphere of chickpea from Jhansi and Faizabad districts of Uttar
   Pradesh, India. Acrobeloides ishraqi sp. n. and A. mushtaqi were
   identified and described on the basis of morphological observations.
   Measurement and morphological observation of different stages of A.
   ishraqi were taken and compared with known species of the genus.
   Acrobeloides ishraqi sp. n. is closely related to Acrobeloides
   bodenheimeri (Steiner G. 1936. Opuscula miscellanea nematologica, IV.
   Proceedings of the Helminthological Society of Washington. Vol. 3. p.
   74-80.), Thorne G. 1937. A revision of the nematode family Cephalobidae
   Chitwood&Chitwood, 1934. Proceedings of Helminth Society, Washington.
   Vol. 4. p. 1-16; however, it differs in having longer body 0.99-1.19
   [mu]m (vs. L 0.655-0.821 [mu]m); longer stoma 15.5-16.49 [mu]m (vs.
   stoma 11-13 mm), longer pharyngeal corpus 179.4-223.1 [mu]m (vs. pharynx
   140-170 m); larger bulb 24.25-38.8 mm (vs. 19-25 [mu]m); bulb is
   spherical (vs. ovoid), of lesser a value 10.5-15.8 (vs. a 16.6-23.5);
   longer rectum 31.04-42.68 mm. (vs. rectum 20-27 mm) and absence of males
   (vs. male present). Tail shape is blunt in sp. n. vs. rounded terminus.
   A. ishraqi sp. n. also compared with Acrobeloides arenicola (Abolafia J,
   Pena-Santiago R. 2003. Nematodes of the order Rhabditida from Andalucia
   Oriental, Spain. The genus Acrobeloides (Cobb, 19-24) Thorne, 1937, with
   description of A. arenicola sp. n. and a key to species. J Nematode
   Morphol Syst. 5: 107-130) but differs in having longer body (vs. c =
   9.6-10.5); lesser C1 value (vs. C1 = 3.3-3.7); lesser number of labial
   probolae (vs. labial probolae 5); shape of female tail (vs. tail with
   pointed terminus). A. mushtaqi sp. n. comprises of 0.49-0.79 mm long
   nematodes, with annulated cuticle all over the body. Body pores are very
   prominent. Reproductive system monoprodelphic with posteriorly
   out-stretched ovary extending beyond vulva with single flexure. New
   species close resemblance to A. bodenheimeri (Steiner G. 1936. Opuscula
   miscellanea nematologica, IV. Proceedings of the Helminthological
   Society of Washington. Vol. 3. p. 74-80) Thorne G. 1937. A revision of
   the nematode family Cephalobidae Chitwood&Chitwood, 1934. Proceedings of
   Helminth Society, Washington. Vol. 4. p. 1-16, but differs in having
   prominent body pores, greater a value (vs. a 16-24 in A. bodenheimeri);
   lesser number of lateral lines (vs. lateral field with five incisures);
   difference in lip region n. sp. bears a pair of sensilla (vs. flattened
   amalgamated lips in A. bodenheimeri).
C1 Pervez, Rashid; Indian Inst Pulses Res, Div Crop Protect, Kanpur, Uttar
   Pradesh 208024, India, India.
EM rashid_pervez@rediffmail.com
SC Zoology
SN 0323-5408
BD Systematics; Nomenclature; New taxa; Land zones; Oriental region;
   Eurasia; Asia; India
DE Acrobeloides ishraqi; Acrobeloides mushtaqi [Uttar Pradesh /  / New
   species]. 
TN Invertebrates; Nematodes
ST Animalia, Nematoda
OR Acrobeloides ishraqi (Nematoda): [Sp nov, Uttar Pradesh, P. 1441].

TI OCCURRENCE OF ENTEDONONECREMNUS BIMACULATUS HANSSON & LASALLE
   (HYMENOPTERA: EULOPHIDAE) ON ALEURODICUS SP. (HEMIPTERA: ALEYRODIDAE).

   (HYMENOPTERA: EULOPHIDAE) EM ALEURODICUS SP. (HEMIPTERA: ALEYRODIDAE).
AU Thomazini, M.J. (marcilio@cnpf.embrapa.br) 
   Costa, V.A.
SO Arquivos do Instituto Biologico Sao Paulo
VL 78
IS 2
PS 321-323
PD 2011
PY 2011
LA Portuguese
U1 0
U2 0
AB This paper reports the first occurrence of the parasitoid
   Entedononecremnus bimaculatus Hansson&LaSalle (Hymenoptera: Eulophidae)
   in Brazil. The insect was recorded on whitefly nymphs of Aleurodicus sp.
   (Hemiptera: Aleyrodidae), on Piper hispidinervum C. DC., in the county
   of Rio Branco, state of Acre, Brazil. The parasitism was 27.2%, with 22
   specimens collected.

DT Article
TI The Catch Per Unit of Swept Area (CPUA) and Estimated Biomass of Large
   Head Hairtail (Trichiurus lepturus) with an Improved Trawl in the
   Persian Gulf and Gulf of Oman, Iran.
AU Shojaei, Mehdi Ghodrati
   Motlagh, Seyyed Amin Taghavi
SO Asian Fisheries Science
VL 24
IS 2
PS 209-217
PD 2011
PY 2011
LA English
U1 0
U2 0
AB The Kish trawler fleet targets large head hairtail (Trichiurus lepturus)
   in the Persian Gulf and the Gulf of Oman. These vessels are equipped
   with a new improved trawl. The objectives of this study were (i) to
   estimate the catch per unit area (CPUA) and biomass of T. lepturus, (ii)
   to identify the catch composition and percentage of target and bycatch
   species in the total catch and (iii) to compare the CPUA between two
   selected strata using a bottom trawl survey. Surveys were conducted
   during the periods August to October 2007 in the Persian Gulf and Gulf
   of Oman. The sampling area was divided into two strata and a stratified
   random sampling design was used to determine sampling sites. Catch per
   unit of area varied significantly between the two selected strata
   (P<0.001). Mean CPUA for T. lepturus in the total area was 4,308
   kg.nm-2. The total biomass of T. lepturus was estimated to be 842 tonnes
   in stratum 1 and 1,430 tonnes in stratum 2. Trichiurus lepturus made up
   74.4% of the total weight in stratum 1 and 70.02% in stratum 2. Among
   the non-target species in the trawl catches, the species with highest
   catch rate were Pampus argenteus (4.629%), Batoids (2.274%), Carangidae
   (2.693%) and Ilisha sp. (2.672%) in stratum 1 and Carangidae (5.710%),
   P. argenteus (5.245%), Batoids (3.256%) and Ilisha sp. (2.995%) in
   stratum 2.
SC Zoology; Environmental Sciences &Ecology
SN 0116-6514; 2073-3720
BD Ecology; Population dynamics; Marine zones; Indian Ocean; North Indian
   Ocean
DE Trichiurus lepturus [Biomass /  / ] [Population density / Catch per unit
   area / ] [Persian Gulf / Iran / ]. 
TN Chordates; Fish; Vertebrates
ST Animalia, Chordata, Vertebrata, Pisces, Osteichthyes, Actinopterygii,
   Perciformes, Trichiuridae
OR Trichiurus lepturus (Trichiuridae). 
UT ZOOREC:ZOOR14803025193
DA 2020-09-17
ER

PT J
AN ZOOR14802014165
DT Article
TI Rapid Assessment of a Coral Reef Community in a Marginal Habitat in the
   Southern Caribbean: A Simple Way to Know What's out There.
AU Belford, S.
   Phillip, M.
SO Asian Journal of Biological Sciences
VL 4
IS 7
PS 520-531
PD 2011
PY 2011
LA English
U1 0
U2 2
AB Reef monitoring programs can utilize simple effective techniques to
   collect abundance and distribution data winch can be used to monitor
   long-term effects of human-environment interactions on reef benthos.
   Line and point intercept and quadrat methods were used to collect data
   at 2 sites located on the northeastern coast of Trinidad, West Indies,
   in the southern Caribbean. The cliversity and abundance of reef-building
   corals were assessed annually from 2006-2008 for three intertidal reef
   flat areas at Toco Bay. Horizontal zones were divided into upper,
   intermediate and lower intertidal from the shore and were assessed at
   Taco Bay. An additional fourth zone was surveyed at Salybia Bay. Annual
   live cnidarian abundance along four randomly selected transects at Toco
   Bay averaged 55.6% (2006-2008); Zoanthid sp. comprised 40% abundance and
   the hydrocoral 1.1illepora alcicornis and the scleractinian corals,
   Siderastrea radians and Porites porites the remaining 13.3%. Live
   abundance at Salybia Bay was 9.4% and included only P. porites (4.4%)
   and Z. social us. Quadrat data collected at both sites showed cnidarian
   abundance at Toco Bay (n = 11) and Salybia Bay (n = 15) to be 47.9%
   (8.7% scleractinian and 39.2% zoanthids) and 10.3% (4.5% scleractinian
   and 5.8% zoanthids), respectively. Coral species diversity at Taco Bay
   (Simpson's index, D = 0.68) was higher than at Salybia Bay throughout
   the inner reef fiat. This study provides the first quantitative coral
   abundance and distribution data effectively using rapid reef-monitoring
   assessment methods for Trinidad and provided a quick and simple way to
   estimate coral and benthic coverage in both intertidal reef systems.
C1 Belford, S.; Department of Curriculum and teaching, Auburn University,
   5040 Haley Center, Auburn, AL 36849-5212, USA, USA.
SC Environmental Sciences &Ecology; Zoology
SN 1996-3351
BD Ecology; Population dynamics; Marine zones; Atlantic Ocean; North
   Atlantic
DE Anthozoa [Community structure /  / corals; reef-building taxa]
   [Population size / Abundance / ] [Caribbean Sea / Trinidad and Tobago,
   Trinidad / ]. 
TN Coelenterates; Invertebrates
ST Animalia, Cnidaria
OR Anthozoa (Cnidaria). 
UT ZOOREC:ZOOR14802014165
DA 2020-09-17
ER

AN ZOOR14803020581

TI A new ant species from Borneo closely resembling Tetramorium flagellatum

AU Sorger, Daniela Magdalena (dm.sorger@gmx.at) 
SO Asian Myrmecology

LA English
U1 0
U2 3
AB Tetramorium lucyae sp. nov. from Gunung Murud (Kelabit Highlands),
   Sarawak, Borneo is described and recognized as a member of the
   Tetramorium ciliatum-species group. The species closely resembles
   Tetramorium flagellatum Bolton, 1977. A discussion of the discrimination
   of the two species is presented.

TI New report of the coral-associated decapods from the early Messinian
   (Late Miocene) of Acquabona, Rosignano Marittimo (Toscana, Italy).
AU de Angeli, Antonio (antonio.deangeli@alice.it) 
   Garassino, Alessandro
   Pasini, Giovanni
SO Atti della Societa Italiana di Scienze Naturali e del Museo Civico di
   Storia Naturale in Milano
VL 152
IS 2
PS 107-122
PD Fascicolo 2011
PY 2011
LA English
U1 0
U2 0
AB We report a coral-associated decapods from the early Messinian (Late
   Miocene) of Acquabona, Rosignano Marittimo, Livorno (Toscana, Italy).
   This study allowed to identify these species, as follows: Galathea cfr.
   G. sguamifera Leach, 1814 (Galatheidae Samouelle, 1819), Pisi-dia kokayi
   (Muller, 1974) (Porcellanidae Haworth, 1825), Pilumnus cfr. P.
   mediterraneus (Lorenthey, 1897) (Pilumnidae Samouelle, 1819), Actaea
   calzadai Muller, 1984, Xantho,noldai icu.c (Yanakevich, 1977), Haydnella
   cfr. H. steiningeri Muller, 1984, and Liomera bagaglioi n. sp.
   (Xanthidae MacLeay, 1838). The studied fauna has some affinities with
   the Miocene faunas of Mediterranean area, especially with the fauna from
   the Neogene of Catalonia (Spain). It is the first report of
   coral-associated decapods from the Miocene of Italy.

TI Pleuronassa timerchidouensis n. gen., n. sp. (Axiidea, Callianassidae)
   from the Calcaires a slumps de Taghit Fm., Late Campanian of the Moyenne
   Moulouya, NE Morocco.
AU Osso-Morales, Alex (aosso@comt.cat) 
   Garassino, Alessandro
   Vega, Francisco J.
   Artal, Pedro
SO Atti della Societa Italiana di Scienze Naturali e del Museo Civico di
   Storia Naturale in Milano
VL 152
IS 2
PS 165-175
PD Fascicolo 2011
PY 2011
LA English
U1 0
U2 0
AB The new fossil decapod locality discovered recently in the NE extreme
   flank of the Chebka Timerchidou mountain, at the Moyenne Moulouya, NE of
   Morocco has yielded a rich decapod assemblage such as Hasaracancer
   merijaensis Osso, Artal & Vega, 2011, Costacopluma maroccana OssO, Artal
   & Vega, 2010, and Ophthalmoplax minimus Osso, Artal & Vega, 2010. We
   report Pleuronassa timerchidouensis n. gen., n. sp. (Callianassidae
   Dana, 1852) from the same locality. It represents the second species of
   thalassinid from the Upper Cretaceous of Morocco following the recent
   discovery of Ncocallichirus agadirensis Garassino, De Angeli & Pasini,
   2011, from the Cenomanian of Agadir (W Morocco).

DT Article
TI Noteridae. Dytiscidae (Coleoptera) from Gabon (eighth part). Monts de
   Cristal.
FT Noteridae, Dytiscidae (Coleoptera) du Gabon (8eme partie). Monts de
   Cristal.
AU Bilardo, Armando (armando@studiobilardo.it) 
   Rocchi, Saverio
SO Atti della Societa Italiana di Scienze Naturali e del Museo Civico di
   Storia Naturale in Milano
VL 152
IS 2
PS 177-231
PD Fascicolo 2011
PY 2011
LA French
U1 0
U2 0
AB This work concerns the Coleoptera Hydradephaga collected in eight
   localities of Monts de Cristal (Republic of Gabon) included locality of
   Tchimbele into the National Park of Monts de Cristal in years 2006 -
   2010; altogether 76 species are listed (3 Noteridae and 73 Dytiscidae)
   of which 51 species found in the Park. The authors describe two new
   species: Copelatus angouei (group romans, sensu Guignot, 1961,
   distinguishable from other species of group by small size, the robust
   conformation, the upper side clearly microreticulate covered by fine and
   thick punctuation which give it an opaque look and by characteristic
   penis). Copelatus ogueunri (group irinus, subgroup assinulis, sensu
   Guignot, 1961, related to assinilis Regimbart, 1895, distinguishable by
   longer spine of metatibia clearly curved at third apical in both sexes
   and by characteristic penis) and one new subspecies: Copelatus
   la.cckonvi tehinhelensis (group Onus, subgroup irinus, sensu Guignot,
   1961, characterized by very small size, by narrowed profile of the body
   from shoulders in some specimens and by the upper side finely
   microreticulate, penis, very characteristic, is identical to typical
   form). The examination of two sintypes of Copelatus variegatus
   Regimbart, 1895 (group erichsoni, subgroup atrosu/cants, sensu Guignot.
   1961) of Museum Nationale d'Histoire Naturelle of Paris and of specimens
   of related species of the Museums of Tervuren and Bruxelles permitted
   the determination of the specimens of C. variegatus collected during
   research and the redescription of the species known till now by the two
   sintypes (here respectively designate lectotype and paralectotype);
   meanwhile a new species has been identified: Copelatus mender, belonging
   to same group and subgroup of C. variegatus. misidentified with
   veritable C. variegatus. Some taxa of aquatic macroinvertebrates
   (Hexapoda, Malacostraca, Clitellata et Mollusca) in the zone collected
   and determined by a Researcher of IRAF (CENAREST, Gabon). Blaise Mhoye
   Rollinat, who had participated in mission 2010, are furnished.
   Observations on some of the collected species and some ecological data
   of the biocenoses that populate the zone and some considerations on
   aquatic Coleoptera habitats are presented. The name of the species
   Copelatus efautensis Bilardo & Rocchi. 1995 is amended in efntensis.
   Hvdrovatrs senegalensis Regimbart, 1895 and Uranus baronibicus Bilardo,
   1982 are signalled for the first time of Gabon.
C1 Bilardo, Armando; Via Amicis 29, 21012 Cassano Magnago (VA), Italy,
   Italy.
EM armando@studiobilardo.it
SC Zoology; Environmental Sciences &Ecology
SN 0037-8844
BD Systematics; Nomenclature; New taxa; Description; Ecology; Land zones;
   Afrotropical region; Africa

DT Article
TI Predation on brachyuran (Crustacea, Decapoda): an unique direct evidence
   from the Late Cretaceous (Cenomanian) of Hadjoula (Lebanon).
AU Pasini, Giovanni (juanaldopasini@itscali.it) 
   Garassino, Alessandro
SO Atti della Societa Italiana di Scienze Naturali e del Museo Civico di
   Storia Naturale in Milano
VL 152
IS 2
PS 233-245
PD Fascicolo 2011
PY 2011
LA English
U1 0
U2 0
AB We report for the first time in the fossil record the exceptional direct
   evidence of predation of a catfish shark (Scyliorhinus sp.) on a
   brachyuran crustacean belonging to Paranecrocarcinus cfr. P. milbournei
   Collins, 2010 (Necrocarcinidae Forster, 1968) from the Late Cretaceous
   of Hadjoula, Lebanon. It is the first report of this species out of
   African continent.

   21050 Besano (Varese), Italy, Italy.

DT Article
TI A NEW CAVE-DWELLING HARPACTEA FROM CRETE (ARANEAE, DYSDERIDAE).
FT UNA NUOVA HARPACTEA CAVERNICOLA DI CRETA (ARANEAE, DYSDERIDAE).
AU Gasparo, Fulvio
SO Atti e Memorie della Commissione Grotte "Eugenio Boegan"
VL 43
PS 57-65
PD 2011
PY 2011
LA Italian
U1 0
U2 0
AB Harpactea persephone n. sp. is described on a single female specimen
   collected in the Kournas cave (Spilaio tou Kourna), Chania prefecture,
   Crete. The main diagnostic characters of the new species are: the large
   body size, a strong eye reduction and depigmentation and the very
   abundant leg spination: spines are present on all leg segments, except
   for the anterior coxae and patellae and all the tarsi; an absolutely
   high number of spines (about 10 on each segment) are located on the
   tibiae and metatarsi of the first and second pair of legs. Due to the
   above features, the new species is easily distinguished from all the
   congeners. Harpactea persephone n. sp. belongs to the rubicunda group
   and, according to the vulvar structure, appears to be related to H.
   catholica (Brignoli, 1984), a troglophilic species (often found outside
   caves) endemic for the western part of Crete.
C1 Gasparo, Fulvio; Commissione Grotte "Eugenio Boegan", Societa Alpina
   delle Giulie, C.A.I., Via Donota 2, I-34132 Trieste, Italy, Italy.
SC Zoology
SN 0391-1764
BD Systematics; Nomenclature; New taxa; Land zones; Palaearctic region;
   Eurasia; Europe; Greece
DE Harpactea persephone [Crete /  / New species]. 
TN Arachnids; Arthropods; Chelicerates; Invertebrates
ST Animalia, Arthropoda, Arachnida, Araneae
OR Harpactea persephone (Araneae): [Sp nov, Crete, P. 58]. 
UT ZOOREC:ZOOR14803026106

PT J
AN ZOOR14708057574
DT Article
TI Predation of stocked Brook Char Salvelinus fontinalis by Short-finned
   Eel Anguilla australis and interactions with other salmonids in
   Wollondibby Creek in the high country of south eastern Australia.
AU Llewellyn, L.C. (leighton@activ8.net.au) 
SO Australian Zoologist
VL 35
IS 3
PS 719-746
PD 2011
PY 2011
LA English
U1 0
U2 1
AB This study was initiated to investigate poor survival of stocked Brook
   Char Salvelinus fontinalis in Wollondibby Creek, a tributary of Lake
   Jindabyne in the south eastern highlands of NSW, Australia. Sampling of
   the creek following stocking was carried out on two separate occasions
   by poisoning 17.6 km, almost the entire length of the creek in 19
   sections. Collection of fish was shown to be 78% effective. Five species
   of fish were present in the creek: Salvelinus fontinalis, Salmo trutta,
   Oncorhynchus mykiss, Anguilla australis and Galaxias sp. Population
   density in terms of numbers of fish per hectare and kilograms of fish
   per hectare of all species present was determined. Recovery of stocked
   S. fontinalis was low (0.38% in 1977 and 0.15% in 1979). Distribution of
   salmonid populations in the creek was significantly affected by physical
   barriers and eel predation, not cormorants as first thought. Eel
   predation was confirmed by the presence of salmonids in eel stomachs and
   extensive fin damage as a result of eel attack. Only five S. fontinalis
   in the first sampling event and one in the second sampling event had
   reached angling size (250 mm). It is suggested that stocking of S.
   fontinalis not be carried out in areas where A. australis occurs and
   that careful consideration be given to the location of physical barriers
   in the creek when stocking and the presence of native fish.
C1 Llewellyn, L.C.; Curlew Biol Serv, POB 67, Pacific Palms, NSW,
   Australia, Australia.
EM leighton@activ8.net.au
SC Zoology; Nutrition &Dietetics; Environmental Sciences &Ecology; Marine
   &Freshwater Biology
SN 0067-2238
BD Nutrition; Diet; Prey; Ecology; Population dynamics; Predators;
   Competition; Habitat; Freshwater habitat; Lotic water; Land zones;
   Australasian region; Australasia; Australia
DE Anguilla australis [Piscean prey / Salvelinus fontinalis / Predation
   pressure] [New South Wales / Lake Jindabyne, Wollondibby Creek / ]. 
   Galaxias; Oncorhynchus mykiss; Salmo trutta [Interspecific competition /
   Competitive interactions / ] [Stream / Creek / ] [New South Wales / Lake
   Jindabyne, Wollondibby Creek / ]. 
   Salvelinus fontinalis [Survival /  / predation pressure] [Piscean
   predators / Anguilla australis / ] [Interspecific competition /
   Competitive interactions / ] [Stream / Creek / ] [New South Wales / Lake
   Jindabyne, Wollondibby Creek / ] [ /  / ]. 
TN Chordates; Fish; Vertebrates
ST Animalia, Chordata, Vertebrata, Pisces, Osteichthyes, Actinopterygii,
   Anguilliformes, Anguillidae, Salmoniformes, Galaxiidae, Salmonidae
OR Anguilla australis (Anguillidae): [Predator]. 
   Galaxias (Galaxiidae). 
   Oncorhynchus mykiss (Salmonidae). 
   Salmo trutta (Salmonidae). 
   Salvelinus fontinalis (Salmonidae): [Prey]. 
UT ZOOREC:ZOOR14708057574

TI Contribution to the knowlege [knowledge] of Platyderus Stephens, 1827
   (Coleoptera, Carabidae) from Spain.
AU Anichtchenko, Alexandre (beetl2000@mail.ru) 
SO Baltic Journal of Coleopterology
VL 11
IS 1
PS 33-39
PD 2011
PY 2011
LA English
U1 0
U2 1
AB New species of Platyderus Stephens, 1828 from Spain are described: P.
   lencinai sp.n. (Riopar, Albacete prov.), P. bolivari sp.n. (Cala, Huelva
   prov.), P. gazureki sp.n. (Sierra del Castenar). P. zaballosi sp.n.
   (Montes de Toledo) belonging to the "ruficollis" group is described and
   diagnostic characters for the separation from related taxa are provided.
   New synonymy are proposed: P. marduk Anichtchenko, 2003 syn.n. = P.
   emblema Marseul, 1871.

TI Contributions to the knowledge of Stenus (Nestus) species of the crassus
   group (Insecta: Coleoptera: Staphylinidae: Steninae) 1. Four new species
   from the Russian Far East with taxonomic notes.
AU Ryvkin, Alexandr B.
SO Baltic Journal of Coleopterology
VL 11
IS 1
PS 57-72
PD 2011
PY 2011
LA English
U1 0
U2 1
AB The subgenus Nestus Rey, 1884 of the genus Stenus Latreille, 1797 is
   revalidated. The crassus species group is reestablished. Four new Stenus
   (Nestus) species are described from the Russian Far East: S. (N.)
   finalis sp.n. from Sakhalin, Kuriles, the Khabarovsk Territory, and
   Maritime Province; S. (N.) pardulus sp.n. from the S Maritime Province;
   S. (N.) finitor sp.n. and S. (N.) minus sp.n., both from the NE Amur
   Area. Stenus (N.) subcautus Ryvkin, 2000 is transferred from the cautus
   group to the crassus group and reported from the Amur Area for the first
   time.
C1 Ryvkin, Alexandr B.; Laboratory of Ecology & Morphology of Insects,
   Severtsov Institute of Problems of Ecology & Evolution, Russian Academy
   of Sciences, Leninskiy Prospect, 33, Moscow, 119071, Russia, Russia.

DT Article
TI On the fauna of Tachyporinae (Coleoptera, Staphylinidae) of the Russian
   Far East. I. The genus Tachinus Gravenhorst, 1802.
AU Veselova, Elena (vr_staph@orc.ru) 
SO Baltic Journal of Coleopterology
VL 11
IS 1
PS 73-92
PD 2011
PY 2011
LA English
U1 0
U2 0
AB An annotated list of Tachinus species (Coleoptera, Staphylinidae) with
   new records is given. T. rubricollis Rambousek, 1921 is revalidated; T.
   rishirianus Watanabe et Shibata, 1965 is elevated to species propria. T.
   latissimus Tichomirova, 1973 and T. nigriceps mandschuricus Ullrich,
   1975 are placed in the synonymy of T. rubricollis. The synonymy of T.
   kobensis Cameron, 1933 with T. nigriceps Sharp, 1888 is reestablished.
   The synonymy of T. exiguus Veselova, 1993 with T. kabakovi Veselova,
   1990 is considered to be doubtful. T. atripes J.Sahlberg, 1876 and T.
   setosus Ullrich, 1975 are first recorded for the Far East. T.
   rishirianus is first recorded for the Asian mainland. T. bipustulatus
   (Fabricius, 1793), T. elegans Eppelsheim, 1893 and T. rubricollis are
   first cited for the N Amur basin. T. nigriceps Sharp, 1888 and T.
   atripes J.Sahlberg, 1876 are cited for Russia for the first time.

TI A new species of the genus Zherichiniletus Legalov, 2003 with systematic

   (Coleoptera: Rhychitidae).

AB A new species Zherichiniletus ponomarenkoi Legalov, sp.n. (Indonesia:
   Kalimantan) similar to Zh. ovatus (Philippines) is described. Seven
   synonyms and four systematic placements are newly presented, new

   proposed.
