PT J
AN ZOOR14803026224
DT Article
TI Revision of the Omophron (Phrator) 'vittulatum' species group
   (Coleoptera: Carabidae).
AU Valainis, Uldis (uldis.valainis@biology.lv) 
SO Baltic Journal of Coleopterology
VL 11
IS 2
PS 117-126
PD 2011
PY 2011
LA English
U1 0
U2 0
AB Review of the Omophron (Phrator) 'vittulatum' group led to an increase
   in the number of known species to four [long dash] Omophron (Phrator)
   vittulatum Fairmaire, 1894, Omophron (Phrator) schoutedeni Deleve, 1924,
   Omophron (Phrator) alluaudi Dupuis, 1913 stat. nov., and Omophron
   (Phrator) barsevskisi sp.n. One species was newly described: Omophron
   (Phrator) barsevskisi n. sp. The new species differs from other species
   of this group by a smaller size, rounded shape of elytra, and almost
   smooth elytral striae. Omophron (Phrator) alluaudi Dup. is recognized as
   a valid species. A key to the species is provided. Redescription,
   habitus illustrations, and distribution maps are provided for all
   species.
C1 Valainis, Uldis; Institute of Systematic Biology, Daugavpils University,
   Daugavpils, Latvia, Latvia.
EM uldis.valainis@biology.lv
SC Zoology
SN 1407-8619
BD Systematics; Nomenclature; New taxa; Description; Synonymy; Taxonomy;
   Key; Land zones; Afrotropical region; Africa
DE Omophron (Phrator) barsevskisi [Cameroon /  / New species] [Nigeria /  /
   ]. 
TN Arthropods; Beetles; Insects; Invertebrates
ST Animalia, Arthropoda, Insecta, Coleoptera, Adephaga, Caraboidea,
   Carabidae
OR Omophron (Phrator) alluaudi - Dupuis 1913 (Carabidae): [Redescription,
   P. 119; Removal from synonymy, With Omophron (Phrator) vittulatum
   Fairmaire 1894, p. 119]. 
   Omophron (Phrator) barsevskisi (Carabidae): [Sp nov, Cameroon, P. 120]. 
   Omophron (Phrator) schoutedeni - Deleve 1924 (Carabidae):
   [Redescription, P. 124]. 
   Omophron (Phrator) vittulatum - Fairmaire 1894 (Carabidae):
   [Redescription, P. 124; Removal from synonymy, Omophron (Phrator)
   alluaudi Dupuis 1913, p. 119]. 
   Omophron (Phrator) vittulatum species group (Carabidae): [Revision, P.
   117; Key to species, P. 118]. 
UT ZOOREC:ZOOR14803026224
DA 2020-09-17
ER

PT J
AN ZOOR14803026227
DT Article
TI Two new species of the genus Notiophilus Dumeril, 1806 (Coleoptera:
   Carabidae) from India and Afghanistan.
AU Barsevskis, Arvids (arvids.barsevskis@du.lv) 
SO Baltic Journal of Coleopterology
VL 11
IS 2
PS 127-134
PD 2011
PY 2011
LA English
U1 0
U2 0
AB This article describes two new species of the genus Notiophilus Dumeril,
   1806 (Coleoptera: Carabidae) from the West Himalayas: N. dostali sp.n.
   has been found in India, Himachal Pradesh, Jalaori pass, and N.
   nuristanensis sp.n. has been collected in Afghanistan, i.e. in the
   province of Nuristan. The new species are compared with other species of
   this genus distributed in the West Himalayas and neighbouring
   territories. The key for determination of West Himalayan species is
   presented.
C1 Barsevskis, Arvids; Institute of Systematic Biology, Daugavpils
   University, Vienibas Str 13, Daugavpils, LV-5401, Latvia, Latvia.
EM arvids.barsevskis@du.lv
SC Zoology
SN 1407-8619
BD Systematics; Nomenclature; New taxa; Taxonomy; Key; Land zones; Oriental
   region; Palaearctic region; Eurasia; Asia; India
DE Notiophilus [Asia / West Himalayas / Key to species]. 
   Notiophilus dostali [Himachal Pradesh /  / New species]. 
   Notiophilus nuristanensis [Afghanistan /  / New species]. 
TN Arthropods; Beetles; Insects; Invertebrates
ST Animalia, Arthropoda, Insecta, Coleoptera, Adephaga, Caraboidea,
   Carabidae
OR Notiophilus - Dumeril 1806 (Carabidae): [Key to species, Asia, West
   Himalayas, P. 133]. 
   Notiophilus dostali (Carabidae): [Sp nov, Himachal Pradesh, P. 128]. 
   Notiophilus nuristanensis (Carabidae): [Sp nov, Afghanistan, P. 129].

PT J
AN ZOOR14803026230
DT Article
TI On new and poorly known Lathrobium (s.str.) species from Siberia and the
   Russian Far East (Insecta: Coleoptera: Staphylinidae: Paederinae).
AU Ryvkin, Alexandr B.
SO Baltic Journal of Coleopterology
VL 11
IS 2
PS 135-170
PD 2011
PY 2011
LA English
U1 0
U2 0
AB An annotated list of 16 Lathrobium (s.str.) species is provided,
   including the two new taxa: L. (s.str.) generosum sp.n. from the NE
   Irkutsk Area and L. (s.str.) ishiharai ursinum ssp.n. from the NE Amur
   Area; L. (s.str.) viduum Eppelsheim, 1893 is redescribed, its aedeagus
   and female terminalia are illustrated for the first time; L. (s. str.)
   japonicum kunashiriense Y. Watanabe, 2004 is placed in the synonymy of
   L. (s. str.) japonicum Bernhauer, 1907. New faunistic data on Siberian
   and Far Eastern localities are given for all the species listed. Some
   short additional data are provided also for other territories of the
   former USSR.
C1 Ryvkin, Alexandr B.; Laboratory of Ecology & Morphology of Insects,
   Severtsov Institute of Problems of Ecology & Evolution, Russian Academy
   of Sciences, Leninskiy Prospect 33, Moscow 119072, Russia, Russia.
SC Zoology
SN 1407-8619
BD Systematics; Nomenclature; New taxa; Description; Synonymy; Land zones;
   Palaearctic region; Eurasia
DE Lathrobium (Lathrobium) [Russia / Russian Far East & Siberia /
   Distribution; annotated systematic list]. 
   Lathrobium (Lathrobium) generosum [Russia /  / New species]. 
   Lathrobium (Lathrobium) ishiharai ursinum [Russia /  / New subspecies]. 
TN Arthropods; Beetles; Insects; Invertebrates
ST Animalia, Arthropoda, Insecta, Coleoptera, Polyphaga, Staphylinoidea,
   Staphylinidae
OR Lathrobium (Lathrobium) - Gravenhorst 1802 (Staphylinidae). 
   Lathrobium (Lathrobium) generosum (Staphylinidae): [Sp nov, Russia, P.
   150]. 
   Lathrobium (Lathrobium) ishiharai ursinum (Staphylinidae): [Subsp nov,
   Russia, P. 155]. 
   Lathrobium (Lathrobium) japonicum - Bernhauer 1907 (Staphylinidae): [Syn
   nov, Lathrobium (Lathrobium) japonicum kunashiriense Watanabe 2004, p.
   157]. 
   Lathrobium (Lathrobium) viduum - Eppelsheim 1893 (Staphylinidae):
   [Redescription, P. 162; First time figured, Aedeagus & female
   terminalia, p. 154].

DT Article
TI A new genus and species Lorestania gracilis gen. n., sp. n. from Iran
   (Coleoptera: Carabidae: Lebiini).
AU Anichtchenko, Alexander (beetl2000@mail.ru) 
SO Baltic Journal of Coleopterology
VL 11
IS 2
PS 197-201
PD 2011
PY 2011
LA English
U1 0
U2 0
AB A new genus and species, Lorestania gracilis gen. n., sp. n. (type
   locality: Lorestan prov., Iran), is described and illustrated. The new
   genus is placed in the subtribe Lionychina Jeannel, 1948, according to
   the structure of the elytral epipleura, of the labium and of the
   stylomeres.

   Biology, Vienibas iela 13-229, Daugavpils LV-5400, Latvia, Latvia.

   Lorestania gracilis, p. 198]. 
   Lorestania gracilis (Carabidae): [Sp nov, Iran, P. 198].

PT J
AN ZOOR14707051266
DT Article
TI Medusoid cnidarians from the Montral-Alcover Lagerstaetten (Triassic),
   northeastern Spain.
AU Romero, Aldemaro (aromero@siue.edu) 
   Rogers, Raymond R.
   Gershwin, Lisa A.
SO Batalleria
VL 16
PS 50-57
PD gener 2011
PY 2011
LA English
U1 0
U2 0
AB We present a number of specimens of medusoid cnidarians, all of which
   are the first ever described from the Spanish Ladinian. Tarracodiskus
   vial, T. villaltui, and Heliobranchiu catulaunlea are described as new
   genera and species. These specimens present a number of systematic
   challenges due to our lack of knowledge with regard to their life cycle,
   soft anatomy, phenotypic plasticity, convergent characters, and paucity
   in the fossil record. Their mode of preservation is consistent with that
   of other fauna from the Montral-Alcover locality.
C1 Romero, Aldemaro; College of Arts and Sciences, Southern Illinois
   University Edwardsville, Peck Hall 3409, Edwardsville, IL 62026-1608,
   USA, USA.
EM aromero@siue.edu
RI Gershwin, Lisa-ann/N-6392-2015
OI Gershwin, Lisa-ann/0000-0003-1254-725X
SC Zoology; Anatomy &Morphology; Developmental Biology; Genetics &Heredity;
   Evolutionary Biology; Environmental Sciences &Ecology; Paleontology
SN 0214-7831
BD Systematics; Nomenclature; New taxa; General morphology; Life cycle and
   development; Genetics; Evolution; Ecology; Fossilization; Land zones;
   Palaearctic region; Eurasia; Europe; Geological time periods; Mesozoic

   medusae] [Life cycle /  / ] [Phenotype / Phenotypic plasticity / ]
   [Variation /  / ] [Taphonomy /  / ] [Spain /  / ] [Triassic /  / ]. 
   Heliobranchia; Tarracodiscus [Triassic /  / New genus]. 
   Heliobranchia catalaunica; Tarracodiscus viai; Tarracodiscus vllaltai
   [Spain /  / new species] [Triassic /  / ]. 
   Heliobranchiidae [Triassic /  / New family]. 
TN Coelenterates; Invertebrates
ST Animalia, Cnidaria, Hydrozoa, Hydroida, Scyphozoa, Scyphomedusae
OR Cnidaria (Animalia): [Fossil; New record]. 
   Tarracodiscus (Hydroida): [Gen nov, Of family Aequoreidae, Type species
   Tarracodiscus viai, p. 52, Triassic; Fossil]. 
   Tarracodiscus viai (Hydroida): [Sp nov, Spain, Triassic, P. 52; Fossil].
   
   Tarracodiscus vllaltai (Hydroida): [Sp nov, Spain, Triassic, P. 53;
   Fossil]. 
   Heliobranchia (Scyphomedusae): [Gen nov, Of new family Heliobranchiidae,
   Type species Heliobranchia catalaunica, p. 54, Triassic; Fossil]. 
   Heliobranchia catalaunica (Scyphomedusae): [Sp nov, Spain, Triassic, P.
   54; Fossil].

TI Checklist of the Lucanidae (Insecta: Coleoptera) from the
   Indo-Australian transition zone.

   Cianferoni, Fabio

   Guinea. Volume I.
PS 43-58

LA English
U1 0

AB A checklist of the known species of Coleoptera Lucanidae from New Guinea
   and its surrounding islands (Solomon Archipelago, Moluccan Archipelago,
   Raja AmpatArchipelago, Bismarck Archipelago, Louisiade Archipelago, and
   D'Entrecasteaux Archipelago) is provided. The subspecies Dorcus meeki
   delis/el Nagai et Tsukawaki, 1999 and Dorcus meeki jasmini Nagai et
   Tsukawaki, 1999 are considered as synonyms of D. meeki Boileau, 1906
   (new synonymy).

TI Xantholinini of the Australian region (Coleoptera: Staphylinidae), V.
   New species collected by Alexander Riedel in Arfak and Cyclops Mts., New
   Guinea.
AU Bordoni, Arnaldo (arnaldo.bordoni@libero.it) 
ED Telnov, Dmitry
SO Biodiversity, biogeography and nature conservation in Wallacea and New
   Guinea. Volume I.
PS 59-64
PD 2011
PY 2011
LA English
U1 0
U2 0
AB Seven new species of Xantholinini (Eachamia sentanica sp. nov., E.
   cyclopica sp. nov., E. riedeli sp. nov., Mitomorphus arfakensis sp.
   nov., M. cyclopicus sp. nov., M. riedelianus sp. nov., M. doyo sp. nov.)
   are described from the Arfak and Cyclops mountains, Indonesian Papua
   (former Irian Jaya). To date, 147 species of Xantholinini have been
   recorded from the island of New Guinea, an indication of the high level
   of biodiversity in a region in which few collections of members of this
   tribe have as yet been made.

DT Book chapter
TI Species of Ditropopsis E.A. Smith, 1897 (Architaenioglossa:
   Cyclophoridae) from the Papuan region.
AU Greke, Kristine (k.greke@gmail.com) 
ED Telnov, Dmitry
SO Biodiversity, biogeography and nature conservation in Wallacea and New
   Guinea. Volume I.
PS 69-76
PD 2011
PY 2011
LA English
U1 0
U2 0
AB Representatives of the gastropod genus Ditropopsis E.A.Smith, 1897
   (Architaenioglossa: Cyclophoridae) from New Guinea, Raja Ampat and
   Moluccan Archipelago are revised. In total, 11 species are confirmed for
   the study region. The type species for the genus Ditropopsis E.A.Smith,
   1897 is here designated. The following new synonymy is proposed:
   Ditropopsis E.A.Smith, 1897 = Diaspira Sobs, 1911 syn. nov. Lectotypes
   are designated for two species - Ditropopsis fultoni E.A.Smith, 1897 and
   D. papuana E.A.Smith, 1897. Three species new to science were described
   and illustrated, namely Ditropopsis benthemjuttingi sp. nov., D.
   mirabilis sp. nov., and D. tritonensis sp. nov. New faunal information
   on previously known species is presented. A new key to Ditropopsis from
   the Papuan biogeographical region and an annotated species list are
   presented for the first time.
C1 Greke, Kristine; Stopinu novads, Darza iela 10, LV-2130, Dzidrinas,
   Latvia, Latvia.
EM k.greke@gmail.com
PU The Entomological Society of Latvia
PA Riga
SC Zoology
BN 978-9984-9768-4-6

   zones; Oriental region; Eurasia; Asia

   Papuan region / Key to species] [ /  / Distribution]. 
   Ditropopsis benthemjuttingi; Ditropopsis mirabilis; Ditropopsis
   tritonensis [Indonesia /  / New species]. 
TN Invertebrates; Molluscs
ST Animalia, Mollusca, Gastropoda, Prosobranchia, Mesogastropoda,
   Cyclophoroidea

   Ditropopsis papuana Smith 1897, p. 70; Syn nov, Diaspira Soos 1911, p.
   70; Key to species, Indonesia, Papuan region, P. 73]. 
   Ditropopsis benthemjuttingi (Cyclophoroidea): [Sp nov, Indonesia, P.
   70]. 
   Ditropopsis fultoni - Smith 1897 (Cyclophoroidea): [Lectotype
   designated, P. 71; Redescription, P. 71]. 
   Ditropopsis mirabilis (Cyclophoroidea): [Sp nov, Indonesia, P. 71].

AB Endelus (s. str.) barclayi sp. nov., E. (s. str.) splendens sp. nov.,
   and E. (s. str.) nairaarum sp. nov. all from Sulawesi (Indonesia) are
   described and figured. The new species belong to the E. marseulii
   Deyrolle, 1864 species-group, established in this paper. A key to
   species of this group is provided including E. scintillans Deyrolle,
   1864 and E. lunatus Fisher, 1921.

TI New species of Alticinae (Coleoptera: Chrysomelidae) from insular
   systems of SE Asia.
AU Medvedev, Lev N. (lev.n.medvedev@mail.ru) 
ED Telnov, Dmitry

   Guinea. Volume I.

AB Ten new species of Alticinae are described from islands in South East
   Asia, mainly from Sulawesi: Luperomorpha sulawesianus (Sulawesi), L.
   schawalleri (Borneo), Chabria riedeli (Sulawesi), Ch. luzonica (Luzon),
   Paratonfania nigricollis, Argopistes bosi, Chilocoristes bipunctatus
   (all three - Sulawesi), Ch. sabahensis, Ch. obscurus (both - Borneo),
   and Ch. laysi (Mindanao). A key to genus Chilocoristes Weise, 1895 from
   these islands is given.

PT B
AN ZOOR14805037190
DT Book chapter
TI [Taxonomic revision of the genus Macratria Newman, 1838 (Coleoptera:
   Anthicidae: Macratriinae) from Wallacea, New Guinea and the Solomon
   Islands.]
FT Taxonomische Revision der Gattung Macratria Newman, 1838 (Coleoptera:
   Anthicidae: Macratriinae) aus Wallacea, neuguinea und den Salomonen.
AU Telnov, Dmitry (anthicus@gmail.com) 
ED Telnov, Dmitry
SO Biodiversity, biogeography and nature conservation in Wallacea and New
   Guinea. Volume I.
PS 97-286
PD 2011
PY 2011
NT Separate unpaginated plates.
LA German
U1 0
U2 0
AB Representatives of cosmopolitan genus Macratria Newman, 1838
   (Coleoptera: Anthicidae: Macratriinae) from the classic Wallacea
   (excluding the Philippines), New Guinea and the Solomon Islands were
   taxonomically revided. In total, 108 species and subspecies confirmed
   for the study region. Eight species-groups for Macratria were
   established, namely M. apicata-, beccarii-, celebensis-, forticornis-,
   gestroi-, kovalevskyi-, obliquesetosa-, and pygmaea-Group. Four new
   synonyms were proposed, namely Macratria beccarii Pic, 1900 = var.
   submetallica Pic, 1900 syn. nov., M. coniceps Pic, 1900 = giloloana
   Champion, 1916 syn. nov., M. forticornis Pic, 1896b = grandis Pic, 1896b
   syn. nov., M. subguttata Pascoe, 1860 = testaceicornis ternatensis Pic,
   1901 syn. nov. New status for one subspecific taxon is proposed: M.
   densata Pic, 1900 stat. nov. Lectotypes were designated for 15 taxa,
   namely M. albertisi Pic, 1900, M. beccarii Pic, 1900, M. beccarii var.
   submetallica Pic, 1900, M. coniceps Pic, 1900, M. densata Pic, 1900, M.
   gestroi Pic, 1900, M. Ioriae Pic, 1900, M. maculata Pic, 1896b, M.
   maculipennis Pic, 1900, M. neoguineensis Pic, 1900, M. obscuripes Pic,
   1912, M. opacicollis Pic, 1900, M. rubriceps Pic, 1900, M.
   testaceicornis Pic, 1901, and M. testaceicornis ternatensis Pic, 1901.
   Eighty four species and subspecies were described and illustrated as new
   to science, namely M. abscondita sp. nov., M. administrator sp. nov., M.
   apicata sp. nov., M. aquila sp. nov., M. areare sp. nov., M. baliemensis
   sp. nov., M. balkei sp. nov., M. bicoloritarsis sp. nov., M.
   caerulescens sp. nov., M. capreolus sp. nov., M. confertopunctata sp.
   nov., M. cracens sp. nov., M. curtinotum sp. nov., M. curvamina sp.
   nov., M. dani sp. nov., M. debellatrix sp. nov., M. dumogaensis sp.
   nov., M. elegans sp. nov., M. elongatissima sp. nov., M. emacerata sp.
   nov., M. finisterrensis sp. nov., M. flaveosetosa sp. nov., M. fore sp.
   nov., M. fulvissima sp. nov., M. furva sp. nov., M. fuscocyanea sp.
   nov., M. gladia sp. nov., M. grekei sp. nov., M. grisescens sp. nov., M.
   hatamensis sp. nov., M. imitans sp. nov., M. impressithorax sp. nov., M.
   iridescens sp. nov., M. jayawijaya sp. nov., M. ketengban sp. nov., M.
   kokodaensis sp. nov., M. kovalevskyi sp. nov., M. laszlowagneri sp.
   nov., M. Iongesetosa sp. nov., M. lydekkeri sp. nov., M. magna sp. nov.,
   M. matrozisi sp. nov., M. maxbarclayi sp. nov., M. megalops sp. nov., M.
   misoolensis sp. nov., M. moluccensis sp. nov., M. momina sp. nov., M.
   monstrosicornis sp. nov., M. monstrosifemorata sp. nov., M. monticola
   sp. nov., M. montivaga sp. nov., M. mordelloides sp. nov., M. morobensis
   sp. nov., M. multisignis sp. nov., M. nguzunguzu sp. nov., M. nigricula
   sp. nov., M. nigrita sp. nov., M. nigrolateralis sp. nov., M.
   nigromaculata sp. nov., M. obliquesetosa sp. nov., M. oblonga sp. nov.,
   M. obtusicapita sp. nov., M. pamelaschmidti sp. nov., M. parangana sp.
   nov., M. phallocryptus sp. nov., M. platycephala sp. nov., M. pumicosa
   sp. nov., M. pygmaea halmaherica ssp. nov., M. riedeli sp. nov., M.
   ronaldi sp. nov., M. rotundiceps sp. nov., M. rufula sp. nov., M.
   sanguiceps sp. nov., M. sepik sp. nov., M. spungisi sp. nov., M.
   sulaensis sp. nov., M. trifaria sp. nov., M. unaensis sp. nov., M.
   vandeveldei sp. nov., M. vaturanga sp. nov., M. viking sp. nov., M.
   wahgi sp. nov., M. weberi sp. nov., and M. yapena sp. nov. An
   identification key to Macratria species of the study area and an
   annotated species list are presented for the first time. Biogeographical
   distribution aspects of Macratria in the study region were discussed.
   Ecological and biological information on the study group are given.
C1 Telnov, Dmitry; Stopinu novads, Darza iela 10, LV-2130, Dzidrinas,
   Lettland, Latvia, Latvia.
EM anthicus@gmail.com
PU The Entomological Society of Latvia
PA Riga
SC Zoology; Environmental Sciences &Ecology
BN 978-9984-9768-4-6
BD Systematics; Nomenclature; New taxa; Type material; Synonymy; Taxonomy;
   Status; Key; Documentation; Publications; Ecology; Community structure;
   Zoogeography; Land zones; Australasian region; Oriental region; Eurasia;
   Asia; Australasia; Oceanic islands; Pacific Ocean islands

DT Book chapter
TI New Gilletinus Boucomont, 1932 (Coleoptera: Geotrupidae: Bolboceratinae)
   from Misool, with the key to known species.
AU Telnov, Dmitry (anthicus@gmail.com) 
ED Telnov, Dmitry
SO Biodiversity, biogeography and nature conservation in Wallacea and New
   Guinea. Volume I.
PS 287-290
PD 2011
PY 2011
NT Separate unpaginated plates.
LA English
U1 0
U2 1
AB A new species of genus Gilletinus from Misool Island, East Indonesia, is
   described. An annotated species list of the genus Gilletinus is
   presented. An updated identification key to Gilletinus species is
   provided.

DT Book chapter
TI Notes on the genus Acaloloepta Pascoe, 1858 (Coleoptera: Cerambycidae)
   from Indonesian Papua and the Moluccas.
AU Vitali, Francesco (vitalfranz@yahoo.de) 
ED Telnov, Dmitry
SO Biodiversity, biogeography and nature conservation in Wallacea and New
   Guinea. Volume I.
PS 291-297
PD 2011
PY 2011
NT Separate unpaginated plates.
LA English
U1 0
U2 0
AB Taxonomic remarks and faunistic data concerning some Acalolepta-species
   collected in different surveys in the Moluccas (Halmahera, Seram,
   Saparua) and Indonesian Papua are provided. The following species are
   recorded for the first time from the following islands: Acalolepta
   fasciata (Montrouzier, 1855) and Acalolepta tincturata (Pascoe, 1866)
   from Misool, Acalolepta producta (Pascoe, 1866) from Seram and Saparua,
   and Acalolepta cf. ternatensis (Breuning, 1936) from Halmahera. Dihammus
   fasciatus aurivarius Gressitt, 1952 is removed from the synonymy with A.
   acanthias and considered as a younger synonym of M. captiosus Pascoe,
   1866 syn. nov. Monochamus uraeus Pascoe, 1866 is removed from the
   synonymy with A. antenor (Newman, 1842) and considered as asynonym of
   Monochamus captiosus syn. nov.
C1 Vitali, Francesco; 7a rue Jean-Pierre Huberty, L-1742, Luxembourg,
   Luxembourg.
EM vitalfranz@yahoo.de
PU The Entomological Society of Latvia
PA Riga
SC Zoology
BN 978-9984-9768-4-6
BD Systematics; Nomenclature; Synonymy; Taxonomy; Key; Land zones; Oriental
   region; Eurasia; Asia

   / Biology; distribution; faunal list; new record; systematics]. 
   Acalolepta cf. ternatensis [Indonesia / Moluccas, Halmahera / New
   record]. 
   Acalolepta fasciata; Acalolepta tincturata [Indonesia / Irian Jaya,
   Misool Archipelago / New record]. 
   Acalolepta producta [Indonesia / Moluccas, Seram & Saparua / New
   record].

   Cerambycidae

   Moluccas, P. 295; New record]. 
   Acalolepta acanthias - (Pascoe 1875) (Cerambycidae): [Removal from
   synonymy, Dihammus fasciatus aurivarius Gressitt 1952, p. 293]. 
   Acalolepta antenor - (Newman 1842) (Cerambycidae): [Removal from
   synonymy, Monochamus uraeus Pascoe 1866, p. 293]. 
   Acalolepta cf. ternatensis (Cerambycidae): [New record]. 
   Acalolepta fasciata (Cerambycidae): [New record]. 
   Acalolepta producta (Cerambycidae): [New record]. 
   Acalolepta tincturata (Cerambycidae): [New record]. 
   Dihammus fasciatus aurivarius - Gressitt 1952 (Cerambycidae): [Removal
   from synonymy, With Acalolepta acanthias (Pascoe 1875), p. 293]. 
   Monochamus capitosus - Pascoe 1866 (Cerambycidae): [Syn nov, Dihammus
   fasciatus aurivarius Gressitt 1952, p. 292; Syn nov, Monochamus uraeus
   Pascoe 1866, p. 292]. 
   Monochamus uraeus - Pascoe 1866 (Cerambycidae): [Removal from synonymy,
   With Acalolepta antenor (Newman 1842), p. 293].

PT B
AN ZOOR14805037193
DT Book chapter
TI The Spilosoma group of species from New Guinea and adjacent islands
   (Lepidoptera: Erebidae: Arctiinae: Arctiini).
AU de Vos, Rob (rob.devos@ncbnaturalis.nl) 
   Suhartawan, Daawia
ED Telnov, Dmitry
SO Biodiversity, biogeography and nature conservation in Wallacea and New
   Guinea. Volume I.
PS 299-334
PD 2011
PY 2011
NT Separate unpaginated plates.
LA English
U1 0
U2 0
AB Species in the genus Spilosoma Curtis, 1825 from New Guinea and adjacent
   islands are revised. Species groups are recognized primarily according
   to similarities in genitalia structures and secondarily to other
   external characters. The genus Spilosoma is in New Guinea and adjacent
   islands represented by 27 species of which 10 are new to science:
   Spilosoma adriani sp. nov., S. cinnamomea sp. nov., S. enarotali sp.
   nov., S. grandimacula sp. nov., S. mastrigti sp. nov., S. nana sp. nov.,
   S. postbrunnea sp. nov., S. transversa sp. nov., S. vulgaris sp. nov.,
   S. wernerthomasi sp. nov. Diacrisia eichhorni Rothschild, 1917 proved to
   be conspecific with Diacrisia pratti Bethune-Baker, 1904 and is
   downgraded to subspecies level. In the closely related Spilaethalida
   Dubatolov et al., 2007 the taxa Diacrisia sordidior Rothschild, 1910,
   Diacrisia montana Rothschild, 1910, Diacrisia alpina Rothschild, 1914
   and Diacrisia woodlarkiana Rothschild, 1910 are synonymized with the
   nomotypical subspecies of Diacrisia turbida Butler, 1882. All species
   are described or redescribed and imagines and male and female genitalia
   are figured.
C1 de Vos, Rob; Nietherlands Centre for Biodiversity (CB Naturalis),
   section ZMAN, Department of Entomology, Darwinweg 2, NL-2333 Cr Leiden,
   Netherlands, Netherlands.
EM rob.devos@ncbnaturalis.nl
PU The Entomological Society of Latvia
PA Riga
SC Zoology
BN 978-9984-9768-4-6
BD Systematics; Nomenclature; New taxa; Type material; Synonymy; Taxonomy;
   Status; Key; Documentation; Publications; Land zones; Australasian
   region; Oriental region; Eurasia; Asia; Australasia

   [Papua New Guinea /  / ] [ /  / ].

   [Papua New Guinea /  / ] [ /  / ].

   ].

   Biology; distribution; systematics; checklist] [Papua New Guinea /  / ].

   Spilosoma pratti eichhorni, p. 308]. 
   Spilosoma enarotali (Arctiidae): [Sp nov, Indonesia, P. 321]. 
   Spilosoma fraterna - (Rothschild 1910) (Arctiidae): [Description, P.

AN ZOOR14805037194
DT Book chapter
TI [Systematics, taxonomy and faunistics of the Apomecynini of the Oriental
   and Australian Region (Coleoptera: Cerambycidae: Lamiinae). Revision of
   the genus Sybra Pascoe, 1865 and comments on other genera, part 2.]
FT Systematik, Taxonomie und Faunistik der Apomecynini der orentalischen
   und australischen Region (Coleoptera: Cerambycidae: Lamiinae). Revision
   der Gattung Sybra Pascoe, 1865 und Anmerkungen zu weiteren Gattungen,
   Teil 2.
AU Weigel, Andreas (rosalia@versanet.de) 
   Skale, Andre
ED Telnov, Dmitry
SO Biodiversity, biogeography and nature conservation in Wallacea and New
   Guinea. Volume I.
PS 335-350
PD 2011
PY 2011
NT Separate unpaginated plates.
LA German
U1 0
U2 0
AB This paper deals with taxonomical changes and faunistical data for 72
   taxa within the genus complex of Sybra Pascoe, 1865 and further taxa of
   Apomecynini. 17 valid species are pictured. The following synonymies are
   proposed: Ichthyodes freyi Breuning, 1957 syn. nov. to Elaidius
   biplagiatus Breuning, 1945, Ichthyodes biguttulus ssp. dinagatensis
   Breuning, 1965 syn. nov. and Ichthyodes ochreoguttatus Breuning, 1942
   syn. nov. to Ichthyodes biguttulus Newman, 1842, Mimosybra postlineata
   Hudepohl, 1995 syn. nov. and Atelais (?) surigaonis Heller, 1924 syn.
   nov. (objective) to Mimosybra surigaonis (Heller, 1923), Falsepilysta
   rosselli Breuning, 1982 syn. nov. to Orinoeme rosselli (Breuning, 1970),
   Falsoropica javaensis Breuning, 1982 syn. nov. to Sybra alternans
   (Wiedemann, 1823), Falsoropica albopunctata Breuning et Villiers, 1983
   syn. nov. to Sybra densealbomarmorata Breuning, 1966, Sybra egumensis
   Breuning, 1973 syn. nov. to Sybra fuscoapicalis Breuning, 1939, Sybra
   patrua Pascoe, 1865 syn. nov. and Sybra irrorata Pascoe, 1865 syn. nov.
   to Sybra inanis Pascoe, 1865, Sybra ochraceicollis Breuning, 1940 syn.
   nov. to Sybra leucostictica Breuning, 1939, Sybra assimilis Breuning,
   1939 syn. nov. to Sybra maculicollis Aurivillius, 1927, Sybra sumbawana
   Breuning, 1959 syn. nov. to Sybra patruoides Breuning, 1939, Sybra
   obliquevittata Breuning, 1939 syn. nov., Sybra proximatoides Breuning,
   1966 syn. nov. and Sybra submodesta Breuning, 1970 syn. nov. to Sybra
   porcellus Pascoe, 1865, Sybra keyensis Breuning, 1939 syn. nov. to Sybra
   primaria Pascoe, 1865, Sybra decemmaculata Breuning, 1965 syn. nov. to
   Sybra strigina Pascoe, 1865. The following taxa are considered as valid
   species: Orinoeme chalybeata Pascoe, 1867 stat. rev. as a synonym to
   Orinoeme punctata (Montrouzier, 1855), Sybra destituta Pascoe, 1865
   stat. rev. former as morphe to Sybra luteicornis Pascoe, 1865, Sybra
   latiuscula Aurivillius, 1927 stat. rev. as a synonym to Sybra alternans
   (Wiedemann, 1823), Sybra strigina Pascoe, 1865 stat. rev. former as
   morphe to Sybra patrua Pascoe. The following new combinations are
   proposed: Mimectatina fuscoapicata (Breuning, 1964) comb. nov. and
   Mynonoma integricollis (Breuning, 1942) comb. nov. from the genus Sybra
   Pascoe, 1865. Both genera until now under Ichthyodes Newman, 1842 as
   synonym Hestima Pascoe, 1867 stat. rev. or subgenus Orinoeme Pascoe,
   1867 stat. rev. are considered as valid genera. Features for the
   differentiation and provisional lists for the according three genera are
   given. Lectotypes are designated for the following four taxa: Sybra
   biguttata Aurivillius, 1927, Sybra fuscovittata Aurivillius, 1927, Sybra
   latiuscula Aurivillius, 1927, Sybra sibuyana Aurivillius, 1927.
C1 Weigel, Andreas; Am Schlossgarten 6, D-07381 Werburg, Germany, Germany.
EM rosalia@versanet.de
PU The Entomological Society of Latvia
PA Riga
SC Zoology
BN 978-9984-9768-4-6

   [Oriental region /  / ].

   (Saltatoria): [Syn nov, Stenobothrus bulgaricus Ramme 1933, p. 195].

DT Article; Meeting paper
TI Excavating sponges boring into the precious red coral from the Cape
   Verde archipelago.
FT Spugne perforanti lo sclerasse del corallo ross dall'Arcipelago di Capo
   Verde.
AU Pica, D.
   Calcinai, B. (b.calcinai@univpm.it) 
   Bertolino, M.
SO Biologia Marina Mediterranea
VL 18
IS 1
PS 278-279
PD 2011
PY 2011
LA Italian
U1 0
U2 0
AB Four species of sponges boring into Corallium rubrum were identified in
   colonies collec in Cape Verde. Two species are probably new, and in
   particular Alectona sp. 1 is strongly related A. triradiata described
   for the Indo-Pacific area and also excavating into Corallium scleraxis.
   disjunt distribution of the new species of Alectona respect to the
   congeneric and highly similar sp. A. triradiata excavating the same
   substratum (Corallium spp.) strongly suggests a Tethyan re distribution
   of this excavating genus strongly connected to the disjunt and relict
   distribution of the g Corallium. The evidence of circular and radial
   signs of erosion on pits surface produce by Th. armata similar to the
   ones described for Alectona spp. together with other similar and shared
   charac support the inclusion of the genera Thoosa and Alectona in the
   family Thoosidae.

   (Di.S.V.A.), University Politecnica delle Marche, Via Brecce Bianche,

DT Article
TI A new genus and two new species of marine free-living nematodes from
   coastal waters of southern Vietnam.
AU Thanh, Nguyen Vu (nvthanh49@yahoo.com) 
   Gagarin, V.G.
SO Biologiya Morya (Vladivostok)
VL 37
IS 5
PS 357-361
PD Sentyabr-Oktyabr 2011
PY 2011
NT Serial normally translated cover to cover in: Russian Journal of Marine
   Biology.
LA Russian
U1 0
U2 0
AB A new genus and two new species of free-living marine nematodes from
   sediments in the coastal zone of the South China Sea (Vietnam) are
   described. Cyartonemoides gen. n. morphologically resembles Cyartonema
   Cobb, 1920, but differs from it in having a well-developed cephalic
   capsule. Cyartonemoides foetidus gen. n., sp. n. is the type and the
   only species of the genus. Campylaimus abnormis sp. n. differs from all
   species of the genus Campylaimus Cobb, 1920 by the shape of the
   amphidial fovea and shorter lateral fields.

   Giay, Hanoi, 10 000, Vietnam, Vietnam.

TI New data on the species of the genus Pista (Polychaeta: Terebellidae)
   from the Russian Far-eastern seas.
AU Leontovich, M.K. (axionice@mail.ru) 
   Zhirkov, I.A.
SO Biologiya Morya (Vladivostok)
VL 37
IS 5
PS 391-395
PD Sentyabr-Oktyabr 2011
PY 2011
NT Serial normally translated cover to cover in: Russian Journal of Marine
   Biology.
LA Russian
U1 0
U2 1
AB Two species of the genus Pista (Polychaeta: Terebellidae) [long dash] P.
   brevibranchiata Moore, 1923 and P. incarrientis Annenkova, 1925 [long
   dash] are redescribed based on materials from the Russian Far-eastern
   seas. The former species was not previously recorded in this region.
   Pista shizugawaensis Nishi et Tanaka, 2006 is regarded as a junior
   synonym of P. brevibranchiata Moore, 1923. Because of the vague original
   description of Pista zachsi Annenkova, 1925 and the loss of its type
   material, this species should be considered as incertae sedis.

   University, Moscow, 119991, Russia, Russia.

TI Two species of free-living nematodes from Lake Baikal.
AU Gagarin, V.G. (gagarin@ibiw.yaroslavl.ru) 
   Naumova, T.V.
SO Biologiya Vnutrennikh Vod
VL 3
PS 5-10
PD Iyul-Avgust-Sentyabr 2011
PY 2011
LA Russian
U1 1
U2 3
AB Illustrated descriptions of two species of free-living nematodes:
   Tobrilus securus sp. n. and Paramphidelus paludicola Gagarin, 1991 found
   in Lake Baikal. T. securus sp.n. resembles the endemic of Lake Baikal,
   T. bekmanae Tsalolichin, 1975, but differs from it by longer tail,
   shorter outer labial setae, shorter stoma and another structure of
   spicules. Paramphidelus paludicola, is described by three females from
   Lake Taimyr, discovered in Lake Baikal. It is the second finding this of
   species and the first description of a male.

PT J
AN ZOOR14803025952
DT Article
TI Two new species of dorylaimids (Nematoda, Dorylaimida) from Lake Baikal.
AU Gagarin, V.G. (gagarin@ibiw.yaroslavl.ru) 
   Naumova, T.V.
SO Biologiya Vnutrennikh Vod
VL 1
PS 34-39
PD Yanvar-Fevral-Mart 2011
PY 2011
LA Russian
U1 0
U2 2
AB Illustrated descriptions of two new for the science species of
   free-living nematodes Arctidorylaimus parvulus and Eudorylaimus sedatus,
   found in littoral zone of Lake Baikal are given. A. parvulus sp. n.
   differs from A. kurenkovi Gagarin, 2002 and is characterized by a
   shorter body, absence of longitudinal cuticular ridges, shorter
   spicules, a smaller number of precloacal supplements and a relatively
   shorter prerectum. E. sedatus sp. n. is morphologically similar to E.
   spongiophilus Batalova, 1983, but is smaller, has shorter odontostyle
   and odontophore, longer tail and prerectum. A key is given to determine
   valid species of the genus Arctidorylaimus.
C1 Gagarin, V.G.; Institute for Biology of Inland Waters RAS, 152742 Borok,
   Russia, Russia.
EM gagarin@ibiw.yaroslavl.ru
RI Gagarin, Vladimir Grigorievich/A-8438-2017

   Palaearctic region; Eurasia

   species]. 
TN Invertebrates; Nematodes
ST Animalia, Nematoda
OR Arctidorylaimus (Nematoda): [Key to species, P. 36]. 
   Arctidorylaimus parvulus (Nematoda): [Sp nov, Russia, P. 34].

   temperature, humidity and rainfall on the incidence of infection of the
   cestode parasite, Lytocestus parasitising the air breathing freshwater

AN ZOOR14808055358
DT Article
TI [Apistogramma megaptera (Perciformes: Cichlidae), a new species for the
   Orinoco Basin.]
FT Apistogramma megaptera (Perciformes: Cichlidae), una nueva especie para
   la cuenca del Orinoco.
AU Salazar, Lina M. Mesa (lmesasalazar@gmail.com) 
   Lasso, Carlos A.
SO Biota Colombiana
VL 12
IS 1
PS 19-30
PD enero-junio 2011
PY 2011
LA Spanish
U1 0
U2 1
AB We describe a new species, Apistogramma megaptera (Perciformes:
   Cichlidae) that occurs in the upper Orinoco River Basin, in the Inrida,
   Atabapo and Mavaca rivers of Venezuela and Colombia. This species is
   characterized by a deep body and a sexual dimorphism expressed in the
   different shape of the dorsal and caudal fins of males and females, as
   well as color pattern. Other diagnostic features that differentiate it
   from other species from Orinoco with crossbars on the caudal fin
   (Apistogramma iniridae, A. velifera and A. inornata) are: anal fin with
   marginal black stripe; dorsal fin with a thin marginal black line;
   infraorbital band wide, its width equal to the pupil; these characters
   are not present in the above mentioned species. The males reach a larger
   size (58.7 mm LS) than females (39 mm LS). The pigmentation in the form
   of crossbars on the tail fin is the character that distinguishes it from
   other species in the Orinoco River Basin that have immaculate caudal fin
   (Apistogramma alacrina, A. hoignei, A. hongsloi, A. guttata, A.
   macmasteri and A. viejita).
C1 Salazar, Lina M. Mesa; Fundacion para el Desarrollo de las Ciencias
   Fisicas, Matematicas y Naturales (FUDECI) Academia de Ciencias Fisicas,
   Matematicas y Naturales, Palacio de las Academias, Caracas, Venezuela,
   Venezuela.
EM lmesasalazar@gmail.com
SC Zoology
SN 0124-5376
BD Systematics; Nomenclature; New taxa; Taxonomy; Key; Land zones;
   Neotropical region; South America
DE Apistogramma [South America / Orinoco River Basin / Key to species]. 
   Apistogramma megaptera [Colombia /  / New species] [Venezuela /  / ].

DT Article
TI Trichomycterus sketi: a new species of subterranean catfish
   (Siluriformes: Trichomycteridae) from the Andean Cordillera of Colombia.
AU Castellanos-Morales, Cesar A. (cesarcas1a@gmail.com) 
SO Biota Colombiana
VL 11
IS 1-2
PS 33-41
PD enero-diciembre 2010(2011)
PY 2011
LA English
U1 0
U2 1
AB A new catfish species belonging to genus Trichomycterus Valenciennes
   (Trichomycteridae) is described. Trichomycterus sketi n. sp. was
   collected in Cueva del Indio located in the upper ro Opon basin,
   Magdalena river system, in the Andean Cordillera, Santander department,
   Colombia. The new species differs from other species of the genus by
   having posterior fontanel divided into two widely separated portions;
   head wider than body; body thin, nearly as deep as wide. The new species
   is compared with cave species of the genus having restricted
   distributions in South America and with epigean species from Colombia.
C1 Castellanos-Morales, Cesar A.; Universidad Industrial de Santander -
   Escuela de Biologia, Carrera 27 calle 9, Ciudad Universitaria,
   Bucaramanga, CP 678, Colombia, Colombia.

DT Article
TI [Batrachoidiformes of Colombian waters.]
FT Batrachoidiformes de aguas colombianas.
AU Ibagon E, Nicole (nicoleibagon@gmail.com) 
   Acero P, Arturo
   Polanco F, Andrea
SO Biota Colombiana
VL 11
IS 1-2
PS 43-52
PD enero-diciembre 2010(2011)
PY 2011
LA Spanish
U1 0
U2 1
AB In order to establish the group diversity and to clarify the status of
   some species, a taxonomic review of the teleostean fishes included in
   the order Batrachoidiformes (toadfishes) from Colombian waters was made,
   based on available samples in the main fish collections of the country.
   The Batrachoidiformes include a single family, Batrachoididae, with
   three subfamilies (Porichthyinae, Batrachoidinae y Thalassophryninae) in
   the New World. In Colombia there are five genera deposited in the
   Colombian Marine Natural History Museum - MHNMC and the referenced
   collections: Porichthys, Batrachoides, Sanopus, Daector, and
   Thalassophryne. Those genera include 15 species: P. margaritatus, P.
   oculellus, P. pauciradiatus, P. plectrodon, B. boulengeri, B. manglae,
   B. pacifici, B. surinamensis, Sanopus sp., D. dowi, D. gerringi, D.
   quadrizonatus, T. amazonica, T. maculosa, and T. nattereri.The most
   representative species of referenced collections because of the number
   of samples and wide distribution in Colombian water are D. dowi, P.
   plectrodon, P. margaritatus, and T. maculosa. An identification key for
   Colombian species of Batrachoidiformes is included.
C1 Ibagon E, Nicole; Calle 6 #87A-15, Tintala 1, Apto 204 Int 34, Bogota,
   Colombia, Colombia.
EM nicoleibagon@gmail.com
SC Zoology

   Neotropical region; South America

DT Article
TI Burseramyia braziliensis, a new species of gall midge (Diptera,
   Cecidomyiidae, Asphondyliini) associated with Swartzia langsdorfii Raddi
   (Fabaceae).
AU Maia, Valeria Cid (maiavcid@acd.ufrj.br) 
   Figueiredo Fonseca, Karina
SO Biota Neotropica
VL 11
IS 4
PS 1-3
PD 2011
PY 2011
UR http://www.biotaneotropica.org.br/v11n4/pt/toc
AW http://www.biotaneotropica.org.br/v11n4/pt/fullpaper?bn00611042011+en
LA English
U1 0
U2 0
AB Burseramyia braziliensis Maia&Fonseca, a new species of Cecidomyiidae
   (Diptera) that induces leaf galls on Swartzia langsdorfii Raddi
   (Fabaceae) is described and illustrated (larva, pupa, male and female)
   based on material from restinga areas of Bertioga, Sao Paulo, Brazil.
   Until now, Burseramyia was known from one galling species, Burseramyia
   burserae Mohn, 1960, restricted to El Salvador. The genus is easily
   recognizable by the shape of the gonostylus (equally subdivided into
   toothed and setose portions). The new species differs from the
   previously described species mainly in the number and shape of terminal
   papillae (larva), shape of hypropoct (male) and method of pupation.
C1 Maia, Valeria Cid; Departamento de Entomologia, Museu Nacional, Quinta
   da Boa Vista, Sao Cristovao, CEP 20940-040, Rio de Janeiro, RJ, Brazil,
   Brazil.
EM maiavcid@acd.ufrj.br

TI Iporangomberus pei n. gen., n. sp. from southeastern Brazil (Diptera:
   Chironomidae, Orthocladiinae).
AU Mendes, Humberto Fonseca (humberto.mendes@bm.uib.no) 
   Andersen, Trond
SO Biota Neotropica
VL 11
IS 4
PS 1-5
PD 2011
PY 2011
UR http://www.biotaneotropica.org.br/v11n4/pt/toc
AW http://www.biotaneotropica.org.br/v11n4/pt/fullpaper?bn01311042011+en
LA English
U1 0
U2 0
AB Iporangomberus pei n. gen., n. sp. is described and illustrated based on
   an adult male from Mata Atlantica in southeastern Brazil. This genus can
   be separated from other Orthocladiinae based on the combination of hairy
   eyes; decumbent acrostichals starting close to antepronotum; bare wing;
   squama with few setae; R4+5 ending distal to M3+4 ; curved, apically
   spoon-shaped phallapodeme; and simple, subquadrangular gonostylus with
   well developed heel.
C1 Mendes, Humberto Fonseca; Department of Natural History, University
   Museum of Bergen, University of Bergen, PO Box 7800 N-5020, Bergen,
   Norway, Norway.
EM humberto.mendes@bm.uib.no
SC Zoology
SN 1806-129X; 1676-0611
BD Systematics; Nomenclature; New taxa; Land zones; Neotropical region;
   South America
DE Iporangomberus pei [Brazil /  / New species].

PT J
AN ZOOR14807045639
DT Article
TI The orchid bee fauna (Hymenoptera, Apidae) of a core area of the
   Cerrado, Brazil: the role of riparian forests as corridors for
   forest-associated bees.
AU Ribeiro Faria, Luiz Roberto (nunofariajr@gmail.com) 
   Amaral da Silveira, Fernando
SO Biota Neotropica
VL 11
IS 4
PS 1-8
PD 2011
PY 2011
UR http://www.biotaneotropica.org.br/v11n4/pt/toc
AW http://www.biotaneotropica.org.br/v11n4/pt/fullpaper?bn02111042011+en
LA English
U1 0
U2 0
AB The composition of local orchid-bee faunas (Hymenoptera, Apidae,
   Euglossina) in open-vegetation domains is poorly known, making the
   ecology and biogeography of the group dificult to understand. The aim of
   this work was to answer the following questions: i) Is the orchid-bee
   fauna composition, species richness and abundance in the cerrado
   (Brazilian savanna) sensu stricto similar to that of riparian forests
   immersed in that domain? ii) Do species from neighboring forest domains
   use riparian forests as mesic corridors into the Cerrado? Two sites in
   cerrado s.s. and two in riparian forests were sampled monthly, one day
   per month, during one year (Nov/2003[long dash]Oct/2004) in northwestern
   Minas Gerais state, Brazil. Six aromatic compounds ([beta]-ionone,
   1,8-cineole, eugenol, methyl trans-cinnamate, methyl salicilate and
   vanillin) were exposed from 8:00 AM to 4:00 PM to attract orchid bees.
   The results suggest that: i) The composition of the orchid bee fauna in
   the two kinds of environments is the same; ii) Riparian forests
   apparently have no role as mesic corridors for penetration of
   forest-dependent euglossine species into the core of the Cerrado Domain.
C1 Ribeiro Faria, Luiz Roberto; Programma Pos-graduacao em Ecologia,
   Conservacao e Manejo de Vida Silvestre, Departamento de Zoologia,
   Universidade Federal de Minas Gerais - UFMG, CP 486, CEP 30123-9,
   Brazil, Brazil.
EM nunofariajr@gmail.com
SC Zoology; Environmental Sciences &Ecology; Forestry
SN 1806-129X; 1676-0611
BD Ecology; Habitat; Terrestrial habitat; Land zones; Neotropical region;
   South America
DE Euglossina [Community structure /  / Comparative study] [Terrestrial
   habitat / Cerrado / ] [Forest and woodland / Riparian forest / ]
   [Riparian habitat /  / ] [Brazil / Minas Gerais, Brasilandia de Minas /
   ]. 
TN Arthropods; Hymenopterans; Insects; Invertebrates
ST Animalia, Arthropoda, Insecta, Hymenoptera, Apocrita, Aculeata, Apoidea,
   Apidae
OR Euglossina (Apidae).

TI A new species of Colosmittia Andersen et Saether from Costa Rica
   (Chironomidae: Orthocladiinae).
AU Andersen, Trond (trond.andersen@zmb.uib.no) 
   Mendes, Humberto F.
   Hagenlund, Linn K.
SO Biota Neotropica
VL 11
IS 3
PS 211-213
PD 2011
PY 2011
UR http://www.biotaneotropica.org.br/v11n3/en/toc
AW http://www.biotaneotropica.org.br/v11n3/en/abstract?article+bn0371103201
   1
LA English
U1 0
U2 0
AB Colosmittia anamariae sp. n. from Costa Rica is described and figured as
   male imago. The genus Colosmittia Andersen et Saether, 1994 was
   described based on a single species, C. clavata Andersen et Saether,
   1994 from the West Usambara Mountains in Tanzania, East Africa. A second
   species, C. brasileira Mendes et Andersen, 2009 was recently described
   from Brazil. The discovery of a third species in Costa Rica indicates
   that the genus might be widespread in the Neotropical region.

DT Article
TI A NEW, POSSIBLY THREATENED SPECIES OF MELANOPHRYNISCUS GALLARDO, 1961
   FROM THE STATE OF MINAS GERAIS, SOUTHEASTERN BRAZIL (AMPHIBIA, ANURA,
   BUFONIDAE).
AU Caramaschi, Ulisses (ulisses@acd.ufrj.br) 
   Cruz, Carlos Alberto Goncalves
SO Boletim do Museu Nacional Rio de Janeiro Zoologia
VL 528
PS 1-9
PD 19 de Abril 2011
PY 2011
LA English
U1 0
U2 0
AB A new species belonging to the Melanophryniscus tumifrons group is
   described from the Pico do Selado (22[degrees]53[minute]05[second]S,
   46[degrees]01 [minute]43[second]W; ca. 2000m altitude), District of
   Monte Verde, Municipality of Camanducaia, State of Minas Gerais,
   Southeastern Brazil. Melanophryniscus peritus sp.nov. is characterized
   by the medium size (SVL 39.3 mm in female); head broader than long, with
   a prominent, rounded protuberance above snout, extending between eyes to
   near the mid length of upper eyelid; skin on dorsal and lateral surfaces
   of body largely covered by spinulose warts; foot without tumefaction on
   metatarsus; dorsum and flanks with light brown background color,
   maculated with sinuous dark brown glandular thin marks somewhat
   anastomosed, two rounded light brown spots on shoulders, a large whitish
   brown area on loreal region, and dorsal surfaces of arms and legs
   uniformly dark brown; gular region dark brown with clear brown spots;
   chest and belly with small irregular dark brown spots; dorsal surface of
   arms and legs uniformly dark brown. The new species extends the
   geographic distribution of the M. tumifrons group to 22[degrees]S, in
   the State of Minas Gerais, Brazil. Until the species have been
   rediscovered and new data on its biology, geographic distribution, and
   population size obtained, we suggest that M. peritus sp.nov. shall be
   considered a critically endangered species.
C1 Caramaschi, Ulisses; UFRJ, Museu Nacl, Rio De Janeiro, Brazil, Brazil.
EM ulisses@acd.ufrj.br

   Neotropical region; South America

   species / ] [Brazil /  / New species] [ / Minas Gerais / ]. 
TN Amphibians; Chordates; Vertebrates
ST Animalia, Chordata, Vertebrata, Amphibia, Lissamphibia, Anura, Bufonidae

AB A new species of Microcaecilia is described from the municipality of
   Obidos, state of Para, in the Brazilian part of the Guianan Region. The
   new species has a high number of secondary annuli, monocuspid
   vomeropalatine teeth, and other characteristics that together
   differentiate it from the other eight known species of the genus.

IS 3-4
PS 421-442

LA Spanish
U1 0

AB This work contributes data on Leiodidae from Costa Rica. Four new
   species are descri- bed: Dissochaetus unidentatus n. sp., Adelopsis
   curvata n. sp., Adelopsis mixta n. sp., and Ptomaphagus (Adelops)
   acuminatus n. sp. In all cases, the taxonomic position is discussed,
   pointing out the characters that differentiate these from similar
   species. In addition, records are provided for 17 other species, citing
   Adelopsis galea Ganaspini & Peck, 1996 for the first time.

DT Article
TI Carboniferous columnar crinoid plates in the Santiago Ixtaltepec region,
   Nochixtlan, Oaxaca; stratigraphic and paleobiogeographic considerations.
FT Placas columnares de crinoides del Carbonifero de la region de Santiago
   Ixtaltepec, Municipio de Nochixtlan, Oaxaca; consideraciones
   estratigraficas y paleobiogeograficas.
AU Villanueva-Olea, Rafael (rvo17@yahoo.com.mx) 
   Castillo-Espinoza, Karla Maria
   Sour-Tovar, Francisco
   Quiroz-Barroso, Sara Alicia
   Buitron-Sanchez, Blanca E.
SO Boletin de la Sociedad Geologica Mexicana
VL 63
IS 3
PS 429-443
PD 2011
PY 2011
UR http://boletinsgm.igeolcu.unam.mx/igl/index.php?option=com_content&view=
   article&id=423:volumen-63-numero-3-2011&catid=149:epoca4&Itemid=74
AW http://boletinsgm.igeolcu.unam.mx/epoca04/6303/%285%29Villanueva.pdf
LA Spanish
U1 0
U2 0
AB Eleven crinoid columnal morphotypes of Mississippian and Pennsylvanian
   ages found in different stratigraphic levels of the Santiago (informal
   unit) and Ixtaltepec formations in outcrops in the Santiago Ixtaltepec
   region, municipality of Nochixtlan, Oaxaca, are reported and described.
   Axilinucrinus angustus is proposed as a new morphogenus and new
   morphospecies. Cyclocaudex insaturatus and Floricyclus welleri have been
   found in middle Mississippian (Meramecian-Chesterian?) strata from the
   upper member of the Santiago formation. Lomalegnum cf. L. hormidium,
   Axilinucrinus angustus and one indeterminate genus are present in
   middle-late Mississippian (Meramecian-Chesterian) strata of the
   Ixtaltepec Formation. Pentagonomischus cf. P. plebeius and Cyclocion
   distinctus occur in early-middle Pennsylvanian (Morrowan-Desmoinesian)
   strata of the Ixtaltepec Formation. Cylindrocauliscus fiski and
   Cyclocaudex typicus are morphotypes with a broad distribution throughout
   the carboniferous section of Nochixtlan. A strong similarity exists
   between all of the parataxa from Oaxaca and those reported from lower
   Mississippian-middle Pennsylvanian faunas of the Mid-Continent region of
   the central eastern United States.
C1 Villanueva-Olea, Rafael; Posgrado en Ciencias Biologicas, Universidad
   Nacional Autonoma de Mexico, Ciudad Universitaria, 04510 Mexico, D.F.,
   Mexico, Mexico.

PT J
AN ZOOR14806040980
DT Article
TI THE TITHONIAN-BERRIASIAN AMMONITE FAUNA AND STRATIGRAPHY OF ARROYO
   CIENEGUITA, NEUQUEN-MENDOZA BASIN, ARGENTINA.
AU Scherzinger, A.
   Schweigert, G.
   Parent, H. (parent@fceia.unr.edu.ar) 
SO Boletin del Instituto de Fisiografia y Geologia Universidad Nacional de
   Rosario
VL 79-81
PS 21-94
PD 2011
PY 2011
LA English
U1 0
U2 0
AB In this paper we present the results of the revision of the ammonite
   fauna and the stratigraphy of the Tithonian- Berriasian succession of
   Arroyo Cieneguita (Mendoza, Argentina), based on new material recently
   collected and the collections studied by Steuer, Gerth and Krantz. The
   studied succession belongs to the Vaca Muerta Formation which overlies
   the Tordillo Formation in concordance. The lower part of the succession
   consists of marls and shales, being rich in ammonites, bivalves and
   gastropods; the middle (shales) and upper (limestones and marls) parts
   contain almost exclusively ammonites. The majority of the species
   described by Steuer and a part of those studied by Gerth and Krantz have
   been revised and several type specimens designated and refigured.
   Ammonites of the Haploceratoidea have been only recorded in the interval
   Picunleufuense - lower Internispinosum zones including the genera
   Pseudolissoceras, Cieneguiticeras, Pasottia, ?Parastreblites, ?Uhligites
   and ?Semiformiceras. The Catutosphinctes and Choicensisphinctes genera
   are recorded from the Picunleufuense Zone (lowermost Tithonian) up to
   the Koeneni Zone (uppermost Tithonian). Two new genera of the
   Lithacoceratinae (family Ataxiocertidae) are introduced: Krantziceras n.
   gen. and Platydiscus n. gen. Remaining Ataxioceratid genera recorded
   are: Lithacoceras, Mazatepites and probably Malagasites (a doubtful
   specimen). The Berriasellinae are represented by Parodontoceras,
   Substeueroceras, Blanfordiceras and Chigaroceras (a single specimen),
   and the Spiticeratinae by Spiticeras and Groebericeras. The
   Himalayitidae include species of Steueria n. gen., Micracanthoceras,
   Windhauseniceras, Corongoceras and Himalayites (a single specimen). The
   Aspidoceratinae are well represented by Aspidoceras, Toulisphinctes,
   Pseudhimalayites and Physodoceras, although as typical in the basin, the
   material is scarce. The chronostratigraphic classification and
   time-correlation of the studied succession are based, as usual, on the
   biostratigraphy of its ammonites. In some levels occur associations
   which enable the definition of ammonite (bio-)horizons, useful
   biostratigraphic units consisting of beds with a characteristic fauna.
   Eight new ammonite horizons are introduced, from below: cf. erinoides
   hz. (Zitteli Z.), falculatum hz. (Proximus Z.), vetustum hz., bardense
   hz. (Alternans Z.), striolatus hz. (Koeneni Z.), compressum hz.,
   noduliferum hz. (Noduliferum Z.) and transgrediens hz. (Damesi Z.). The
   succession of these horizons and other ones already defined in previous
   papers, are associated to the Andean chronostratigraphic scale which is
   then used for fine time-correlation between sections of several
   localities of the Neuquen-Mendoza Basin where a number of them could be
   recognized by means of their characteristic ammonite assemblages. The
   vetustum hz., Alternans Zone, upper Tithonian is recognized in
   Madagascar and probably in parts of Antarctica.
C1 Parent, H.; Laboratorio de Paleontologia, IFG, FCEIA, Universidad
   Nacional de Rosario, Pellegrini 250, 2000 Rosario, Argentina, Argentina.
EM parent@fceia.unr.edu.ar
SC Paleontology; Zoology
SN 1666-115X
BD Systematics; Nomenclature; New taxa; Type species; Type material;
   Diagnosis; Combination; Synonymy; Available name; Taxonomy; Taxonomic
   position; Ecology; Land zones; Neotropical region; South America;
   Geological time periods; Mesozoic
DE Ammonitida [Fossil assemblages /  / Systematics] [Argentina / Mendoza,

   Ammonites koellikeri - Zittel 1868 (Ammonitida): [Lectotype designated,

   Andiceras - Krantz 1926 (Ammonitida): [Nomen dubium, P. 42; Fossil].

   Berriasella argentina - Krantz 1928 (Ammonitida): [Lectotype designated,
   P. 61; Fossil].

   Berriasella pastorei - Leanza 1945 (Ammonitida): [Lectotype designated,
   P. 69; Fossil]. 
   Berriasella spinulosa - Gerth 1921 (Ammonitida): [Lectotype designated,
   P. 66; Fossil]. 
   Berriasella steinmanni - Krantz 1928 (Ammonitida): [Lectotype

DT Article
TI A NEW SPECIES OF COLEOPTERA FOR THE CHILEAN FAUNA: BLAPTEA ELGUETAI
   (COLEOPTERA: CHRYSOMELIDAE: CHRYSOMELINAE).
FT Una nueva especie de coleoptero para la fauna chilena: BLAPTEA ELGUETAI
   (coleoptera: CHRYSOMELIDAE: CHRYSOMELINAE).
AU Petitpierre, Eduard (eduard.petitpierre@uib.es) 
SO Boletin del Museo Nacional de Historia Natural Chile
VL 60
PS 63-66
PD 2011
PY 2011
LA Spanish
U1 0
U2 0
AB A new species, Blaptea elguetai is described from the central area of
   Chile; so far, it was classified as B. balyi, a species occurring in
   Colombia. However, both differ in morphological characters, either
   aedeagus and spermatheca, which are illustrated for its easy
   identification.

   Spain.

PT J
AN ZOOR14912066607
DT Article
TI An ornithological survey of Pinas Bay, a site on the Pacific coast of
   Darien Province, Panama.
AU Miller, Matthew J. (millerma@si.edu) 
   Weir, Jason T.
   Angehr, George R.
   Guitton, Peggy
   Bermingham, Eldredge
SO Boletin SAO
VL 20
IS 2
PS 29-38
PD 2011
PY 2011
LA English
U1 0
U2 0
AB We surveyed the avifauna of the lowland and foothill habitats
   surrounding Pinas Bay, located on the Pacific coast of Darien Province,
   Panama from 3 May-16 May, 2003 as part of a general biological inventory
   sponsored by the Smithsonian Tropical Research Institute and the Tropic
   Star Lodge. During the two weeks, we recorded 179 species, of which we
   collected 112 species. We recorded three restricted-range species, all
   near-threatened at the global level, and one globally-threatened
   species: Great Green Macaw. Furthermore, we collected two species at
   elevations substantially below previously published records for Panama,
   and we report the first instance of syntopic breeding condition Purple
   and Shining Honeycreepers (Cyanerpes sp.), as well as several first
   records of non-forest species for southwestern Darien Province.
C1 Miller, Matthew J.; Smithsonian Trop Res Inst, Apartado 0843-03092,
   Balboa, Panama, Panama.
EM millerma@si.edu
SC Zoology
SN 0123-9082
BD Land zones; Neotropical region; Central America
DE Aves [Panama / Darien, south west / Biology; distribution; faunal list;
   new record]. 
TN Birds; Chordates; Vertebrates
ST Animalia, Chordata, Vertebrata
OR Aves (Vertebrata): [New record]. 
UT ZOOREC:ZOOR14912066607
DA 2020-09-17

PT J
AN ZOOR14803025131
DT Article
TI Three new species of Harpalomorphus Peringuey, 1896 and notes on
   Boeomimetes Peringuey, 1896 (Coleoptera: Carabidae, Harpalinae).
FT Tre nuove specie di Harpalomorphus Peringuey, 1896 e note sul genere
   Boeomimetes Peringuey, 1896 (Coleoptera, Carabidae, Harpalinae).
AU Facchini, Sergio (sfacchini@virgilio.it) 
SO Bollettino del Museo Civico di Storia Naturale di Verona Botanica
   Zoologia
VL 35
PS 3-13
PD 2011
PY 2011
LA Italian
U1 0
U2 0
AB Three new species of Harpalomorphus Peringuey, 1896 are here described
   and the habitus and male genitalia of the new taxa are figured. H. minor
   n. sp., H. sinuaticollis n. sp. and H. pseudocapicola n. sp. from
   Republic of South Africa are the fifth, sixth and seventh species of
   this genus known so far. H. minor n. sp. is characterized by small size,
   pale brown elytra, sides of pronotum in the basal half almost
   rectilinearly restricted towards base and mesotarsomeres 1 of male with
   very small scale-like bristles ventrally. H. sinuaticollis n. sp. is
   characteristic in having a small size, pale brown elytra, sides of
   pronotum in the basal half markedly sinuate, hind angles of the pronotum
   right and mesotarsomeres 1 of male without scale-like bristles
   ventrally. H. pseudocapicola n. sp. is characterized by pale brown
   elytra, sides of pronotum in the basal half markedly sinuate, hind
   angles of the pronotum right, elytra with shoulders moved forward, with
   an evident tooth, and mesotarsomeres 1 of male without scale-like
   bristles ventrally. Moreover, some notes on the genus Harpalomorphus and
   the genus Boeomimetes Peringuey, 1896 are provided and the following
   change of systematic status is proposed: Boeomimetes jeanneli somalicus
   Basilewsky, 1964 valid species, not subspecies of Boeomimetes jeanneli
   Basilewsky, 1946. A map with the distribution and figures of habitus and
   male genitalia of the last two species are also given.
C1 Facchini, Sergio; Via Prati 12, I - 29100, Piacenza, Italy, Italy.
EM sfacchini@virgilio.it
SC Zoology; Anatomy &Morphology; Reproductive Biology
SN 1590-8399
BD Systematics; Nomenclature; New taxa; Diagnosis; Taxonomy; Status; Key;
   Documentation; Publications; General morphology; Reproduction;
   Reproductive system; Land zones; Afrotropical region; Africa
DE Boeomimetes jeanneli; Boeomimetes somalicus [Illustrations /  / ]
   [General morphology /  / ] [Genitalia /  / ] [Africa /  / distribution].
   
   Harpalomorphus minor; Harpalomorphus pseudocapicola; Harpalomorphus
   sinuaticollis [South Africa /  / New species]. 
TN Arthropods; Beetles; Insects; Invertebrates
ST Animalia, Arthropoda, Insecta, Coleoptera, Adephaga, Caraboidea,
   Carabidae
OR Boeomimetes - Peringuey 1896 (Carabidae): [Key to species, Amendment, p.
   11]. 
   Boeomimetes jeanneli - Basilewsky 1946 (Carabidae): [Diagnostic
   characters, P. 11]. 
   Boeomimetes jeanneli somalicus - Basilewsky 1964 (Carabidae): [Raised
   to, Boeomimetes somalicus, p. 11]. 
   Boeomimetes somalicus - Basilewsky 1964 (Carabidae): [Diagnostic
   characters, P. 11; Raised from, Boeomimetes jeanneli somalicus, p. 11]. 
   Harpalomorphus - Peringuey 1896 (Carabidae): [Systematics, P. 10]. 
   Harpalomorphus minor (Carabidae): [Sp nov, South Africa, P. 4]. 
   Harpalomorphus pseudocapicola (Carabidae): [Sp nov, South Africa, P. 9].

DT Article
TI On the genus Nesiotophasis Peringuey, with descriptions of four new
   species and new synonymies (Coleoptera, Curculionidae).
AU Bello, Cesare (cesarebello@ortoveneto.it) 
   Osella, Giuseppe
   Colonnelli, Enzo
SO Bollettino del Museo Civico di Storia Naturale di Verona Botanica
   Zoologia
VL 35
PS 21-36
PD 2011
PY 2011
LA English
U1 0
U2 0
AB Four new species of Nesiotophasis Peringuey from South Africa, N.
   boscimanus n. sp., N. dubius n. sp., N. inopinatus n. sp. and N.,
   superstes n. sp. are described and illustrated. The following new
   synonymies are established: Nesiotophasis promontorii (Peringuey, 1908)
   (= Paranesiotes abbreviatus Voss, 1974, syn. n.), N. capicola
   (Peringuey, 1908) (= Paranesiotes ferrugineus Voss, 1974, syn. n.), N.
   integer (Voss, 1974) (= Paranesiotes rudebecki Voss, 1974, syn. n.).
   Descriptions of the genus and of all its members are included, as well
   as a key to species.
C1 Bello, Cesare; Via a. Vespucci 11/A, I-31033 Castelfranco Veneto, Italy,
   Italy.
EM cesarebello@ortoveneto.it
SC Zoology
SN 1590-8399

   [Designated type species for, Nesiotophasis Peringuey 1908, p. 22].

TI [Description of Synapsusa lecoqi, new genus and new species from Reunion
   (Coleoptera, Staphylinidae).]
FT Description de Synapsusa lecoqi nouveau genre et nouvelle espece de La
   Reunion (Coleoptera, Staphylinidae).
AU Pace, Roberto (pace.ent@tiscali.it) 
SO Bollettino del Museo Civico di Storia Naturale di Verona Botanica
   Zoologia
VL 35
PS 37-41
PD 2011
PY 2011
LA Italian
U1 0
U2 0
AB Synapsusa lecoqi n. gen. and n. sp. is described and illustrated. The
   new genus, similar to Thamiaraea and Exaeretota, is included in a key of
   determination. Exaeretota reunionensis Pace is transferred to the new
   genus Synapsusa and its aedeagus, before unknown, is illustrated for the
   first time. A key distinguishes the two species of Synapsusa.

AN ZOOR14803025143
DT Article
TI New and additional records, new genera and new species of Aleocharinae
   from Venezuela, Ecuador and Peru (Coleoptera, Staphylinidae).
AU Pace, Roberto (pace.ent@tiscali.it) 
SO Bollettino del Museo Civico di Storia Naturale di Verona Botanica
   Zoologia
VL 35
PS 43-70
PD 2011
PY 2011
LA English
U1 0
U2 0
AB In the present paper 12 tribes (Deinopsini, Pronomaeini, Gyrophaenini,
   Placusini, Homalotini, Diestotini, Falagriini, Athetini, Lomechusini,
   Oxypodini, Hoplandriini, Aleocharini), 30 genera and 54 species are
   recognized. Twenty-eight species are described as new to science:
   Myllaena ecudimidiata n. sp., Gyrophaena canaimensis n. sp., Gyrophaena
   veninfida n. sp., Falagria scupolai n. sp., Falagria ecustricta n. sp.,
   Anaulacaspis rougemonti n. sp., Gnypeta etontii n. sp., Lamprostiba
   etontii n. sp., Atheta araguensis n. sp., Atheta etontii n. sp., Atheta
   dichroides n. sp., Atheta escalonai n. sp., Atheta flaviterminalis n.
   sp., Atheta bordoni n. sp., Atheta scurratheca n. sp., Parademosoma
   venezuelana n. sp., Leptonia andina n. sp., Leptonia peruviana n. sp.,
   Plesioleptonia abdominalis n. sp., Pseustantha escalonai n. sp.,
   Orphnebius venezuelanus n. sp., Kochlifeluva ecuadorensis n. sp.,
   Paraplandria quadripustulata n. sp., Paraplandria sanctaeclarae n. sp.,
   Paraplandria rougemonti n. sp., Platandria pastazensis n. sp., Eydelusa
   scupolai n. sp., Aleochara rougemonti n. sp. The new genera are:
   Plesioleptonia n. gen. and Pseustantha n. gen. both of the tribe
   Athetini, and Kochlifeluva n. gen. of the tribe Oxypodini. All new
   species and genera are illustrated. The new species and new genera are
   compared with specimens of the type series of closely related taxa
   examined by the author. A new synonymy of Akanthaktema Pace, 2008, n.
   syn. of Parademosoma Bernhauer, 1926 and a new combination: Parademosoma
   ecuadoriana (Pace, 2008), n. comb., from Hydrosmecta (Akanthaktema)
   ecuadoriana Pace, 2008, are proposed. Diestota curticollis (Erichson,
   1840) is the new combinaision for Atheta curticollis (Erichson, 1840).
   Coenonica puncticollis Kraatz, 1857, a species known above all in the
   Oriental Region, is new to South America.
C1 Pace, Roberto; Via Vittorio Veneto 13, I-37032, Monteforte d'Alpone,
   Verona, Italy, Italy.
EM pace.ent@tiscali.it

SN 1590-8399

TI Freshwater amphipods from Madagascar with description of a new familiy
   [family], three new genera and six new species (Crustacea, Amphipoda).
AU Iannilli, Valentina (valentina.iannilli@enea.it) 
   Krapp, Traudl
   Ruffo, Sandro
SO Bollettino del Museo Civico di Storia Naturale di Verona Botanica
   Zoologia
VL 35
PS 93-137
PD 2011
PY 2011
LA English
U1 0
U2 0
AB Sampling the freshwater-inhabitants of different localities in
   Madagascar yielded three new genera and six new species of Amphipoda of
   the superfamily Crangonyctoidea, showing how little known this zone has
   been until now. A new family is erected.

DT Article
TI Two new species of Bolivian Trechisibus Motschoulsky, 1863.
FT Due nuove specie di Trechisibus Motschoulsky, 1863 della Bolivia
   (Coleoptera, Carabidae, Trechinae).
AU Trezzi, Giuliano (giuliano.trezzi@tiscali.it) 
SO Bollettino del Museo Civico di Storia Naturale di Verona Botanica
   Zoologia
VL 35
PS 139-146
PD 2011
PY 2011
LA Italian
U1 0
U2 0
AB Two new species of Trechini are described here belonging to the genus
   Trechisibus, and found in two different localities at high altitudes in
   the Bolivian Andes, in the Real Cordillera, Department of La Paz.
   Trechisibus bolivarianus n. sp., from Huayna Potosi, 5200 m. and
   Trechisibus guzzettii n. sp., from Nevado Illampu, 4000 m. Besides, in
   the present work a brief discussion is given about external characters
   and genital apparatus comparing them with other species, in order to
   point out the inconsistence of the classic subdivision of Trechisibus in
   subgenera, based on the number of discal setae in the third elytral
   stria.

   (Milano), Italy, Italy.

DT Article
TI [The Cretaceous fish of Nardo. 33. Lecceclupea ehiravaensis gen. and sp.
   nov. (Teleostei, Clupeidae).]
FT Les poissons cretaces de Nardo. 33[degree]. Lecceclupea ehiravaensis
   gen. et sp. nov. (Teleostei, Clupeidae).
AU Taverne, Louis (louis.taverne@gmail.com) 
SO Bollettino del Museo Civico di Storia Naturale di Verona Geologia
   Paleontologia Preistoria
VL 35
PS 3-17
PD 2011
PY 2011
LA French
U1 0
U2 0
AB The osteology of Lecceclupea ehiravaensis gen. and sp. nov., a clupeid
   from the marine Campano-Maastrichthian of Nardo (Lecce province, Apulia,
   southern Italy) is described in details. Its caudal skeleton exhibits
   fused preural 1 and ural 1 vertebrae, and an autogenous ural 2 centrum.
   The penultimate anal pterygiophore possesses a distal part (mesonost)
   very elongated backwardly and the two last anal fin rays are distinctly
   separated from the other, forming so a finlet. These three characters
   allow to range this fish within the family Clupeidae, the subfamily
   Pellonulinae and the tribe Ehiravini.
C1 Taverne, Louis; Residence "Les Platanes", Boulevard du Souverain 142,
   (Boite 8), B-1170 Bruxelles, Belgium, Belgium.
EM louis.taverne@gmail.com
SC Zoology
SN 1590-8402

   Eurasia; Europe; Geological time periods; Mesozoic

   Lecceclupea ehiravaensis [Italy /  / new species] [Cretaceous /  / ].

   Clupeiformes, Clupeidae

   of H. lyleae n. sp. from the Republic of South Africa (Insecta,

U1 0

AB Redescription and illustrations are presented for Hoplia laconiae
   Petrovitz, a poorly known species from Greece for which no further data
   appeared after the original description. Based on the examination of
   type specimens, the synonymy Hoplia caucasica danieli Tesar, 1969 = H.
   laconiae Petrovitz, 1958 is established. The exact year of description
   of Hoplia herminiana Apfelbeck is also provided.

DT Article
TI THREE NEW SPECIES OF DRYXO ROBINEAU-DESVOIDY, 1830 FROM AFRICA, WITH A
   KEY TO THE SPECIES OF THE AFROTROPICAL REGION (INSECTA, DIPTERA,
   EPHYDRIDAE).
AU Raffone, Gianni (gianni_raffone@tin.it) 
SO Bollettino del Museo di Storia Naturale di Venezia
VL 62
PS 95-100
PD 2011
PY 2011
LA English
U1 0
U2 0
AB Three new species of Dryxo Robineau-Desvoidy, 1830 are described: Dryxo
   pseudornata n. sp. related to Dryxo ornata (Macquart, 1844), from which
   it differs in having anepisternum with 3 setae on posterior-margin, hind
   basitarsus of male lacking posterodorsal setae, as well as for the
   maculation of abdomen, besides the male terminalia morphology; Dryxo
   obscura n. sp. related to Dryxo ornata, from which it differs in having
   the parafacial with a golden brown spot reaching genal area, the
   presence of two posterior dorsocentral setae, the maculation of abdomen,
   as well as the male terminalia morphology; Dryxo fusca n. sp. related to
   Dryxo ornata, from which it differs in having parafacial entirely brown
   with dark spot reaching genal area, for the maculation of abdomen, as
   well as the male terminalia morphology.
C1 Raffone, Gianni; Museo Storia Nat Venezia, Santa Croce 1730, Venice,
   I-30135, Italy, Italy.
EM gianni_raffone@tin.it

DT Article
TI DRAPETIS IORDANIENSIS N. SP FROM JORDAN (INSECTA, DIPTERA, HYBOTIDAE).
AU Raffone, Gianni (gianni_raffone@tin.it) 
SO Bollettino del Museo di Storia Naturale di Venezia
VL 62
PS 101-103
PD 2011
PY 2011
LA English
U1 0
U2 0
AB Drapetis iordaniensis n. sp. from Jordan (Azraq, Wetland Reserve) is
   described. The new species is related to Drapetis flavipes (Macquart,
   1834) and differs from it in the number of notopleural setae (2 in D.
   iordaniensis; 1 in D. flavipes), number of supralar setae (2 in D.
   iordaniensis; 1 in D. flavipes) and morphology of the male terminalia.

DT Article
TI A new glyptomeroid species of Lathrobium from the Aurunci Mountains,
   Latium (Coleoptera Staphylinidae).
AU Bordoni, Arnaldo (arnaldo.bordoni@libero.it) 
   Magrini, Paolo
SO Bollettino della Societa Entomologica Italiana
VL 143
IS 1
PS 15-17
PD gennaio-aprile 2011
PY 2011
LA English
U1 0
U2 0
AB Lathrobium auruncum n. sp. from the Aurunci Mts (central Italy) is
   described. The new species is closely related to L. oblitum Pace, 1977
   from Mount Viglio (Lazio-Abruzzi), which differs in some external
   characters such as a smaller body, more elongate head, shorter pronotum
   and elytra, and distincte male genitalia (i. e., smaller aedeagus,
   different shape of dorsal and ventral laminae and of the inner sac). It
   is suggested, the presence of several endemic species on Aurunci Mts is
   in relation to the prolonged isolation of these mountains, which were
   islands separated from the mainlnand.
C1 Bordoni, Arnaldo; Univ Florence, Museo Storia Nat, Via Romana 17,
   Florence, Italy, Italy.
EM arnaldo.bordoni@libero.it
SC Zoology
SN 0373-3491

   region; Eurasia; Europe
DE Lathrobium auruncum [Italy /  / New species]. 
TN Arthropods; Beetles; Insects; Invertebrates
ST Animalia, Arthropoda, Insecta, Coleoptera, Polyphaga, Staphylinoidea,
   Staphylinidae

   P. 15].

PT J
AN ZOOR14708060105
DT Article
TI Taxonomic remarks on Cryptocephalus aureolus and C. therondi (Coleoptera
   Chrysomelidae).
FT Annotazioni tassonomiche su Cryptocephalus aureolus e C. therondi
   (Coleoptera Chrysomelidae).
AU Sassi, Davide (davidesassi14@gmail.com) 
SO Bollettino della Societa Entomologica Italiana
VL 143
IS 1
PS 19-31
PD gennaio-aprile 2011
PY 2011
LA Italian
U1 0
U2 0
AB Taxonomic remarks on Cryptocephalus aureolus and C. therondi (Coleoptera
   Chrysomelidae). Subsequent to the study of several tens of specimens
   coming from the whole range the taxonomy of Cryptocephalus aureolus
   Suffrian and its subspecies has been reviewed. Lectotypes of all the
   mentioned taxa have been designated. C. aureole's ssp. transcaucasicus
   Jacobson is raised to valid species, that is how it was formerly
   regarded by the author. C. aureole's ssp. monticola Breit and C.
   aureolus ssp. illyricus Franz are considered as new syn. of C.
   transcaucasicus. Short biogeographical notes are provided. For
   completion of a previous study, the lectotypus of Cryptocephalus
   therondi Franz has been designated as well.
C1 Sassi, Davide; Via San Rocco 17, Castelmarte, CO, Italy, Italy.
EM davidesassi14@gmail.com
SC Zoology
SN 0373-3491
BD Systematics; Nomenclature; Type material; Synonymy; Taxonomy; Status;
   Zoogeography; Land zones; Palaearctic region
DE Cryptocephalus [Zoogeography /  / Systematics] [Eurasia /  / biology;
   distribution].

TI Description of four new species of Gymnetron from South Africa
   (Coleoptera Curculionidae).

   (Coleoptera Curculionidae).

SO Bollettino della Societa Entomologica Italiana
VL 143
IS 1
PS 33-39
PD gennaio-aprile 2011
PY 2011
LA Italian
U1 0
U2 0
AB Description of four new species of Gymnetron from South Africa
   (Coleoptera Curculionidae). Four new species belonging to the weevil
   genus Gymnetron Schoenherr, 1825 collected in South Africa are here
   described: Gymnetron brevinasus n. sp., G. ibis n. sp., G. monstruosum
   n. sp., and G. subdolum n. sp. For every taxon the description, the
   photograph of their habitus, the illustration of rostra and genitalia,
   and the differential characters from the more closely related species
   are reported.

PT J
AN ZOOR14802010552
DT Article
TI The xenusian-to-anomalocaridad transition within the lobopodians.
AU Dzik, Jerzy (dzik@twarda.pan.pl) 
SO Bollettino della Societa Paleontologica Italiana
VL 50
IS 1
PS 65-74
PD 2011
PY 2011
LA English
U1 0
U2 10
AB The morphological series composed of large xenusiids of the Chengjiang
   fauna of China and the basal anomalocaridids Pambdelurion and
   Kerygmachela from the Sirius Passel fauna of Greenland is supplemented
   with another xenusiid lobopodian, Siberion lenaicus gen. et sp. nov,
   from the Early Cambrian Sinsk Formation of central Siberia. Reduction
   and ventral bending of the proboscis in Siberion and the Chengjiang
   Megadictyon and Jianshanopodia may be a synapomorphy uniting these
   representatives with the anomalocaridids. Throughout the series, the
   raptorial appendages became larger and more sclerotised, while the
   gill-like structures on the trunk appendages were transformed from their
   originally tubular shape into a pinnate form and may eventually have
   given rise to the wide anomalocaridid flaps. Such a tendency can be
   rooted in the Aysheaia-like xenusians, that have raptorial appendages
   associated with a prominent proboscis. This results in a scenario of
   almost complete transition from early lobopodians to ancestral
   arthropods within the xenusian-anomalocaridid segment of the
   phylogenetic tree.
C1 Dzik, Jerzy; Instytut Paleobiologii PAN, Twarda 51/55, 00-818 Warszawa,
   and Instytut Zoologii Uniwersytetu Warszawskiego, Banacha 2, 02-079,
   Warszawa, Poland, Poland.
EM dzik@twarda.pan.pl
SC Zoology; Evolutionary Biology; Anatomy &Morphology
SN 0375-7633
BD Systematics; Nomenclature; New taxa; Taxonomy; Taxonomic position;
   General morphology; Evolution; Land zones; Palaearctic region; Eurasia;
   Geological time periods; Palaeozoic
DE Lobopodia [Evolution /  / Systematics] [Russia / Siberia, Lena River
   region / ] [Cambrian / Early Cambrian / ]. 
   Siberiida [Cambrian /  / New order]. 
   Siberiidae [Cambrian /  / New family]. 
   Siberion [Cambrian /  / New genus]. 
   Siberion lenaicus [Russia /  / new species] [Cambrian /  / ]. 
   Xenusia [General morphology /  / systematics] [Evolution /  / ] [Russia
   / Siberia / ] [Cambrian /  / ]. 
TN Invertebrates
ST Animalia, Xenusia
OR Lobopodia (Animalia): [Fossil]. 
   Megadictyon - Luo & Hu 1999 (Animalia): [Referred to, New family
   Siberiidae (Xenusia), p. 72; Fossil]. 
   Xenusia (Animalia): [Fossil]. 
   Jianshanopodia - Liu et al 2006 (Xenusia): [Referred to, New family
   Siberiidae, p. 72; Fossil]. 
   Siberiida (Xenusia): [Order nov, For Siberiidae (new), p. 72, Cambrian;
   Fossil]. 
   Siberiidae (Xenusia): [Fam nov, Of new order Siberiida, Type genus
   Siberion, p. 72, Cambrian; Fossil]. 
   Siberion (Xenusia): [Gen nov, Of new family Siberiidae, Type species
   Siberion lenaicus, p. 72, Cambrian; Fossil]. 
   Siberion lenaicus (Xenusia): [Sp nov, Russia, Cambrian, P. 73; Fossil].

AN ZOOR15208052803
DT Article
TI Cricket frog (Amphibia: Anura: Dicroglossidae): two regions of Asia are
   corresponding two groups.
AU Howlader, Mohammad Sajid Ali (sajidpabc@gmail.com) 
SO Bonnoprani - Bangladesh Wildlife Bulletin
VL 5
IS 1-2
PS 1-7
PD 2011
PY 2011
LA English
U1 0
U2 0
AB Cricket frogs are widely distributed throughout South and South-east
   Asia. They are divided into two distinct clades based on phylogenetics
   and morphology: South Asian morph and Southeast Asian morph.
   Morphologically, they can also be classified according to their
   distribution pattern. Herein, South Asian Cricket frogs are grouped
   under Zakerana, a new genus.
C1 Howlader, Mohammad Sajid Ali; Herpetology Laboratory' Bangladesh (HL'B),
   House no: 28/5 Shonatangar, Jigatola, Dhanmondi, Dhaka-1209, Bangladesh,
   Bangladesh.
EM sajidpabc@gmail.com

   Taxonomy; Taxonomic position; Land zones; Palaearctic region; Eurasia
DE Fejervarya [Asia / South & south east / Distribution; systematics].

TI [New Trichoptera from Europe and Asia.]
FT Neue Trichopteren aus Europa und Asien.
AU Malicky, Hans
SO Braueria
VL 38
PS 23-43
PD 2011
PY 2011
LA German
U1 0
U2 2
AB 26 new species are described and figured in the genera Himalopsyche
   (Rhyacophilidae, 2 species), Synagapetus (Glossosomatidae, 1), Chimarra
   (Philopotamidae, 4), Gunungiella (Philopotamidae, 1), Wormaldia
   (Philopotamidae, 1), Stenopsyche (Stenopsychidae, 1), Polyplectropus
   (Polycentropodidae, 5), Psychomyia (Psychomyiidae, 2), Tinodes
   (Psychomyiidae, 2), Cheumatopsyche (Hydropsychidae, 3), Hydromanicus
   (Hydropsychidae, 1), Diplectrona (Hydropsychidae, 1), Goera (Goeridae,
   1), Apatania (Limnephilidae, 2),
   Limnephilus	(Limnephilidae,	1),	Pseudostenophylax (Limnephilidae, 7),
   Lepidostoma (Lepidostomatidae, 1), Psilotreta	(Odontoceridae,	1),
   Anisocentropus (Calamoceratidae, 1), Triaenodes (Leptoceridae, 1),
   Leptocerus (Leptoceridae, 1), Oecetis (Leptoceridae, 1), Ceraclea
   (Leptoceridae, 1), Beraea (Beraeidae, 1) which came from Italy,
   Portugal, Thailand, China, Sumatra, Bali, Kalimantan, Ambon, Bacan,
   Irian Jaya, Sabah and West Malaysia. [long dash] Parapsyche aias and
   Pseudostenophylax cf. obscurus are figured. - A hypothesis is put
   forward that the genus Pseudostenophylax may include many local endemic
   species, similar as in the European Drusinae. The study of their inter-
   and intraspecific relationships may be similarly important as in
   Drusinae.
