DT Article
TI A new pachycephalosaurid from the Baynshire Formation (Cenomanian-Late
   Santonian), Gobi Desert, Mongolia.
AU Watabe, Mahito
   Tsogtbaatar, Khishigjaw
   Sullivan, Robert M.
SO Bulletin of the New Mexico Museum of Natural History and Science
VL 53
PS 489-497
PD 2011
PY 2011
LA English
U1 0
U2 2
AB A nearly complete pachycephalosaurid frontoparietal dome, from the
   Baynshire Formation at Amtgai, southern Gobi Desert, Mongolia, is
   identified as a new taxon. Amtocephalegohiensis n. gen., n. sp. differs
   from all other pachycephalosaurids in a combination of features that
   include: deep supratemporal fossae; broad (craniocaudally) prefrontal
   sutural surfaces with the nasal; prefrontal and anterior supraorbital
   sutural surfaces lying in a single plane; short parietal (parietal
   length to the frontoparietal length is 2.44); the medial posterior
   extension the parietal sharply downturned and wide relative to the
   maximum width of the frontoparietal; and lacking supratemporal
   fenestrae. Amtocephalegobiensis may be the oldest known
   pachycephalosaurid as it comes from rocks that are no younger than late
   Santonian. While it may be the oldest known pachycephalosaurid,
   phylogenetic analysis Amtocephale gobiensis suggests relationship to the
   more derived pachycephalosaurids.
C1 Watabe, Mahito; Center for Paleobiological Research, Hayashibara
   Biochemical Laboratories Inc., Okayama 700-0907, Japan, Japan.

   Mesozoic

   Amtocephale gobiensis [Mongolia /  / new species] [Cretaceous /  / ].

   ].

DT Article
TI Stegomastodon (Mammalia, Proboscidea) from the Pliocene of Jalisco,
   Mexico and the species-level taxonomy of Stegomastodon.
AU Lucas, Spencer G.
   Aguilar, Ricardo H.
   Spielmann, Justin A.
SO Bulletin of the New Mexico Museum of Natural History and Science
VL 53
PS 517-553
PD 2011
PY 2011
LA English
U1 0
U2 0
AB We describe a nearly complete skeleton of the gomphotheriid proboscidean
   Stegomastodon primitivus Osborn from the Pliocene (Blancan) of Lago de
   Chapala, Jalisco, Mexico. This skeleton documents important differences
   between the postcrania of North American Stegomastodon and the
   gomphothere postcrania from South America assigned to Cuvieronius,
   Haplomastodon and Stegomastodon that include features indicative of more
   graviportal limbs (especially the forelimb) in North American
   Stegomastodon. This strengthens the case against referring any South
   American gomphothere fossils to Stegomastodon; Notiomastodon and
   Haplomastodon are the valid generic names for these fossils.
   Stegomastodon is known only from North America, and ranges from early
   Blancan ([long dash]4 Ma) to early lrvingtonian ([long dash]1.2 Ma) in
   age. Its fossils form a chronomorphocline that can be assigned to three
   species: early Blancan S. primitivus, primarily late Blancan S.
   mirificus (Leidy) and early Irvingtonian S. aftoniae (Osborn).

AN ZOOR14802015412
DT Article
TI Systematics of the musk deer (Artiodactyla: Moschidae: Blastomerycinae)
   from the Miocene of Nevada.
AU Prothero, Donald R.
SO Bulletin of the New Mexico Museum of Natural History and Science
VL 53
PS 610-615
PD 2011
PY 2011
LA English
U1 0
U2 0
AB The North American musk deer (family Moschidae, subfamily
   Blastomerycinae) were an important element of many faunas during the
   Miocene. They were recently revised by Prothero (2008), who reduced
   dozens of named species to only 8 species distributed among 6 genera.
   Two samples from early-middle Miocene faunas of Nevada, however, were
   not assessed in the 2008 revision. These include the type series of
   Blastomervx mollis Merriam, 1911, from the early Barstovian (early
   middle Miocene) Virgin Valley and High Rock faunas, and specimens from
   the late Hemingfordian (late early Miocene) Massacre Lake fauna that
   Morea (1981) thought represented a new genus and 1 or 2 new species.
   These specimens are re-examined in light of the improved sample size and
   taxonomy of other Miocene blastomerycines, and it is clear that neither
   study was based on inadequate comparisons with enough specimens. Based
   on the modern taxonomy of blastomerycines, these Nevada samples are
   assigned to Problastomeryx primus (Matthew, 1908), a common primitive
   early-middle Miocene blastomerycid in North America. Blastomervx mollis
   Merriam, 1911 is rendered ajunior synonym.
C1 Prothero, Donald R.; Department of Geology, Occidental College, Los
   Angeles, California 90041, USA, USA.
SC Anatomy &Morphology; Zoology; Paleontology
SN 1524-4156
BD Systematics; Nomenclature; Synonymy; Skeletal and supporting structures;
   Land zones; Nearctic region; North America; USA; Geological time
   periods; Caenozoic; Tertiary; Neogene
DE Blastomerycinae [Skeleton / Fossil morphology / Systematics; taxonomic
   implications] [Nevada /  / ] [Miocene /  / ]. 
TN Chordates; Mammals; Ungulates; Vertebrates
ST Animalia, Chordata, Vertebrata, Mammalia, Artiodactyla, Cervidae
OR Blastomerycinae (Cervidae): [Fossil]. 
   Problastomeryx primus - (Matthew 1908) (Cervidae): [Syn nov, Blastomeryx
   mollis Merriam 1911, p. 611; Fossil].

DT Article
TI Selachians from the Upper Cretaceous (Santonian) Hosta Tongue of the
   Point Lookout Sandstone, central New Mexico.
AU Bourdon, Jim (jim_bourdon@elasmo.com) 
   Wright, Keith
   Lucas, Spencer G.
   Spielmann, Justina A.
   Pence, Randy
SO Bulletin of the New Mexico Museum of Natural History and Science
VL 52
PS i-iv, 1-54
PD 2011
PY 2011
LA English
U1 0
U2 1
AB In Bernalillo County, central New Mexico, a thin sandstone bed in the
   upper part of the Hosta Tongue of the Point Lookout Sandstone (Upper
   Cretaceous, Santonian) yields a diverse assemblage of selachian and
   other vertebrate fossils. The selachian teeth are assigned to the
   following taxa: ?Egertonodus sp., Meristodonoides sp. cf. M.
   montanensis, Planohybodus sp., Lonchidion sp., Ptychodus mortoni,
   Parasquatina sp., Cantioscrllium decipiens, Chiloscyllium sp.,
   Cederstroemia ziaensis new species, Columbusia sp. cf. C. fragilis,
   Scindocorav novimexicanus new genus and species, Squalicorax sp. cf. S.
   lindstromi, S. sp. aff. S. yangaensis, Cretoxyrhina mantelli,
   Scapanorhynchus puercoensis new species, S. sp. cf. S. tenuis, S. sp.
   cf. S. texanus, "Carcharias" sp., Eostriatolamia sp., Pueblocarcharias
   kawaikensis new genus and species, Cretalamna sp., Ptychotrygon
   eutawensis, Texatrygon stout new species, Ischyrhiza sp. aff. I. mira,
   cf. Onchosaurus sp., Sclerorhynchus sp., Rhinobatos sp., Proplatyrhina
   sp. aff. P. renae, Myledaphus sp. and "Pseudohypolophus" ellipsis. In
   addition to the selachians, the Hosta Tongue assemblage includes fossils
   of teleost fish, turtles, plesiosaurs, mosasaurs, crocodiles, and
   dinosaurs. Teeth of Scapanorhynchus dominate the selachian assemblage
   ([long dash]51%), followed by sclerorhynchids (teeth and rostral spines,
   -22%) and rhinobatoids ([long dash]16%); the other selachians are minor
   components.

IS 1
PS 64-66
PD Jan 2011
PY 2011
LA Russian
U1 0
U2 0
AB New species Dolichopus jakutus Selivanova et Negrobov sp. n. is
   described from Yakutia. The given species is close to Dolichopus
   shantaricus Stack., but different from this species with long
   apicoventral bristle on fore tibia, fore coxae with light yellow hairs,
   veins M1+2 and R4+5 at top parallel, cerci long-oval.

TI Ampelisca sevastopoliensis sp n. (Amfhipoda [Amphipoda], Ampeliscidae) -
   new species from coastal zone of Crimea (Black Sea).
AU Grintsov, V.A. (V.Grintsov@gmail.ru) 
SO Byulleten' Moskovskogo Obshchestva Ispytatelei Prirody Otdel
   Biologicheskii
VL 116
IS 1
PS 67-69
PD Jan 2011
PY 2011
LA Russian
U1 0
U2 1
AB New species Ampelisca sevastopoliensis sp. n. (Amphipoda, Ampeliscidae)
   is describe from mud community of Crimea coastal zone (15 m depth)
   (Sevastopol, Black Sea). Morphological and ecological data are
   presented. Differential diagnosis of morphology: head long narrow
   anteriorly, A 1 shorter than A 2 peduncle, Mx 1 inner lobe without seta,
   urosome with carina.

TI Cyclaspis giveni sp nov (Crustacea: Cumacea) from Bahia de Todos Santos,
   Baja California, Mexico.
AU Donath-Hernandez, Francisco E. (ultronic_oli@hotmail.com) 
SO Cahiers de Biologie Marine
VL 52
IS 2
PS 125-129
PD 2011
PY 2011
LA English
U1 0
U2 1
AB The order Cumacea (Crustacea, Peracarida), of the Mexican coast is
   poorly known. Previous descriptions of new species have been limited to
   the Gulf of California. With the description of Cyclaspis given; sp.
   nov. from Bahia de Todos Santos, four species of the genus Cyclaspis,
   are now known to occur in the coast of Baja California: Cyclaspis nubila
   Zimmer, 1936, C. concepcionensis Donath-Hernandez, 1988 and C.
   bituberculata Donath-Hernandez, 1988.
C1 Donath-Hernandez, Francisco E.; 1115 Euclid Av,Apt 11, Miami Beach, FL,

DT Article
TI Two new free-living marine nematode species of the genus Vasostoma
   (Comesomatidae) from the China Sea.
AU Huang, Yong (huangy@lcu.edu.cn) 
   Wu, Xiuqin
SO Cahiers de Biologie Marine
VL 52
IS 2
PS 147-155
PD 2011
PY 2011
LA English
U1 0
U2 4
AB Two new species of free-living marine nematodes Vasostoma brevispicula
   sp. nov. from the Yellow Sea and Vasostoma longicaudata sp. :nov. from
   the South China Sea are described. Vasostoma brevispicula sp. nov. is
   characterized by its thin and long body, amphideal fovea with two and a
   half turns, tubular buccal cavity with three small tooth-like
   projections, long pyriform pharyngeal bulb, curved spicules with central
   lamella. Vasostoma longicaudata sp., nov. is characterized by its long
   filiform portion of tail and without terminal setae, long tubular buccal
   cavity with three teeth, curved spicules with ventral alae.
C1 Huang, Yong; Liaocheng Univ, Sch Life Sci, 1 Hunan Rd, Liaocheng, China,
   China.
EM huangy@lcu.edu.cn
SC Zoology
SN 0007-9723
BD Systematics; Nomenclature; New taxa; Taxonomy; Key; Marine zones;
   Pacific Ocean
DE Vasostoma brevispicula; Vasostoma longicaudata [North Pacific /  / New
   species]. 
TN Invertebrates; Nematodes
ST Animalia, Nematoda
OR Vasostoma - Wieser 1954 (Nematoda): [Key to species, P. 154]. 
   Vasostoma brevispicula (Nematoda): [Sp nov, North Pacific, P. 148]. 
   Vasostoma longicaudata (Nematoda): [Sp nov, North Pacific, P. 151].

LA English
U1 0
U2 4
AB During the expedition Me48/1 DIVA 1 in the Abyssal Angola Basin, a small
   collection of Solenogastres was collected. In this article, a new genus
   and two new species, Lophometria dorsocaeca sp. nov. and Abyssoherpia
   ctenata gen et sp. nov., collected at depths of 5390-5415 m, which
   present some characters that complete the diagnoses of several
   suprageneric taxa, are described.

DT Article
TI [Contribution on the knowledge of the Histeridae of Morocco
   (Coleoptera).]
FT Contribution a la connaissance des Histeridae du Maroc (Coleoptera).
AU Gomy, Yves (halacritus@neuf.fr) 
   Labrique, Harold
   Chavanon, Guy
   Janati Idrissi, Abdellatif
   Francois, Alexandre
SO Cahiers du Musee des Confluences Etudes Scientifiques
VL 2
PS 23-74
PD 2011
PY 2011
LA French
U1 0
U2 0
AB The study of more than 4000 specimens of Histeridae resulting mainly
   from sampling realized during the entomological missions of the Musee
   des Confluences (Lyon) to Morocco (from 2001 till 2011) and of those
   made by the ECWP at Tamlelt (Bouarfa) in 2008, allows to complete the
   local geographical distribution of 101 species of this family. Twenty
   four species are new for Morocco. Pholioxenus chavanoni Gomy sp. nov. is
   described. A new Eretmotus is also described but not named looking
   forward to a new revision of the genus.The phenology of the species
   collected in the Tamlelt's plain is specified.
C1 Gomy, Yves; 2 boulevard Victor Hugo, 58000 Nevers, France, France.
EM halacritus@neuf.fr
SC Zoology; Environmental Sciences &Ecology
SN 2114-978X; 2110-560X

TI [The Phylan Dejean, 1821 of the subgenus Meladeras Mulsant et Rey, 1854
   (Coleoptera; Tenebrionidae; Pedinini; Dendarina) in Morocco.]
FT Les Phylan Dejean, 1821 du sousgenre Meladeras Mulsant et Rey, 1854
   (Coleoptera; Tenebrionidae; Pedinini; Dendarina) au Maroc.
AU Labrique, Harold (harold.labrique@rhone.fr) 
   Chavanon, Guy
   Janati-Idrissi, Abdellatif
SO Cahiers du Musee des Confluences Etudes Scientifiques
VL 2
PS 75-82
PD 2011
PY 2011
LA French
U1 0
U2 0
AB The Moroccan Phylan belonging to the subgenus Meladeras Mulsant et Rey,
   1854 are revised. Phylan (Meladeras) marocanus Obenberger, 1914 is
   reinstated as a valid species, Phylan (Meladeras) ferreri sp. n. is
   described and Phylan (Meladeras) barbarus (Lucas, 1846) is excluded of
   Moroccan fauna. A key to the three Moroccan species is provided.

   d&apos;Etude des Collections, 13A rue Bancel, F-69007 Lyon, France,

PS 1-7

   maculatus DeGeer, 1774 is first herein recorded from the Bahamas.

PT J
AN ZOOR14706047258
DT Article
TI A new species of Sorbinichthys (Teleostei: Clupeomorpha:
   Ellimmichthyiformes) from the Late Cretaceous of Morocco.
AU Murray, Alison M. (ammurray@ualberta.ca) 
   Wilson, Mark V.H.
SO Canadian Journal of Earth Sciences
VL 48
IS 1
PS 1-9
PD January 2011
PY 2011
LA English
U1 0
U2 9
AB A new species of ellimmichthyiform fish, represented by three specimens,
   has been recovered from deposits of the Akrabou Formation of Morocco.
   The new species is described in the existing genus Sorbinichthys, family
   Sorbinichthyidae, as Sorbinichthys africanus, sp. nov., closely related
   to the type species Sorbinichthys elusivo. The Ellimmichthyiformes is an
   extinct order of clupeomorph fishes that includes both freshwater and
   marine species ranging from the Early Cretaceous through the Eocene.
   Sorbinichthys elusivo is known from Cenomanian deposits of the eastern
   Mediterranean Tethys (Lebanon), whereas the new species is possibly
   early Turonian but more probably late Cenomanian in age, from the
   western Tethys (eastern Morocco). At lower taxonomic levels, the
   assemblage from the Akrabou Formation has a primarily Tethyan
   composition, exemplified by the genus Sorbinichthys, whereas
   supra-generic taxa found there include groups with trans-Atlantic (e.g.,
   Sorbinichthyidae, Macrosemiidae) or near-cosmopolitan (e.g.,
   Paraclupeidae) distributions.
C1 Murray, Alison M.; Department of Biological Sciences, University fo
   Alberta, Edmonton, AB T6G 2E9, Canada, Canada.
EM ammurray@ualberta.ca
RI Murray, Alison M./L-5242-2013
OI Murray, Alison M./0000-0001-9648-2902
SC Zoology
SN 0008-4077

PT J
AN ZOOR14706047259
DT Article
TI An istiodactylid pterosaur from the Upper Cretaceous Nanaimo Group,
   Hornby Island, British Columbia, Canada.
AU Arbour, Victoria M. (arbour@ualberta.ca) 
   Currie, Philip J.
SO Canadian Journal of Earth Sciences
VL 48
IS 1
PS 63-69
PD January 2011
PY 2011
LA English
U1 1
U2 9
AB An unusual jaw found in a calcite nodule from Collishaw Point, Hornby
   Island, British Columbia (off the east coast of Vancouver Island)
   represents the first definitive pterosaur found in British Columbia, and
   the first istiodactylid from Canada. The nodule was derived from the
   Northumberland Formation (Nanaimo Group), a fossiliferous formation
   known for producing numerous plants, invertebrates, sharks, and
   mosasaurs. The pterosaur is represented by the anterior portion of the
   rostrum, including the anterior edge of the nasoantorbital fenestra, and
   numerous small, triangular teeth lacking denticles. These teeth are
   similar in overall morphology to the teeth of istiodactylids, but are
   smaller, more numerous, more tightly packed, and have proportionately
   smaller crowns. Although fragmentary, this specimen is diagnostic and
   rep-resents a new genus of istiodactylid pterosaur. Its presence in the
   upper Campanian Northumberland Formation makes this the latest occurring
   istiodactylid and extends the stratigraphic and geographic range of this
   enigmatic group of pterosaurs.
C1 Arbour, Victoria M.; Department of Biological Sciences, University of
   Alberta, Edmonton, AB T6G 2E9, Canada, Canada.
EM arbour@ualberta.ca
RI Currie, Philip J/A-2628-2014
OI Currie, Philip J/0000-0001-6857-3161
SC Zoology
SN 0008-4077
BD Systematics; Nomenclature; New taxa; Land zones; Nearctic region; North
   America; Canada; Geological time periods; Mesozoic
DE Gwawinapterus [Cretaceous /  / New genus]. 
   Gwawinapterus beardi [British Columbia /  / new species] [Cretaceous / 
   / ]. 
   Istiodactylidae [Canada /  / new record] [Cretaceous / Upper Cretaceous
   / ]. 
TN Chordates; Reptiles; Vertebrates
ST Animalia, Chordata, Vertebrata, Reptilia, Archosauria, Pterosauria,
   Pterodactyloidea
OR Gwawinapterus (Pterodactyloidea): [Gen nov, Of family Istiodactylidae,
   Type species Gwawinapterus beardi, p. 64, Cretaceous; Fossil]. 
   Gwawinapterus beardi (Pterodactyloidea): [Sp nov, British Columbia,
   Cretaceous, P. 64; Fossil]. 
   Istiodactylidae (Pterodactyloidea): [Fossil; New record]. 
DI 10.1139/E10-083
UT ZOOREC:ZOOR14706047259

DT Article
TI Xenobrochus norfolkensis (Brachiopoda: Dyscoliidae), a new species from
   the Norfolk Ridge, New Caledonia, South-West Pacific.
AU Bitner, Maria Aleksandra (bitner@twarda.pan.pl) 
SO Carnets de Geologie
SU Article 5
PS 203-211
PD 2011
PY 2011
UR http://paleopolis.rediris.es/cg/CG2011_A05/CG2011_A05.pdf
AW http://paleopolis.rediris.es/cg/CG2011_A05/CG2011_A05.pdf
LA English
U1 0
U2 0
AB The genus Xenobrochus, with the type species Gryphus africanus COOPER,
   1973, was erected for short-looped brachiopods of small size,
   rectimarginate and having a loop with anteriorly convex transverse band.
   A new species of Xenobrochus, X. norfolkensis sp. nov. has been
   identified in the material collected during the French cruises SMIB 8,
   NORFOLK 1 and NORFOLK 2 to the Norfolk Ridge, New Caledonia, SW Pacific.
   This species differs from those hitherto described in the absence of
   cardinal process and relatively wide outer hinge plates. The genus,
   represented now by nine species, has a distribution restricted to the
   Indian Ocean and West Pacific.
C1 Bitner, Maria Aleksandra; Institute of Paleobiology, ul. Twarda 51/55,
   PL-00-818 Warszawa, Poland, Poland.
EM bitner@twarda.pan.pl
SC Zoology
SN 1634-0744
BD Systematics; Nomenclature; New taxa; Marine zones; Pacific Ocean
DE Xenobrochus norfolkensis [South Pacific / New Caledonia / New species]. 
TN Brachiopods; Invertebrates
ST Animalia, Brachiopoda
OR Xenobrochus norfolkensis (Brachiopoda): [Sp nov, New Caledonia (marine),
   P. 204]. 
UT ZOOREC:ZOOR14803022344
OA DOAJ Gold
DA 2020-09-17

DT Article
TI Fungus gnats (Diptera: Sciaroidea) of the Gemer region (Central
   Slovakia): Part 2-Mycetophilidae.
AU Sevcik, Jan (sevcikjan@hotmail.com) 
   Kurina, Olavi
SO Casopis Slezskeho Zemskeho Muzea Serie A Vedy Prirodni
VL 60
IS 2
PS 97-126
PD 2011
PY 2011
LA English
U1 0
U2 0
AB A total of 317 species of Mycetophilidae are recorded from the Gemer
   region in central Slovakia. The material was obtained mainly in the
   years 2008-2011 by means of Malaise traps and by individual collecting
   by the authors. A new species of Mycetophila Meigen, M. gemerensis sp.
   n., is described and additional 47 species are recorded as new to
   Slovakia. A new synonym is proposed: Mycetophila quadra Lundstrom, 1909
   = M chamberlini (Laffoon, 1957) syn. n.
C1 Sevcik, Jan; Univ Ostrava, Chittussiho 10, Ostrava, CZ-71000, Czech
   Republic, Czech Republic.
EM sevcikjan@hotmail.com
RI Kurina, Olavi/A-8106-2013
OI Kurina, Olavi/0000-0002-4858-4629
SC Zoology
SN 1211-3026

   region; Eurasia; Europe

   systematics; annotated faunal list].

DT Article
TI Parasites of some bonyfish species from the Boojagh wetland in the
   southwest shores of the Caspian Sea.
AU Khara, H. (h_khara1974@yahoo.com) 
   Sattari, M.
   Nezami, Sh.
   Mirhasheminasab, S.F.
   Mousavi, S.A.
   Ahmadnezhad, M.
SO Caspian Journal of Environmental Sciences
VL 9
IS 1
PS 47-53
PD 2011
PY 2011
LA English
U1 1
U2 3
AB The Boojagh international wetland with a surface area of 80 hectares and
   25 fish species is located in the southwest shores of the Caspian Sea
   (Guilan province, Iran), but there is no report about fish parasites in
   this wetland. In the present study, a total of 553 individuals of 8 fish
   species including Cyprinus carpio (n=71), Abramis bjoerkna (n=153),
   Carassius auratus gibelio (n=89), Esox lucius (n=39), Rutilus rutilus
   caspius (n=36), Rutilus frisii kutum (n=81), Scardinius erythrophthalmus
   (n=119) and Tinca tinca (n=4), were collected in October 2001 through
   November 2003. Eight parasite species were identified in the fishes
   consisting of 1 nematode: Raphidascaris acus (in E. lucius and S.
   erythrophthalmus); 1 cestode: Caryophyllaeus fimbriceps (in R. rutilus
   caspius and C. carpio); 2 digenean trematodes: Asymphylodora tincae (in
   T. tinca) and Diplostomum spathaceum (in all of the fish species except
   for T. tinca and S. erythrophthalmus); 2 monogenean trematodes:
   Tetraonchus monenteron (in E. lucius) and Dactylogyrus sp. (in C.
   carpio, A. bjoerkna and C. auratus gibelio); 1 crustacean: Lernaea
   cyprinacea (in A. bjoerkna, T. tinca and R. rutilus caspius) and 1 leech
   : Piscicola sp. (in R. rutilus caspius and C. carpio). The occurrence of
   R. acus in S. erythrophthalmus and also that of C. fimbriceps in R.
   rutilus caspius are reported for the first time as new host records.
C1 Khara, H.; Dept. of Fisheries and Aquaculture, Faculty of Natural
   Resources, Islamic Azad University- Lahijan Branch, Lahijan, Iran, Iran.
EM h_khara1974@yahoo.com
SC Parasitology; Zoology

   Land zones; Palaearctic region; Eurasia

   record] [Caspian Sea / Iran, Guilan, Boojagh wetland / ]. 
   Cestoda; Crustacea; Digenea; Hirudinea; Monogenea; Nematoda [Piscean
   hosts / Osteichthyes / Prevalence] [Caspian Sea / Iran, Guilan, Boojagh
   wetland / ].

   [Monogenean parasites /  / ] [Nematode parasites /  / ] [Caspian Sea /

   New record] [Caspian Sea / Iran, Guilan, Boojagh wetland / ]. 
   Scardinius erythrophthalmus [Nematode parasites / Raphidascaris acus /
   New record] [Caspian Sea / Iran, Guilan, Boojagh wetland / ].

PT J
AN ZOOR14804027347
DT Article
TI New species and new records of Deliphrosoma Reitter, 1909 (Coleoptera:
   Staphylinidae: Omaliinae) from Iran with note on the taxonomic status of
   Geodromicus libanicus Coiffait, 1985.
AU Shavrin, A.V. (ashavrin@hotmail.com) 
SO Caucasian Entomological Bulletin
VL 7
IS 1
PS 35-37
PD 2011
PY 2011
LA English
U1 0
U2 0
AB Deliphrosoma frischi sp. n. from Esfahan province of Iran is described
   and illustrated. New records of D. bakhtiyariense Zerche, 1991, for
   Esfahan province and D. morvani (Jarrige, 1971) for Alborz province are
   provided. One new synonymy is established: D. libanicum (Fauvel, 1875) =
   Geodromicus libanicus Coifait, 1985 syn. n.
C1 Shavrin, A.V.; Institute of Systematic Biology, Daugavpils University,
   Vienebas 13, Daugavpils LV-5401, Latvia, Latvia.
EM ashavrin@hotmail.com
SC Zoology
SN 1814-3326
BD Systematics; Nomenclature; New taxa; Synonymy; Land zones; Palaearctic
   region; Eurasia; Asia
DE Deliphrosoma [Iran /  / New record; systematics]. 
   Deliphrosoma bakhtiyariense [Iran / Esfahan Province / New record]. 
   Deliphrosoma frischi [Iran /  / New species]. 
   Deliphrosoma morvai [Iran / Alborz Province / New record]. 
TN Arthropods; Beetles; Insects; Invertebrates
ST Animalia, Arthropoda, Insecta, Coleoptera, Polyphaga, Staphylinoidea,
   Staphylinidae
OR Deliphrosoma - Reitter 1909 (Staphylinidae): [New record]. 
   Deliphrosoma bakhtiyariense (Staphylinidae): [New record]. 
   Deliphrosoma frischi (Staphylinidae): [Sp nov, Iran, P. 35]. 
   Deliphrosoma libanicum - (Fauvel 1875) (Staphylinidae): [Syn nov,
   Geodromicus libanicus Coiffait 1985, p. 36]. 
   Deliphrosoma morvai (Staphylinidae): [New record].

DT Article
TI Two new species of the genus Entomogonus Solier, 1848 (Coleoptera:
   Tenebrionidae) from Turkey.
AU Nabozhenko, M.V. (nalassus@mail.ru) 
   Tichy, V.
SO Caucasian Entomological Bulletin
VL 7
IS 1
PS 45-49
PD 2011
PY 2011
LA English
U1 0
U2 0
AB Two new species of the genus Entomogonus Solier, 1848 are described from
   Eastern Turkey (provinces Malatya and Adiyaman): E. bialookii sp. n. and
   E. makovskyi sp. n. Both species included in the subgenus Delonurops
   Reitter, 1922 and close to E. egregius (Seidlitz, 1896) and E.
   clavimanus Reitter, 1922.
C1 Nabozhenko, M.V.; Southern Scientific Centre, Russian Academy of
   Sciences, Chekhov str., 41, Rostov-on-Don 344000, Russia, Russia.
EM nalassus@mail.ru
OI Nabozhenko, Maxim/0000-0001-7914-7942
SC Zoology
SN 1814-3326
BD Systematics; Nomenclature; New taxa; Land zones; Palaearctic region;
   Eurasia
DE Entomogonus (Delonurops) bialookii; Entomogonus (Delonurops) makovskyi
   [Turkey /  / New species]. 
TN Arthropods; Beetles; Insects; Invertebrates
ST Animalia, Arthropoda, Insecta, Coleoptera, Polyphaga, Tenebrionoidea,
   Tenebrionidae
OR Entomogonus (Delonurops) bialookii (Tenebrionidae): [Sp nov, Turkey, P.
   45]. 
   Entomogonus (Delonurops) makovskyi (Tenebrionidae): [Sp nov, Turkey, P.
   48].

DT Article
TI A new species of the longicorn beetles genus Cortodera Mulsant, 1863
   (Coleoptera: Cerambycidae) from the Southern Transcaucasia.
AU Miroshnikov, A.I. (miroshnikov-ai@yandex.ru) 
SO Caucasian Entomological Bulletin
VL 7
IS 1
PS 53-54
PD 2011
PY 2011
LA Russian
U1 0
U2 0
AB A new species Cortodera tatianae Miroshnikov, sp. n. from the Southern
   Transcaucasia is described. It resembles C. transcaspica Plavilstshikov,
   1936, from which well difers by oblique temples with smoothed sculpture,
   shape (not pelecoid) of ultimate segment of labial palpi, shorter
   antennae, reaching middle of elytra only, less rough and less dense
   puncturation of elytra, and other characters.
C1 Miroshnikov, A.I.; Russian Entomological Society, (Kuban Branch),
   Krasnodar, Russia, Russia.
EM miroshnikov-ai@yandex.ru
SC Zoology
SN 1814-3326
BD Systematics; Nomenclature; New taxa; Land zones; Palaearctic region;
   Eurasia; Asia
DE Cortodera tatianae [Azerbaijan /  / New species]. 
TN Arthropods; Beetles; Insects; Invertebrates
ST Animalia, Arthropoda, Insecta, Coleoptera, Polyphaga, Chrysomeloidea,
   Cerambycidae
OR Cortodera tatianae (Cerambycidae): [Sp nov, Azerbaijan, P. 53]. 
UT ZOOREC:ZOOR14804027359

TI New species of genera Brachycerus Billberg, 1820 (Coleoptera:
   Brachyceridae) from Syria.
AU Arzanov, Ju.G. (arz99@mail.ru) 
SO Caucasian Entomological Bulletin
VL 7
IS 1
PS 57-59
PD 2011
PY 2011
LA Russian
U1 0
U2 0
AB A new species Brachycerus skoupyi sp. n. is described he new species has
   postocular lobes on lateral margin of pronotum, as well as B.
   foveicollis Gyllenhal, 1833, but difers from it by the form and
   sculpture of pronotum and dorsal part of elytra.

   Rostov-on-Don, Russia, Russia.

DT Article
TI The review of species of group Dolichopus salictorum Loew, 1871
   (Dolichopodidae: Diptera).
AU Maslova, O.O.
   Negrobov, O.P. (negrobov@list.ru) 
   Selivanova, O.V.
SO Caucasian Entomological Bulletin
VL 7
IS 1
PS 103-108
PD 2011
PY 2011
LA Russian
U1 0
U2 0
AB Two new species Dolichopus zakhvatkini sp. n. from Azerbaijan and
   Dolichopus naglisi sp. n. from Tajikistan are described. The type
   specimens Dolichopus salictorum Loew, 1871 is redescribed, including a
   study of morphology of the hypopygium. Dolichopus salictorum for
   Ukraine, Dolichopus violovitshi for Sakhalin are recorded for the irst
   time. A key to group of species of Dolichopus salictorum is made.
C1 Negrobov, O.P.; Voronezh State University, Universitetskaya sq., 1,
   Voronezh 394006, Russia, Russia.
EM negrobov@list.ru
SC Zoology
SN 1814-3326
BD Systematics; Nomenclature; New taxa; Description; Taxonomy; Key; Land
   zones; Palaearctic region; Eurasia; Asia; Europe
DE Dolichopus naglisi [Tajikistan /  / New species]. 
   Dolichopus salictorum [Ukraine /  / New record]. 
   Dolichopus violovitshi [Russia / Sakhalin Island / New record]. 
   Dolichopus zakhvatkini [Azerbaijan /  / New species]. 
TN Arthropods; Insects; Invertebrates; True Flies
ST Animalia, Arthropoda, Insecta, Diptera, Brachycera, Orthorrhapha,
   Dolichopodidae
OR Dolichopus naglisi - Maslova, Selivanova & Negrobov 2011
   (Dolichopodidae): [Sp nov, Tajikistan, P. 106]. 
   Dolichopus salictorum - Loew 1871 (Dolichopodidae): [Redescription, P.
   103; New record]. 
   Dolichopus salictorum species group (Dolichopodidae): [Systematics, P.
   103; Key to species, P. 107]. 
   Dolichopus violovitshi (Dolichopodidae): [New record]. 
   Dolichopus zakhvatkini - Maslova, Selivanova & Negrobov 2011
   (Dolichopodidae): [Sp nov, Azerbaijan, P. 106].

PT J
AN ZOOR14804027466
DT Article
TI A new species of the dance-fly subgenus Xanthempis Bezzi, 1909 of the
   genus Empis Linnaeus, 1758 (Diptera: Empididae) from the Caucasus.
AU Kustov, S.Yu. (semenkustov@rambler.ru) 
SO Caucasian Entomological Bulletin
VL 7
IS 1
PS 109-111
PD 2011
PY 2011
LA Russian
U1 0
U2 0
AB This paper describes one new species Empis shamshevi sp. n. of the
   subgenus Xanthempis Bezzi, 1909 taken from the Caucasian region of
   Russia (Krasnodar province). Diagnosis. Occiput is almost completely
   dark, scutum almost entirely black, prescutellar deepening is yellow,
   scutellum from the front is black while the edges are yellow,
   postsutural supra-alar bristle is presented. Male: epandrial lamella
   with long hair-like yellow setae, cercus with a plunging neckline,
   phallus medium length, relatively thick, arcuately curved, with a long
   coracoid apex. he changes of key to the Caucasian Xanthempis species
   [Shamshev, Kustov, 2008] are given. Empis shamshevi sp. n. is most
   similar to E. testacea Fabricius, 1805 and E. adriani Chvala, 1996 but
   it difers from them by almost entirely fused black vittae on the
   mesonotum, which are slightly separated on its posterior part, and also
   by the shape of sclerites of male terminalia. In male terminalia the new
   species resembles ?. zinovjevae Shamshev, 1998, however, this species
   has single median vitta on the scutum.
C1 Kustov, S.Yu.; Kuban State University, Biological Faculty (Zoology
   department), Stavropolskaya str., 149, Krasnodar, 350040, Russia,
   Russia.
EM semenkustov@rambler.ru
SC Zoology
SN 1814-3326
BD Systematics; Nomenclature; New taxa; Taxonomy; Key; Land zones;
   Palaearctic region; Eurasia
DE Empis (Xanthempis) [Eurasia / Caucasus / Key to species]. 
   Empis (Xanthempis) shamshevi [Russia /  / New species]. 
TN Arthropods; Insects; Invertebrates; True Flies
ST Animalia, Arthropoda, Insecta, Diptera, Brachycera, Orthorrhapha,
   Empididae
OR Empis (Xanthempis) - Bezzi 1909 (Empididae): [Key to species, Eurasia,
   Caucasus, Amended to include new species, p. 111]. 
   Empis (Xanthempis) shamshevi (Empididae): [Sp nov, Russia, P. 110]. 
UT ZOOREC:ZOOR14804027466
DA 2020-09-17
ER

DT Article
TI Harvestmen (Arachnida: Opiliones) from the yew and box-tree grove of the
   Caucasian State Natural Biospheric Reserve, Russia.
AU Snegovaya, N.Yu. (snegovaya@yahoo.com) 
   Chumachenko, Yu.A.
SO Caucasian Entomological Bulletin
VL 7
IS 2
PS 115-124
PD 2011
PY 2011
LA English
U1 0
U2 0
AB Faunistic and taxonomic data on the harvestmen from the yew and box-tree
   grove (Caucasian State Natural Biospheric Reserve, Russia) are
   presented. 16 harvestmen species from 5 families were found in this
   Reserve. Four new species (Calathocratus hirsutus Snegovaya, sp. n.,
   Calathocratus minutus Snegovaya, sp. n., Giljarovia kratochvili
   Snegovaya, sp. n., Caucnemastoma martensi Snegovaya, sp. n.) are
   described.
C1 Snegovaya, N.Yu.; Institute of Zoology NAS of Azerbaijan, passage 1128,
   district 504, Baku AZ1073, Azerbaijan, Azerbaijan.

   zones; Palaearctic region; Eurasia

   Giljarovia kratochvili [Russia /  / New species].

   Natural Biospheric Reserve / ]. 
TN Arachnids; Arthropods; Chelicerates; Invertebrates

TI New species of the genus Armenohelops Nabozhenko, 2002 (Coleoptera:
   Tenebrionidae: Helopini) from Turkey.
AU Nabozhenko, M.V. (nalassus@mail.ru) 
SO Caucasian Entomological Bulletin
VL 7
IS 2
PS 135-138
PD 2011
PY 2011
LA Russian
U1 0
U2 0
AB Two new species of the genus Armenohelops Nabozhenko, 2002 are described
   from Turkey: A. terminasianae sp. n. from south of Nigde province
   (Central Taurus Mountains) and A. kasatkini sp. n. from west of Erzincan
   province (Pontic Mountains system). Totally 4 species of Armenohelops
   are known, which are distributed from Northern Iran to Central Anatolia.

   RAS, Institute of Arid Zones RAS, Chekhov str., 41, Rostov-on-Don,

DT Article
TI A new species of the weevil genus Melanobaris Alonso-Zarazaga et Lyal,
   1999 (Coleoptera: Curculionidae: Baridinae) from Mt. Hermon in Israel
   and commentaries on the composition of the genera Melanobaris and
   Aulacobaris Desbrochers, 1892.
AU Korotyaev, B.A. (baris@zin.ru) 
   Friedman, A.L.L.
SO Caucasian Entomological Bulletin
VL 7
IS 2
PS 169-172
PD 2011
PY 2011
LA English
U1 0
U2 0
AB A new species of the weevil genus Melanobaris Alonso-Zarazaga et Lyal,
   1999 is described from Israel (Mt. Hermon). Melanobaris margaritae sp.
   n. is similar to M. amanicola (Pic, 1905), known from Turkey (? and
   Syria), in the habitus, but difers in the subparallel- sided and widely
   rounded at apex aedeagus, smaller and narrower body, iner, sparser and
   more even punctation of the pronotum leaving free median line, rounded
   punctures on the sides of the prothorax, deeply engraved at base and
   weakening toward apex elytral striae, and dark brown antennae and legs.
   15 species are transferred from the genus Baris Germar, 1817 to
   Melanobaris, and Melanobaris longicollis (Faust, 1890) is placed in
   Aulacobaris.
C1 Korotyaev, B.A.; Zoological Institute, Russian Academy of Sciences,
   Universitetskaya nab., 1, Saint Petersburg, 199034, Russia, Russia.
EM baris@zin.ru
SC Zoology
SN 1814-3326
BD Systematics; Nomenclature; New taxa; Combination; Taxonomy; Taxonomic
   position; Land zones; Palaearctic region; Eurasia; Asia
DE Melanobaris margaritae [Israel /  / New species]. 
TN Arthropods; Beetles; Insects; Invertebrates
ST Animalia, Arthropoda, Insecta, Coleoptera, Polyphaga, Curculionoidea,
   Curculionidae
OR Aulacobaris longicollis - (Faust 1890) (Curculionidae): [Comb nov,
   Transferred from Melanobaris, p. 170]. 
   Baris amanicola - Pic 1905 (Curculionidae): [Referred to, Melanobaris,
   p. 169].

   Melanobaris, p. 169].

   Melanobaris, p. 169].

   [Referred to, Melanobaris, p. 169].

   Melanobaris, p. 169]. 
   Baris edmundi - Korotyaev 1988 (Curculionidae): [Referred to,
   Melanobaris, p. 169].

   Melanobaris, p. 169].

DT Article
TI A new species of the weevil genus Melanobaris Alonso-Zarazaga et Lyal,
   1999 (Coleoptera: Curculionidae: Baridinae) from Inner Daghestan.
AU Korotyaev, B.A. (baris@zin.ru) 
   Ismailova, M.Sh.
SO Caucasian Entomological Bulletin
VL 7
IS 2
PS 173-175
PD 2011
PY 2011
LA Russian
U1 0
U2 0
AB A new species Melanobaris gulnarae sp. n. is described from Inner
   Daghestan, closely related to M. margaritae Korotyaev et Friedman from
   Mt. Hermon in Israel described in this volume, but difering in the
   larger body, coarser sculpture of the pronotum and elytra but somewhat
   iner punctures on metasternum, matt dorsal surface, broader tarsi, and
   more tapering apically aedeagus.

   Universitetskaya nab., 1, St. Petersburg, 199034, Russia, Russia.

DT Article
TI Four new species of Palaearctic Ceutorhynchinae, with a key to species
   of Datonychus Wagner, 1944 (Coleoptera: Curculionidae).
AU Colonnelli, E. (ecolonnelli@yahoo.it) 
SO Caucasian Entomological Bulletin
VL 7
IS 2
PS 191-195
PD 2011
PY 2011
LA English
U1 0
U2 0
AB Four new species of Palaearctic Ceutorhynchinae are described:
   hamiocolus ruitarsis sp. n. from Iran close to T. comptus Colonnelli,
   1997 from Southern Turkey; Datonychus terminassianae sp. n. from
   Northern China and Datonychus kostali sp. n. from Iran both rather
   isolated among their genus, and Datonychus gultekini sp. n. from
   Northeastern Turkey quite close to D. scabrirostris (Hochhuth, 1847)
   from Eastern Europe and the Caucasus. A key to the 22 species of
   Datonychus Wagner, 1944 described to date is included.
C1 Colonnelli, E.; Via delle Giunchiglie 56, Rome, Italy, Italy.

TI Species of the genus Telmaturgus Mik, 1874 (Diptera: Dolichopodidae).
AU Grichanov, I.Ya. (grichanov@mail.ru) 
SO Caucasian Entomological Bulletin
VL 7
IS 2
PS 229-232
PD 2011
PY 2011
LA English
U1 0
U2 0
AB The genus Telmaturgus Mik is reviewed It comprises eighteen species
   including a new species Telmaturgus congensis sp. n. from DR Congo. A
   check lis of species of this genus and a revised key to Afrotropica
   species are provided. he following new combinations are proposed:
   Lamprochromus belousovi (Grichanov, 2008) comb. n. (from Sympycnus),
   Telmaturgus abidjanensis (Grichanov, 2008), comb. n., T. garambaensis
   (Grichanov 2008), comb. n., T. kenyensis (Grichanov, 2008), comb n., T.
   kovali (Grichanov, 2008), comb. n., T. kwandensis (Grichanov, 2008),
   comb. n., T. mastigomyoformis (Grichanov, 2008), comb. n., T. munroi
   (Curran, 1925) comb. n., T. pseudoviolaceus (Grichanov, 2008), comb n.,
   T. triseta (Grichanov, 2008), comb. n., T. uzungwa (Grichanov, 2008),
   comb. n. (all from Sympycnus).

PT J
AN ZOOR14803026347
DT Article
TI The review of dance-flies subgenus Leptempis Collin, 1926 of the genus
   Empis Linnaeus, 1758 (Diptera: Empididae) from the Caucasus with
   description of three new species.
AU Kustov, S.Yu. (semenkustov@rambler.ru) 
   Shamshev, I.V.
SO Caucasian Entomological Bulletin
VL 7
IS 2
PS 241-251
PD 2011
PY 2011
LA Russian
U1 0
U2 0
AB Currently the subgenus Leptempis Collin, 1926 of the genus Empis
   Linnaeus, 1758 includes 10 species known from the Caucasus, including 3
   new species described in this paper: E. (L.) nagalevskii sp. n. (Russia,
   Krasnodar region; Abkhazia); E. (L.) tatyanae sp. n. (Russia, Krasnodar
   region; Azerbaijan); E. (L.) euxinus sp. n. (Russia, Krasnodar region;
   Abkhazia; Turkey). he lectotype of E. (L.) apicalis Loew, 1865 is
   designated. A female of E. (L.) yaroshenkoi Shamshev et Kustov, 2007 is
   described for the irst time. Additional data on distribution of known
   species of the subgenus Leptempis are given as well as cases of
   morphological variability. Empis (L.) confusa Loew, 1865 is recorded for
   the irst time from the territory of Russia. Key species of the subgenus
   Leptempis from the Caucasus is provided for the first time.
C1 Kustov, S.Yu.; Kuban State University, Biological Faculty (Zoology
   department), Stavropolskaya str., 149, Krasnodar, 350040, Russia,
   Russia.
EM semenkustov@rambler.ru
SC Zoology
SN 1814-3326
BD Systematics; Nomenclature; New taxa; Type material; Description;
   Taxonomy; Key; Land zones; Palaearctic region; Eurasia; Asia
DE Empis (Leptempis) [Eurasia / Caucasus / Key to species]. 
   Empis (Leptempis) confusa [Russia /  / New record]. 
   Empis (Leptempis) euxinus [Russia /  / New species] [Turkey /  / ]
   [Georgia-Asia /  / ]. 
   Empis (Leptempis) nagalevskii [Russia /  / New species] [Georgia-Asia / 
   / ]. 
   Empis (Leptempis) tatyanae [Russia /  / New species] [Azerbaijan /  / ].
   
TN Arthropods; Insects; Invertebrates; True Flies
ST Animalia, Arthropoda, Insecta, Diptera, Brachycera, Orthorrhapha,
   Empididae
OR Empis (Leptempis) - Collin 1926 (Empididae): [Key to species, Eurasia,
   Caucasus, P. 242]. 
   Empis (Leptempis) apicalis - Loew 1865 (Empididae): [Lectotype
   designated, P. 243]. 
   Empis (Leptempis) confusa (Empididae): [New record]. 
   Empis (Leptempis) euxinus (Empididae): [Sp nov, Russia, P. 244]. 
   Empis (Leptempis) nagalevskii (Empididae): [Sp nov, Russia, P. 247].

PT J
AN ZOOR14802016521
DT Article
TI Butterfly (Lepidoptera: Rhopalocera) Fauna of East Calcutta Wetlands,
   West Bengal, India.
AU Chowdhury, Soumyajit (wildlifesc@gmail.com) 
   Soren, Rahi
SO Check List
VL 7
IS 6
PS 700-703
PD 2011
PY 2011
UR http://www.checklist.org.br/archive?vol=7&amp;num=6
AW http://www.checklist.org.br/getpdf?SL041-10
LA English
U1 0
U2 0
AB East Calcutta Wetlands (ECW), lying east of the city of Kolkata
   (formerly Calcutta), West Bengal in India, demonstrates the usage of
   city sewage for traditional practices of fisheries and agriculture. As a
   Ramsar Site, the wetland demands exploration of its bioresources for
   better understanding and management of the ecosystem operating therein.
   Butterflies (Lepidoptera: Rhopalocera) being potent pollinators and
   ecological indicators, are examined in the present study. The diversity
   study, conducted for two consecutive years (Jan. 2007-Nov. 2009) in all
   the three seasons (pre-monsoon, monsoon and post-monsoon), revealed
   seventy-four species. As butterflies depend on preferred host and nectar
   plants during their larval and adult stages respectively, the lack of
   these sources in some parts of ECW indicate degraded habitats with low
   species richness. Ongoing unplanned anthropogenic activities like
   habitat modifications (conversion of wetlands to agricultural lands) are
   resulting in the los of wetland biodiversity and hence ecosystem
   integrity in ECW.
C1 Chowdhury, Soumyajit; School of Oceanographic Studies, Jadavpur
   University, Kolkata - 700 032, West Bengal, India, India.
EM wildlifesc@gmail.com
SC Zoology
SN 1809-127X
BD Documentation; Publications; Land zones; Oriental region; Eurasia; Asia;
   India
DE Rhopalocera [Checklists /  / ] [West Bengal / East Calcutta Wetlands /
   ]. 
TN Arthropods; Insects; Invertebrates; Lepidopterans
ST Animalia, Arthropoda, Insecta, Lepidoptera, Glossata, Heteroneura,
   Papilionoidea
OR Rhopalocera (Papilionoidea). 
UT ZOOREC:ZOOR14802016521
OA DOAJ Gold
DA 2020-09-17

AN ZOOR14708054987
DT Article
TI On a new species of Paragoneplax Castro (Crustacea: Decapoda:
   Goneplacidae), P. chenae sp. nov. from the South China Sea.
AU Jiang, Wei
   Liu, Ruiyu (jyliu@qdio.ac.cn) 
SO Chinese Journal of Oceanology and Limnology
VL 29
IS 1
PS 213-216
PD January 2011
PY 2011
LA English
U1 0
U2 3
AB A new species of goneplacid crab, Paragoneplax chenae, is described,
   based on collections from the Nansha Islands, South China Sea. P. chenae
   closely resembles its only congener P. serenei (Zarenkov, 1972) in
   general appearance. They are distinguishable from each other by the male
   abdominal and gonopodal characters.
C1 Liu, Ruiyu; Chinese Acad Sci, Inst Oceanol, Qingdao 266071, China,
   China.
EM jyliu@qdio.ac.cn
SC Zoology
SN 0254-4059

   Decapoda, Reptantia, Brachyura
OR Paragoneplax chenae (Brachyura): [Sp nov, Spratly Islands (marine), P.
   214].

TI Eranno carrerai sp. nov., a new polychaete worm (Lumbrineridae) from
   coastal waters of China.
AU Cai, Wenqian
   Li, Xinzheng (lixzh@qdio.ac.cn) 
SO Chinese Journal of Oceanology and Limnology
VL 29
IS 1
PS 217-231
PD January 2011
PY 2011
LA English
U1 0
U2 4
AB In this paper, a new polychaete species, Eranno carrerai sp. nov. from
   coastal areas of China, is described based on specimens deposited in the
   Marine Biological Museum of the Chinese Academy of Sciences, Qingdao,
   collected during 1957 to 1976 from the Yellow Sea, East China Sea and
   South China Sea at depths of 9-210 m.

   China, China.

PT J
AN ZOOR14804029146
DT Article
TI A revision of the New Zealand endemic rove beetle genus Agnosthaetus
   Bernhauer (Coleoptera: Staphylinidae).
AU Clarke, Dave J. (dclarke@fieldmuseum.org) 
SO Coleopterists Society Monographs Patricia Vaurie Series
VL 10
PS 1-118
PD 2011
PY 2011
NT Supplement to Coleopterists Bulletin 65(4).
LA English
U1 0
U2 0
AB The New Zealand endemic rove beetle genus Agnosthaetus Bernhauer, 1939
   is revised. Thirty-four species are recognized and the following 28 new
   species are described: Agnosthaetus chinsma Clarke, Agnosthaetus rodmani
   Clarke, Agnosthaetus falx Clarke, Agnosthaetus stenomastax Clarke,
   Agnosthaetus hetemmastax Clarke, Agnosthaetus tumidus Clarke,
   Agnosthaetus aequalis Clarke, Agnosthaetus akatarawa Clarke,
   Agnosthaetus zonatus Clarke, Agnosthaetus bicolor Clarke, Agnosthaetus
   impressus Clarke, Agnosthaetus nitidus Clarke, Agnosthaetus leviceps
   Clarke, Agnosthaetus ecarinatus Clarke, Agnosthaetus imitator Clarke,
   Agnosthaetus aorangi Clarke, Agnosthaetus orongo Clarke, Agnosthaetus
   minutus Clarke, Agnosthaetus lanceolatus Clarke, Agnosthaetus kaikoura
   Clarke, Agnosthaetus thaverae Clarke, Agnosthaetus newtoni Clarke,
   Agnosthaetus truncatus Clarke, Agnosthaetus sculptus Clarke,
   Agnosthaetus nunni Clarke, Agnosthaetus carnelius Clarke, Agnosthaetus
   enigmus Clarke, and Agnosthaetus affinis Clarke. Agnosthaetus brounides
   Newton, new name, is proposed as a replacement name for the type species
   Agnosthaetus bmuni Bernhauer (junior secondary homonym), in light of T.
   Broun's apparently valid description of Agnosthaetus bmuni (Broun), new
   combination. Lectotypes are designated for Agnosthaetus cariniceps
   Bernhauer and A. brouni (Broun). Detailed and revised diagnoses and
   descriptions of both adults and presumed third instars are provided,
   including the first comprehensive larval description for the subfamily
   Euaesthetinae. According to the current suprageneric classification,
   Agnosthaetus is placed in the tribe Stenaesthetini based on the 5-5-4
   tarsal formula and an immarginate abdomen. The monophyly of the genus is
   yet to be tested, but all known species share the following apparently
   unique characters: 1) distinctly ovate or crescentic dorsal tentorial
   sulci; 2) glandular pit on adoral surface of labrum; 3) sclerotized
   labial spines; 4) posteriorly directed corporotentorial arms; 5)
   mesocoxal internal apophysis; and 6) a dorsal branch arising from the
   metendostemal arms. The species are comparatively rarely collected, but
   may be found in a broad range of habitats, mostly forest leaf litter,
   where they are most efficiently collected by sifting.
C1 Clarke, Dave J.; Zoology Department [long dash] Division of Insects,
   Field Museum of Natural History, 1400 S Lake Shore Drive, Chicago, IL
   60605, USA, USA.
EM dclarke@fieldmuseum.org
SC Zoology
SN 1934-0451
BD Systematics; Nomenclature; New taxa; Type material; Description;
   Combination; Synonymy; Available name; Taxonomy; Taxonomic position;
   Key; Land zones; Australasian region; Australasia
DE Agnosthaetus aequalis; Agnosthaetus affinis; Agnosthaetus akatarawa;
   Agnosthaetus aorangi; Agnosthaetus bicolor; Agnosthaetus carnelius;
   Agnosthaetus chiasma; Agnosthaetus ecarinatus; Agnosthaetus enigmus;
   Agnosthaetus falx; Agnosthaetus heteromastax; Agnosthaetus imitator;
   Agnosthaetus impressus; Agnosthaetus kaikoura; Agnosthaetus lanceolatus;
   Agnosthaetus leviceps; Agnosthaetus minutus; Agnosthaetus newtoni;
   Agnosthaetus nitidus; Agnosthaetus nunni; Agnosthaetus orongo;
   Agnosthaetus rodmani; Agnosthaetus sculptus; Agnosthaetus stenomastax;
   Agnosthaetus thayerae; Agnosthaetus truncatus; Agnosthaetus tumidus;
   Agnosthaetus zonatus [New Zealand /  / New species].

   Staphylinidae

DT Article
TI Seasonal occurrence of Pallisentis sp. (Acanthocephala) in a freshwater
   fish host, Channa punctatus Bl. from swampy areas of Darbhanga (Bihar).
AU Rashmi
   Piyusha
   Singh, Sapna
   Sinha, K.P. (Kedar.prasad.sinha@gmail.com) 
SO Columban Journal of Life Sciences
VL 12
IS 1-2
PS 57-59
PD 2011
PY 2011
LA English
U1 0
U2 0
AB The seasonal occurrence of Pallisentis sp (Acanthocephala) infection was
   studied in a fish host, Channa nctatus, from freshwater swamps near
   Darbhanga town (North Bihar) for a period of over a period of two
   i.e.May2008 june2010. Atotal of319 fish were examined and 139 fish found
   infected, and among em 118 were found carrying either singly(51.8%) or
   mixed(37.2%) infections with Pallisentis. As regards frequency
   distribution a maximum of 59 fish carried 1[long dash]3 worms, 44 with
   4[long dash]6 worms, 15 with 10[long dash]12, and "virtually none with
   >12 worms. A marked seasonal difference showing higher incidence during
   rainy months (July[long dash]Oct ) with peak i.e.60% in male and 47.61 %
   in female and lower(20.8[long dash]22.2%) during summer months, and that
   too a significant sex difference(F 26=25.65 25.65 at P>0.001).Lengthwise
   too, fish of I76[long dash]225mm showed higher incidence(r=+0.627)
   irrespective of sex of the host. Similarly, higher worm burden due to
   Pallisentis was found higher during Aug[long dash]Nov. with 3.5[long
   dash]5.5 and lowest of 1.2[long dash]2.7 during summer months but no
   marked sex difference, and however, significantly higher in the length
   group of 151[long dash]200 (F=5.72;P>0.001). As such, the present study
   shows a clear-cut close association between incidence and worm burden,
   and also between the level of infection and feeding habits of the fish
   host.
C1 Sinha, K.P.; Helminthology Laboratory, Dept. of Zoology, L.N.Mithila
   University, Darbhanga (Bihar) 846008, India, India.
EM Kedar.prasad.sinha@gmail.com

   &Ecology

   region; Eurasia; Asia; India

DT Article
TI A molecularly based phylogeny reconstruction of mushroom corals
   (Scleractinia: Fungiidae) with taxonomic consequences and evolutionary
   implications for life history traits.
AU Gittenberger, Arjan
   Reijnen, Bastian T.
   Hoeksema, Bert W. (bert.hoeksema@ncbnaturalis.nl) 
SO Contributions to Zoology
VL 80
IS 2
PS 107-132
PD 2011
PY 2011
LA English
U1 1
U2 34
AB The phylogenetic relationships of the Fungiidae, a family of
   predominantly free-living, zooxanthellate, reef corals, were studied by
   sequencing a part of the mitochondrial Cytochrome Oxidase I (COI) and
   the complete ribosomal Internal Transcribed Spacers (ITS) I & II of
   specimens from various locations in the Indo-West Pacific. Some
   sequences were retrieved by using fungiid-specific primers on
   DNA-extracts from parasitic gastropods living with these corals. The
   analyses were performed both including and excluding intraspecific
   variation to investigate the potential effect of saturation. Even though
   the present molecular phylogeny reconstructions largely reflect those
   based on morphological characters, there are some distinct differences.
   Three major clades are distinguished, one of which consists of species
   with relatively long tentacles. The two other major clades cannot yet be
   clearly separated from each other morphologically. Several polyphyletic
   taxa were detected and some genera and species that previously were
   considered closely related to each other, appear not to be so. Proposed
   nomenclatorial changes include amongst others the upgrading of subgenera
   in Fungia to genus level. A few species moved from one genus to another.
   Among all Fungiidae, the loss of the ability to become free-living
   appears to have evolved independently as reversals in four separate
   clades, including two that were previously assumed to be sister groups.
   The evolution of corals with additional (secondary) mouths leading to
   polystomatous growth forms from corals with only a single primary mouth
   (monostomatous growth form) appears to have occurred independently ten
   times: seven times by extrastomatal budding and three times by
   intrastomatal budding. In two clades, Herpolitha and Polyphyllia, both
   mechanisms co-evolved. In general there is no clear relationship between
   the loss of a free-living phase and the evolution of multiple mouths.
C1 Hoeksema, Bert W.; Netherlands Ctr Biodivers Naturalis, Dept Marine
   Zool, POB 9517, Leiden, Netherlands, Netherlands.
EM bert.hoeksema@ncbnaturalis.nl

TI The genus Bouryia Cossmann, 1888 (Gastropoda: Littorinimorpha:
   Pomatiopsidae ?) from the Thanetian sands (Paleocene) of the Paris
   Basin.
FT Le genre Bouryia Cossmann, 1888 (Gastropoda: Littorinimorpha:
   Pomatiopsidae ?) des sables thanetiens (Paleocene) du bassin de Paris.
AU Pacaud, Jean-Michel (pacaud@mnhn.fr) 
SO Cossmanniana
VL 13
PS 3-10
PD 2011
PY 2011
LA French
U1 0
U2 0
AB The fossil reprersentatives of the genus Bouryia were the subject of a
   recent study focussing on a with the Eocene species of the Paris Basin
   and the West of France. In continuation of that work I add further
   descriptions while expanding the scope of the study to include Thanetian
   (Paleocene) species. To that end, I deal with the two species already
   indicated to Thanetien Truncatella distensa COSSMANN, 1888 and T. minor
   BRIART & CORNET, 1887 as well as a species from the Danian of Mons
   (Belgium) T. cylindrata BRIART & CORNET, 1887, that I have collected in
   the Paris Basin from the Thanetian. A new species Bouryia roberti is
   described from the Thanetian.

DT Article
TI Redescription and new generic assignment of the Middle Eocene
   Rostellariidae Hippochrenes (Semiterebellum) rutoti Glibert, 1938
   (Mollusca, Gastropoda, Littorinimorpha).
FT Redescription et nouvelle assignation generique du Rostellaridae de
   l'Eocene moyen Hippochrenes (Semiterebellum) rutoti Glibert, 1938
   (Mollusca, Gastropoda, Littorinimorpha).
AU Pacaud, Jean-Michel (pacaud@mnhn.fr) 
   Merle, Didier
   Dudon, Patrick
SO Cossmanniana
VL 13
PS 11-19
PD 2011
PY 2011
LA French
U1 0
U2 1
AB We describe unpublished material of the poorly know Hippochrenes
   (Semiterebellum) rutoti GLIBERT, 1938 (Gastropodo: Littonrinimorpha:
   Rostellaridae) on the basis of several complete specimens, wich were
   collected in the Bartonien (Auversian, Eocene) of the Paris basin. It is
   the first time since this species was described in Belgium, that such
   specimens are collected in France. The study of the specimens, more
   complete and better preserved than the holotype, makes it possible to
   note that this species in fact belongs to the genus Amplogladius
   COSSMANN, 1889 (type-species : Rostellaria athleta D'ORBIGNY, 1850, by
   original designation). We here present a new description of this
   species. The specific contents and the stratigraphic distribution of
   this genus are briefly analyzed.
C1 Pacaud, Jean-Michel; Museum National d'Histoire Naturelle, UMR 7207 du
   CNRS, Centre de recherche sur la Paleobiodiversite et les
   Paleoenvironnements, Case postale 38, 57 rue Cuvier, F-75231 cedex 05,
   France, France.

TI A new species of Rostellaridae (Mollusca: Gastropoda: Littorinimorpha)
   for the Lutetian (Middle Eocene) of the Paris basin. Rediscovered of the

   Brogniart, 1793).
FT Une espece nouvelle Rostellaridae (Mollusca: Gastropoda:
   Littorinimorpha) dans le Lutetien (Eocene moyen) du bassin de Paris.
   Redecouverte Hippochrenes fissura (Coquebert de Montbret & Brogniart,
   1793).
AU Pacaud, Jean-Michel (pacaud@mnhn.fr) 
   Caze, Bruno
SO Cossmanniana
VL 13
PS 21-31
PD 2011
PY 2011
LA French
U1 0
U2 1
AB A new species, belonging to the genus Hippochrenes was recognized in the
   Middle Eocene (Lutetian) of the Paris basin. Hippochrenes boucheri nov.
   sp. has been confused up to now with Hippochrenes fissura (COCQUEBERT de
   MONTBRET & BROGNIART, 1793), the type material of which we have just
   rediscovered as well as the original manuscript of 1791, giving its
   description. This new species is discussed and compared with the
   Lutetien species, H. fissura and H. murchisoni (DESHAYES, 1865).

TI A new species of Digitolabrum (Gastropoda, Littorinimorpha,
   Rostellaridae) from the Middle Eocene of Aquitaine basin.
FT Une nouvelle espece de Digitolabrum (Gastropoda, Littorinimorpha,
   Rostellaridae) dans l'Eocene moyen du Bassin d'Aquitaine.
AU Pacaud, Jean-Michel (pacaud@mnhn.fr) 
   Ledon, Daniel
   Caze, Bruno
SO Cossmanniana
VL 13
PS 33-47
PD 2011
PY 2011
LA French
U1 0
U2 1
AB The method, consisting in the study of external prints of molluscs from
   silicon rubber casts, reveals and unexpected faunal diversity. A large
   species of the genus Digitolabrum has been recognized in the Bartonian
   limestones of Blaye (Gironde, France) bases on several well preserved
   external prints. It is the first species of this genus identified in the
   Eocene of the Aquitaine basin; it is also seventh species of this genus
   described from the Bartonian.

   France, France.

TI New species of gastropods (Mollusca: Gastopoda) from the Oligocene and
   Lower Miocene of Aquitaine (southwestern France). (Part 4).
FT Nouvelles especes de gasteropodes (Mollusca: Gastopoda) del'Oligocene et
   du Miocene inferieur d'Aquitaine (Sud-ouest de la France), partie 4.
AU Lozouet, Pierre (lozouet@mnhn.fr) 
SO Cossmanniana
VL 13
PS 49-58
PD 2011
PY 2011
LA French
U1 0
U2 0
AB Eight new species are described from the lower Oligocene (Stampian) and
   from the Lower Miocene of the Aquitaine and Paris Basins. Three of the
   new species, belonging to the families Tornidae, Collumbellidae and
   Olividae, were collected in the Stampien of the Aquitaine basin and a
   new species of the Naticidae was collected in the Stampien of the Basin
   Paris. The last four species belong to the Tornidae and Rissoidae
   families and were collected from the Lower Miocene (Upper Aquitanian and
   Burdigalian) of the Aquitaine basin. It is the oldest occurences for
   genus Lophocolias.

PT J
AN ZOOR14708059914
DT Article
TI [A scale model of Elephas antiquus Falconer & Cautley 1847, the
   straight-tusked elephant of the Late Pleistocene.]
FT Een schaalmodel van Elephas antiquus Falconer & Cautley 1847, de
   Laat-Pleistocene bosolifant.
AU Mol, Dick
SO Cranium
VL 28
IS 1
PS 50-54
PD Mei 2011
PY 2011
LA Dutch
U1 0
U2 0
AB Siatista's Palaeontological Collection of Siatista, Kozani. Macedonia,
   Greece was studied in the summer of 2009 by Professor Dr. Evangelia
   Tsoukala and Dick Mol. The collection was begun in 1902 by local people
   under the initiative of Mr. Nikolaos Diamantopoulos and housed in a high
   school building. Mr. Anastasios Danas, a high school teacher at the
   Trampantzeion Gymnasium in Siatista, was the main collector and he
   founded the Siatista's Palaeontological Collection in 1906. The records
   of the collection are minimal and fossil localities are often obscure or
   missing. However, the archived documents indicate that all the fossils
   were collected in the larger region of Siatista. One of the villages
   where fossils originated is Polylakkos. In 1976. Professor loannes K.
   Melentis, renowned for his many studies and publications on the fossil
   proboscideans of Greece, realized the importance of the collection. In
   1980 he became involved in its study and management and the collection
   was donated to the community of Siatista in 1994. This interesting
   collection contains 56 remains of Pliocene and Pleistocene
   proboscideans, including the mastodon of the Auvergne, Anancus
   arvernensis, the southern mammoth, Mammuthus meridionalis, and the
   straight-tusked elephant, Elephas antiquus. All the material has been
   re-identified and catalogued by Mol, Tsoukala and Mpatsi (2010). One of
   the most interesting items in the collection is a fragment of a lower m3
   of a stegodon, Stegodon sp., catalogued as SIA 22. The Siatista
   community considered exhibiting the Siatista's Palaeontological
   Collection in a new and improved display in the wonderfully restored
   Trampantzeion Gymnasium building on the loannis Trampatzis Square in
   Siatista. In addition, the idea evolved of having a centerpiece exhibit
   to impress the visitors. The collection is dominated by remains of the
   straight-tusked elephant. Elephas antiquus. A large-sized scale model of
   this extinct species of proboscideans was the natural choice for such an
   exhibit. It has since been sculpted in clay by Dutch sculptor Remie
   Bakker of Rotterdam.The height of this clay model is 101 cm and the
   length is 130 cm, including the tusks. The artist used 140 kg of clay
   for modelling it. This clay model was moulded and finally two casts were
   produced. This massive straight-tusked or forest elephant once roamed.
   north-western Europe during interglacial periods of the Pleistocene when
   average temperatures were 1 [long dash] 2 degrees Celsius warmer than
   today. At the same time hippo's were living in rivers and small lakes,
   in an environment like todays (sub)tropical Africa. In this paper the
   production of this magnificent scale model (1:3,5) is described.
SC Zoology; Education &Educational Research; Paleontology
SN 0923-5647
BD Animals and man; Education and entertainment; Techniques; Land zones;
   Palaearctic region; Eurasia; Europe; Geological time periods; Caenozoic;
   Quaternary
DE Elephas antiquus [Museums collections and exhibitions / Siatista
   Palaeontological Collection / Pleistocene fossil material]
   [Palaeontological techniques / Scale model construction / ] [Greece /
   Macedonia, Siatista / Scale model construction of fossil material]
   [Pleistocene / Late Pleistocene / ]. 
TN Chordates; Elephants; Mammals; Vertebrates
ST Animalia, Chordata, Vertebrata, Mammalia, Proboscidea, Elephantidae
OR Elephas antiquus (Elephantidae): [Fossil]. 
UT ZOOREC:ZOOR14708059914
DA 2020-09-17

PT J
AN ZOOR14705039672
DT Article
TI A CLADISTIC ANALYSIS AND TAXONOMIC REVISION OF AUSTRALIAN METACYCLOPS
   AND GONIOCYCLOPS, WITH DESCRIPTION OF FOUR NEW SPECIES AND THREE NEW
   GENERA (COPEPODA, CYCLOPOIDA).
AU Karanovic, T. (Tomislav.Karanovic@utas.edu.au) 
   Eberhard, S.M.
   Murdoch, A.
SO Crustaceana (Leiden)
VL 84
IS 1
PS 1-67
PD January 2011
PY 2011
LA English
U1 0
U2 2
AB Four new small subterranean cyclopid species are described from
   Australia in a newly erected genus Anzcyclops n. gen.: A. yarriensis n.
   sp. (type), A. belli n. sp., A. ballensis n. sp., and A. euryantennula
   n. sp. Three species are from the Pilbara region in Western Australia,
   the fourth species from central Queensland. Another previously described
   species from New Zealand is transferred to this genus, A. silvestris
   (Harding, 1958) n. comb., originally described in the genus Goniocyclops
   Kiefer, 1955. The new genus has a number of unique features, including
   dorsoventrally compressed habitus, reticulated integument of prosomites,
   and a characterstic shape of the fifth leg. It is most closely related
   to the South American genus Muscocyclops Kiefer, 1937, and the two share
   the same spine formula of the swimming legs (2.3.3.2), but they can be
   distinguished by a number of characters in the shape of the genital
   double-somite, caudal rami, and anal operculum, as well as in the
   armature of the first leg. Our preliminary cladistic analysis revealed
   the polyphyletic nature of the endemic Australian genus Fierscyclops
   Karanovic, 2004. As a result, the subgenus Pilbaracyclops Karanovic,
   2006 is upgraded to full generic rank and its two species are given as
   new combinations: P. supersensus (Karanovic, 2006) n. comb. (type) and P
   frustratio (Karanovic, 2006) n. comb. The assemblage of Australian
   species previously considered members of the genus Metacyclops Kiefer,
   1927 is also found to be polyphyletic and all five Australian
   representatives and one New Zealand species of the so-called
   "trispinosus"-goup are transferred into a newly erected genus
   Pescecyclops n. gen.: P. laurentiisae (Karanovic, 2004) n. comb. (type),
   P pilanus (Karanovic, 2004) n. comb., P arnaudi (G. O. Sars, 1908) n.
   comb., P. monacanthus (Kiefer, 1928) n. comb., P. kimberleyi (Karanovic,
   2004) n. comb., and P pilbaricus (Karanovic, 2004) n. comb. After this,
   only two Australian species are left in the genus Metacyclops: M.
   mortoni Pesce, De Laurentiis & Humphreys, 1996 and M. superincidentis
   Karanovic, 2004. Pescecyclops is defined by the presence of three spines
   on the distal exopodal segment of all swimming legs, only one apical
   spine on the fourth leg endopod, and absence of any sexual dimorphism in
   postantennular appendages, in addition to a Metacyclops-like fifth leg.
   Two Australian species previously considered members of Goniocyclops and
   one as a member of Allocyclops Kiefer, 1932 proved to be relatively
   closely related to each other and quite separate from other members of
   their respective genera. They are transferred into a third new genus,
   Dussartcyclops n. gen., although subdivided into two subgenera: D. (s.
   str.) uniarticulatus (Karanovic, 2004) n. comb. (type), D. (s. str.)
   mortoni (Karanovic, 2004) n. comb., and D. (Barrowcyclops) consensus
   (Karanovic, 2003) n. comb. They all have a reduced armature of the
   swimming legs (spine formula 2.2.2.2), vermiform habitus, and the fifth
   leg exopod armed with two subequal apical setae, but the subgenus
   Barrowcyclops n. subgen. has the exopod of the fifth leg fused basally
   to the somite and the inner spine on the first leg basis absent, in
   addition to a more plesiomorphic endopodal armature of the first and
   fourth legs.
C1 Karanovic, T.; Hanyang Univ, Dept Life Sci, Seoul 133791, South Korea,
   South Korea.
EM Tomislav.Karanovic@utas.edu.au
SC Zoology; Evolutionary Biology
SN 0011-216X
BD Systematics; Nomenclature; New taxa; Type species; Combination;
   Taxonomy; Taxonomic position; Status; Key; Evolution; Land zones;
   Australasian region; Australasia; Australia
DE Anzcyclops ballensis; Anzcyclops belli; Anzcyclops yarriensis [Western
   Australia /  / New species]. 
   Anzcyclops euryantennula [Queensland /  / New species]. 
   Metacyclops complex [Phylogeny / Cladistic analysis / Systematics]
   [Australia /  / ]. 
TN Arthropods; Crustaceans; Invertebrates
ST Animalia, Arthropoda, Crustacea, Copepoda, Cyclopoida
OR Allocyclops (Psammocyclops) consensus - Karanovic 2003 (Cyclopoida):
   [Designated type species for new subgenus, Dussartcyclops
   (Barrowcyclops), p. 54]. 
   Anzcyclops (Cyclopoida): [Gen nov, Of subfamily Cyclopinae, Type species
   Anzcyclops yarriensis, p. 13; Key to species, Females, p. 16]. 
   Anzcyclops ballensis (Cyclopoida): [Sp nov, Western Australia, P. 32]. 
   Anzcyclops belli (Cyclopoida): [Sp nov, Western Australia, P. 25]. 
   Anzcyclops euryantennula (Cyclopoida): [Sp nov, Queensland, P. 42]. 
   Anzcyclops silvestris - (Harding 1958) (Cyclopoida): [Comb nov,
   Transferred from Goniocyclops, p. 14]. 
   Anzcyclops yarriensis (Cyclopoida): [Sp nov, Western Australia, P. 16]. 
   Dussartcyclops (Cyclopoida): [Gen nov, Of subfamily Cyclopinae, Type
   species Goniocyclops uniarticulatus Karanovic 2004, p. 49]. 
   Dussartcyclops (Barrowcyclops) (Cyclopoida): [Subgen nov, Type species
   Allocyclops (Psammocyclops) consensus Karanovic 2003, p. 54].

PT J
AN ZOOR14802008381
DT Article
TI DANGOKA JAPONICA NOV GEN. NOV SP AND EUDACTYLINELLA ALBA WILSON, 1932
   (COPEPODA, SIPHONOSTOMATOIDA, EUDACTYLINIDAE) INFESTING JAPANESE
   ELASMOBRANCHS.
AU Izawa, Kunihiko (izawakun@sea.plala.or.jp) 
SO Crustaceana (Leiden)
VL 84
IS 10
PS 1269-1277
PD 2011
PY 2011
LA English
U1 0
U2 1
AB A description of Dangoka japonica nov. gen. nov. sp. and a redescription
   of Eudactylinella alba Wilson, 1932 are given based on specimens
   recovered from the branchial lamellae of two Japanese guitarfishes,
   Rhinobatos schlegelii Muller&Henle, 1841 and R. hynnicephalus
   Richardson, 1846 (Rhinobatidae), and of two Japanese dasyatid rays,
   Taeniura meyeni Muller&Henle, 1841 and Daystis akajei (Muller&Henle,
   1841) (Dasyatidae), respectively. D. japonica nov. gen. nov. sp. is
   easily distinguishable from all confamilial species in having in the
   female a combination of following features: (1) body with rounded
   prosomal somites, (2) 1-segmented abdomen, (3) caudal ramus with 6
   elements, (4) inconspicuous leg 5, (5) chelate maxilliped with
   dactylus-receiving myxal process, (6) 8-segmented antennule without
   spine, (7) legs 1-4 with 2-segmented rami. The occurrence of E. alba is
   the first record from the Pacific Ocean and T. meyeni and D. akajei
   represent new host records for this species.
C1 Izawa, Kunihiko; Izawa Marine Biol Lab, 795-16 Kannonji, Tsu, Mie,
   5140062, Japan, Japan.
EM izawakun@sea.plala.or.jp
SC Parasitology; Zoology
SN 0011-216X
BD Systematics; Nomenclature; New taxa; Description; Parasites diseases and
   disorders; Parasites; Hosts; Marine zones; Pacific Ocean
DE Dangoka japonica [Piscean hosts / Rhinobatos hynnicephalus / New
   parasite species] [ / Rhinobatos schlegelii / ] [North Pacific / Japan /
   New species from piscean host]. 
   Dasyatis akajei; Taeniura meyeni [Crustacean parasites / Eudactylinella
   alba / New record] [North Pacific / Japan, Honshu, Wakayama / ]. 
   Eudactylinella alba [Piscean hosts / Dasyatis akajei / New record] [ /
   Taeniura meyeni / ] [Pacific Ocean /  / ] [North Pacific / Japan,
   Honshu, Wakayama / ]. 
   Rhinobatos hynnicephalus; Rhinobatos schlegelii [Crustacean parasites /
   Dangoka japonica / New parasite species] [North Pacific / Japan / New
   crustacean parasite species].

DT Article
TI NOTES ON SOME INDO-PACIFIC PONTONIINAE, L. TYPTONYCHUS SPP. NOV., FROM
   NORTHWEST AUSTRALIA.
AU Bruce, A.J. (abruce@broad.net.au) 
SO Crustaceana (Leiden)
VL 84
IS 11
PS 1337-1351
PD 2011
PY 2011
LA English
U1 0
U2 1
AB A new species of the genus Typtonychus Bruce from the Kimberley region
   of Western Australia is described and illustrated. The status of T.
   dimorphus Bruce is reconsidered and T. infaustus sp. nov. is designated.
   Six species of the genus Typtonychus are now known, all from the
   Australia-New Caledonia-Japan region. A key is provided for their
   identification.
C1 Bruce, A.J.; Queensland Museum, Crustacea Sect, POB 3300, S Brisbane,
   Qld 4101, Australia, Australia.
EM abruce@broad.net.au
SC Environmental Sciences &Ecology; Zoology
SN 0011-216X

   Associations; Marine zones; Pacific Ocean

   associate species] [South Pacific / Australia, Western Australia / New
   associated crustacean species]. 
   Typtonychus bruceorum [Associations / Tedania? (Porifera) / New
   associate species] [South Pacific / Australia, Western Australia / New
   species; poriferan associate]. 
   Typtonychus infaustus [South Pacific / Australia, Western Australia /
   New species]. 
TN Arthropods; Crustaceans; Invertebrates; Sponges

PT J
AN ZOOR14803025824
DT Article
TI The Distribution and Seasonality of Zooplankton in Sombreiro River,
   Niger Delta, Nigeria.
AU Ezekiel, E.N.
   Ogamba, E.N.
   Abowei, J.F.N.
SO Current Research Journal of Biological Sciences
VL 3
IS 3
PS 234-239
PD 2011
PY 2011
UR http://maxwellsci.com/jp/issue.php?jid=CRJBS&no=111
AW http://maxwellsci.com/print/crjbs/v3-234-239.pdf
LA English
U1 0
U2 1
AB The distribution and seasonality of zooplankton in Sombreiro River of
   the, Niger Delta area in Nigeria was studied for a period of two years
   (August, 2007-July, 2009). All the zooplankton species occurred in all
   the stations except Mysis sp that was not recorded in station 4
   (Odiemudie). Also all the stations recorded seventeen species (17) each
   except station 4 (Odiemudie) that had sixteen (16) species. Five species
   of Cladocera occurred in all the stations and were fairly distributed.
   In station 2 Alonella costata was the highest (35.7%). This was followed
   by Moina cacrocapa (34.2%) station 2 (Ogbele). Five species of Copepoda
   were fairly distributed in all the stations. Acanthocyclops, carinetus
   (53.1%) was the highest in station 1. This was followed by Cyclops
   stenuis (47.2%) station 1. Only one specie of Decapod crustacean was
   recorded. This was recorded in station 1, 2 and 3 but absent in station
   4. Station 1 had the highest percentage of 44.9 followed by station 3
   with 28.6%. Only one specie of Euphasiacea (Meganicilphanes norvegia)
   was recorded and it occurred in all the stations with station 1 having
   the highest percentage of 41.8 followed by station 4 (24.1%). Three
   species of Protozoa were recorded in all the stations. They were fairly
   distributed. Tintinopsis senensis was the highest in station 3 with a
   percentage occurance of 45.8. This was followed by Halteria sp. (39.2%)
   in station 3 also. The two species of Rotifera were also fairly
   distributed in all the stations. Brachionus falcatus was the highest in
   station 3 followed by Brachionus calyciflorus (32.3) in station 3 also.
   Annual variation result showed that Paracyclops fimbriatus had the
   highest mean value 20.417[plus or minus]10.422 (August 2007 - July
   2008), 17.333[plus or minus]9.306 (August 2008 - July 2009). This was
   followed by Cyclops stenuis 18.167[plus or minus]12.494 (August 2007 -
   July 2008) 16.250[plus or minus]10.847 (August 2008 - July 2009) and
   Meganicliphanes norvegia 17.417[plus or minus]11.540 (August 2007 - July
   2008), 14.667[plus or minus]6.596 (August 2008 - July 2009). The least
   was Mysis sp. 2.083[plus or minus]2.539 (August 2007 - July 2008),
   2.833[plus or minus]3.857 (August 2008 - July 2009). There was no
   significant variation in the mean values of the two years studied
   10.123[plus or minus]0.5656 (August 2007 - July 2008), 9.220 [plus or
   minus] 0.4679 (August 2008 - July 2009). Seasonal variations occurred in
   the abundance of Acanthocyclops carinetus (10.822[plus or minus]8.176
   Wet, 22.714[plus or minus]10.209 Dry) and Mysis sp. (1.236[plus or
   minus]2.411 Wet, 5.429[plus or minus]3.101 Dry). Other species did not
   show significant variations. The mean of the wet and dry season showed
   significant variation 8.799[plus or minus]0.418 wet and 11.790[plus or
   minus]0.707 dry. For the 4 stations studied diversity (S) ranged between
   16 species (Odiemudie) and 17 species (Degema, Ogbele and Ihuaba).
   Abundance of individuals (N) of the stations ranged between 708
   (Odiemudie and 1202 (Degema). Margalef index (d) values ranged between
   2.256 (Degema) and 2.345 (Ogbele). The values for Shannon-Wiener index
   (H) ranged between 1.074 (Degema) and 1.204 (Ogbele). Pielou's index of
   relative density or evenness were between 0.870 (Degema) and 0.978
   (Ogbele). Simpsin's Dominance Index (C) ranged between 0.065 (Ogbele)
   and 0.107 (Degema).
C1 Abowei, J.F.N.; Department of Biological Sciences, Niger Delta
   University, Wilberforce Island, PMB 071, Bayelsa State, Nigeria,
   Nigeria.
SC Environmental Sciences &Ecology; Zoology
BD Ecology; Community structure; Land zones; Afrotropical region; Africa
DE Brachionus; Cladocera; Copepoda; Halteria; Meganyctiphanes norvegia;
   Mysis; Spirostomum; Tintinnopsis senensis [Relative abundance /  /
   plankton] [Distribution within habitat /  / ] [Nigeria / Sombreiro River
   / ]. 
TN Arthropods; Crustaceans; Invertebrates; Protozoans; Rotifers
ST Animalia, Arthropoda, Crustacea, Branchiopoda, Malacostraca,
   Eumalacostraca, Eucarida, Euphausiacea, Peracarida, Mysidacea, Rotifera,
   Protozoa, Ciliophora, Polyhymenophorea, Spirotrichia, Heterotrichida,
   Oligotrichida
OR Copepoda (Crustacea). 
   Cladocera (Branchiopoda). 
   Meganyctiphanes norvegia (Euphausiacea). 
   Mysis (Mysidacea). 
   Brachionus (Rotifera). 
   Spirostomum (Heterotrichida). 
   Halteria (Oligotrichida). 
   Tintinnopsis senensis (Oligotrichida).

PT J
AN ZOOR14802008884
PM 21934291
DT Article
TI A New Allopatric Lineage of the Rodent Deltamys (Rodentia:
   Sigmodontinae) and the Chromosomal Evolution in Deltamys kempi and
   Deltamys sp.
AU Ventura, Karen (kabiousp@yahoo.com.br) 
   Fagundes, V.
   D'Elia, G.
   Christoff, A.U.
   Yonenaga-Yassuda, Y.
SO Cytogenetic and Genome Research
VL 135
IS 2
PS 126-134
PD 2011
PY 2011
LA English
U1 1
U2 5
AB Deltamys Thomas 1917 is a poorly studied and rarely collected taxon of
   Akodontini (Sigmodontinae). The single described species, Deltamys kempi
   (DKE), has a basic karyotype with a diploid number of 2n = 37 in males
   and 2n = 38 in females, a fundamental number FN = 38 for both sexes, and
   an X1X1X2X2/X1X2Y sex determination system. Herein, a new allopatric
   form, Deltamys sp. (DSP), is reported, based on specimens from southern
   Brazil, with 2n = 40, FN = 40 and XX/XY sex chromosomes. We describe the
   karyotype and mechanism of chromosomal differentiation between both
   Deltamys complements. Phylogenetic analyses, based on the complete
   sequence (1,140 bp) of the mitochondrial cytochrome b gene, grouped
   Deltamys sp. as sister species to D. kempi, with up to 12% genetic
   divergence between them. The GTG-banding patterns show complete
   autosomal correspondence between D. kempi and Deltamys sp. and identify
   a tandem rearrangement involving DSP7, DSP19 and DKE4 that is
   responsible for the differences in 2n and FN. Chromosome painting with
   Akodon paranaensis chromosome 21 (a small metacentric akodont marker)
   paint revealed total homology with the smallest acrocentric Deltamys sp.
   chromosome, DSP19. This suggests the occurrence of a pericentric
   inversion or centromeric shift when compared to other akodontines, with
   a posterior tandem rearrangement giving rise to DKE4. In DKE, large
   blocks of pericentromeric constitutive heterochromatin are present on
   the autosomes and the X, and the Y/autosome has an entirely
   heterochromatic short arm. In DSP, small heterochromatic blocks are
   observed on autosomes and X, and the Y is a very small, mostly
   heterochromatic acrocentric. The cytogenetic analyses suggest that the
   Deltamys sp. karyotype is ancestral, with the derived condition
   resulting from a tandem fusion (DSP7 + DSP19) and the Y/autosome
   translocation giving rise to the multiple sex chromosome system. The
   autosomal rearrangements, the differences in CBG-banding patterns and
   Ag=NOR localization, as well as the presence of X1X1X2X2/X1X2Y and XX/XY
   sex determination mechanisms, possibly acting as a reproductive barrier,
   and the phylogenetic position within the Deltamys genus, with high
   genetic divergence, call for a taxonomic review of the genus. Copyright
   [copyright]2011 S. Karger AG, Basel
C1 Ventura, Karen; Univ Sao Paulo, Dept Genet & Biol Evolut, Rua Matao 277,
   Sao Paulo, BR-05508-090, Brazil, Brazil.
EM kabiousp@yahoo.com.br
RI D'Elia, Guillermo/AAE-8873-2020; Yassuda, Yatiyo/M-4090-2013; D'Elia,
   Guillermo/G-2253-2011; Fagundes, Valeria/E-6107-2014; Ventura,
   Karen/G-2566-2012; Christoff, Alexandre Uarth/I-6634-2013
OI D'Elia, Guillermo/0000-0001-7173-2709; D'Elia,
   Guillermo/0000-0001-7173-2709; Christoff, Alexandre
   Uarth/0000-0002-6810-7088
SC Zoology; Genetics &Heredity; Evolutionary Biology
SN 1424-8581
BD Genetics; Cytogenetics; Chromosomes; Evolution; Zoogeography; Land
   zones; Neotropical region; South America
DE Deltamys [Sex determination genetics / XX/XY sex chromosome system /
   taxonomic implications; comparative study; undescribed species]
   [Chromosomes / Chromosomal characteristics & evolution / ] [Karyotype / 
   / ] [Phylogeny / Novel allopatric lineage discovery / ] [Allopatry /  /
   ] [Brazil / Rio Grande do Sul, Esmeralda / ]. 
   Deltamys kempi [Chromosomes / Chromosomal characteristics / taxonomic
   implications; comparative study] [Evolution / Chromosome evolution / ]
   [South America /  / ]. 
TN Chordates; Mammals; Rodents; Vertebrates
ST Animalia, Chordata, Vertebrata, Mammalia, Rodentia, Muridae
OR Deltamys - Thomas 1917 (Muridae). 
   Deltamys kempi - Thomas 1917 (Muridae).
