DT Article
TI [Trichomycterus ballesterosi (Siluriformes: Trichomycteridae), a new
   species from the upper basin of River Sinu, Colombia.]
FT Trichomycterus ballesterosi (Siluriformes: Trichomycteridae), especie
   nueva de la cuenca alta del Rio Sinu, Colombia.
AU Ardila Rodriguez, Carlos A. (lebiasina@gmail.com) 
SO Dahlia
VL 11
PS 3-12
PD 2011
PY 2011
LA Spanish
U1 0
U2 0
AB Trichomycterus ballesterosi sp. nov., is a medium size pencil catfish
   described for the upper part of the Rio Sinu, Tierralta, Cordoba
   Department in Colombia. Trichomycterus ballesterosi sp. nov
   differentiates from the rest of species of the genus by the phenotypic
   color variation between 22.8 and 156.4 mm SL, consisting in two
   horizontal rows of large round brown points below the dorsal region of
   the body, irregular brown dots on the middle line and below body region.
   The distance between the origin of dorsal fin to the base of caudal fin
   is equal to the distance between the anterior first dot to almost the
   middle pectoral fin; the distance from the origin of pelvic fin to the
   base of caudal fin is equal to the distance from the first anterior dot
   to the inter-operculum.
C1 Ardila Rodriguez, Carlos A.; Universidad Metropolitana, Barranquilla,
   Colombia, Colombia.
EM lebiasina@gmail.com
SC Zoology
SN 0122-9982
BD Systematics; Nomenclature; New taxa; Land zones; Neotropical region;
   South America
DE Trichomycterus ballesterosi [Colombia /  / New species]. 
TN Chordates; Fish; Vertebrates
ST Animalia, Chordata, Vertebrata, Pisces, Osteichthyes, Actinopterygii,
   Siluriformes, Trichomycteridae
OR Trichomycterus ballesterosi (Trichomycteridae): [Sp nov, Colombia, P.
   4]. 
UT ZOOREC:ZOOR15512088476
DA 2020-09-17

PT J
AN ZOOR15512088477
DT Article
TI [Trichomycterus maldonadoi (Siluriformes: Trichomycteridae), a new
   species from the upper basin of the River Sinu, Colombia.]
FT Trichomycterus maldonadoi (Siluriformes: Trichomycteridae), especie
   nueva de la cuenca alta del Rio Sinu, Colombia.
AU Ardila Rodriguez, Carlos A. (lebiasina@gmail.com) 
SO Dahlia
VL 11
PS 13-22
PD 2011
PY 2011
LA Spanish
U1 0
U2 0
AB Trichomycterus maldonadoi sp. nov. is characterized by its medium size
   (largest specimen 32.1 mm LE), and it is differenced from others because
   it has19-23 conic teeth in the pre-maxillary bone distributed in two
   rows; dental with two rows supporting 16-19 conic teeth; operculum with
   12-14 odontods; interoperculum with 17-22 odontods; seven
   brachiostegals, 35 free vertebrae and color pattern consisting in a pair
   of horizontal rows (dorsolateral and medialateral) of irregular dots and
   a dorsomedial row of dots.
C1 Ardila Rodriguez, Carlos A.; Universidad Metropolitana, Barranquilla,
   Colombia, Colombia.
EM lebiasina@gmail.com
SC Zoology
SN 0122-9982
BD Systematics; Nomenclature; New taxa; Land zones; Neotropical region;
   South America

DT Article
TI [Astroblepus cacharas (Teleostei: Siluriformes: Astroblepidae), a new
   species of River Cachira, Magdalena River Basin, Colombia.]
FT Astroblepus cacharas (Teleostei: Siluriformes: Astroblepidae), nueva
   especie del Rio Cachira, cuenca del Rio Magdalena, Colombia.
AU Ardila Rodriguez, Carlos A. (lebiasina@gmail.com) 
SO Dahlia
VL 11
PS 23-33
PD 2011
PY 2011
LA Spanish
U1 0
U2 0
AB Astroblepus cacharas sp.nov., is a small sucker-mouth catfish of the
   upper part of Cachira River, Magdalena River basin, Norte de Santander
   Department in Colombia. This new catfish is differentiates from other
   species of Astroblepus in having premaxillary bone with 4 rows of teeth;
   the first row (the most external) has 10 to 11 curved conic teeth and
   one or two bicuspid teeth in the center of the row. The premaxillary,
   seen dorsally, has a squared shape. The posterior projection of the
   dorsal process has a smooth edge. The pectoral fin has 7 soft bifurcate
   radius associated to third radial. The color of a live sample is
   attractive: the head dorsally has a clear yellow color up to the
   posterior edge of eyes; two dark bands go from the edge of the snout up
   to the anterior edge of eye orbit; a big dot on every side of the head
   with phosphorescent yellow color is located in the superior part of the
   operculum, this point disappears when the fish is taking it out of the
   water and preserved in formaldehyde; two perpendicular bands appear
   ahead of the operculum; there is a black oval point in the
   supra-occipital region of the head.
C1 Ardila Rodriguez, Carlos A.; Universidad Metropolitana, Barranquilla,
   Colombia, Colombia.
EM lebiasina@gmail.com
SC Zoology
SN 0122-9982

   South America
DE Astroblepus cacharas [Colombia /  / New species].

   Siluriformes, Astroblepidae

PT J
AN ZOOR14709063045
DT Article
TI The Mecyclothorax beetles (Coleoptera, Carabidae, Moriomorphini) of West
   Maui, Hawaii: taxonomy, biogeography, and conservation.
AU Liebherr, James K. (JKLiebherr@gmail.com) 
SO Deutsche Entomologische Zeitschrift
VL 58
IS 1
PS 15-76
PD 2011
PY 2011
LA English
U1 0
U2 9
AB Species of the genus Mecyclothorax Sharp are taxonomically revised for
   West Maui, resulting in recognition of 27 species, 23 newly described:
   M. allostriatus, M. arcanus, M. badius, M. bartletti, M. ceteratus, M.
   clermontiae, M. curtimutinus, M. excavatus, M. exilioides, M.
   ferovipennis. M. filitarsis, M. geminatus, M. improcerus, M.
   kahalawaiae, M. lyratus, M. minimops, M. oppenheimeri, M. pallidus, M.
   platops, M. scapulatus, M. ustulatus, M. vicinus, and M. vulcanoides.
   Among the species are two pairs of cryptic sibling species best
   diagnosed by male and female genitalia. In the sibling species pair M.
   tyrants and M. arcanus, the former species is geographically restricted
   to Hanaula, an isolated southern massif in West Maui, whereas the latter
   is distributed on the main massif, Puu Kukui. Mecyclothorax scapulatus
   is also restricted to Hanaula supporting recognition of this massif as a
   distinct area of endemism within the Mauna Kahalawai mountain system.
   Species comprising a second sibling species pair, M. allostriatus and M.
   geminatus, exhibit a mosaic geographic distribution wherein each
   locality supports only one species, but the species distributions
   interdigitate among the various isolated localities from which the two
   species are known suggesting a more complicated speciation history. The
   genus Mecyclothorax is treated as part of an austral assemblage of
   genera classified as the tribe Moriomorphini (stat. n.). Species
   richness and endemism are compared among West Maui carabid beetles, land
   snails (Gastropoda), and Drosophilidae (Diptera). Carabid beetles with
   46 species present in West Maui are less rich than the land snail fauna
   of 59 species and drosophilid fly fauna of 51 species. Over all genera,
   carabid beetles exhibit 87% species-level endemism to West Maui, with
   Mecyclothorax species 100% precinctive. Percentage endemism across all
   snail groups is somewhat lower - 73% - but among the more diverse snail
   families Achatinellidae and Amastridae, fraction endemism is similar to
   beetles, being 80% and 88% respectively. Drosophilidae exhibit much
   lower levels of endemism, with only 25% of West Maui species restricted
   to the volcano. Authochthonous speciation occurs at similar rates in all
   three groups, with species duration in all three groups estimated to be
   0.2-0.3 Myr. The higher fraction endemism in beetles versus flies can be
   explained in part by absence of metathoracic flight wings in 48 of the
   51 resident carabid species versus the retention of flight by the flies.
   Mecyclothorax species diversity peaks at 1200-1300 m elevation. This
   elevational zone supports closed canopy forest with a well-developed
   forest floor leaf litter microhabitat, enabling occupation by
   subarboreal trunk and moss inhabitants as well as terrestrial
   litter-inhabiting taxa. Mecyclothorax species are recorded in habitats
   ranging from 600m to the highest West Maui summit at 1760 m elevation.
   Their present-day persistence in this broad range of natural habitats
   makes them suitable subjects for habitat monitoring and continued biotic
   survey.
C1 Liebherr, James K.; Cornell Univ, Dept Entomol, John H & Anna B Comstock
   Hall, Ithaca, NY, USA, USA.
EM JKLiebherr@gmail.com
OI Liebherr, James/0000-0001-9831-884X
SC Zoology; Evolutionary Biology; Environmental Sciences &Ecology
SN 0012-0073

   Evolution; Ecology; Community structure; Zoogeography; Land zones; USA;
   Oceanic islands; Pacific Ocean islands

DT Article
TI Malayatelura ponerophila - a new genus and species of silverfish
   (Zygentoma, Insecta) from Malaysia, living in Leptogenys army-ant
   colonies (Formicidae).
AU Mendes, Luis F. (luis.mendes@iict.pt) 
   von Beeren, Christoph
   Witte, Volker
SO Deutsche Entomologische Zeitschrift
VL 58
IS 2
PS 193-200
PD 2011
PY 2011
LA English
U1 0
U2 10
AB A new species of myrmecophilous Atelurinae silverfish, which is
   considered to represent a new genus, is described from Peninsular
   Malaysia where it was collected in emigration columns of the predacious
   army-ant Leptogenys distinguenda (Formicidae: Ponerinae). The new genus
   is compared with those silverfish species whose praetarsus is devoid of
   empodium as well as with all the seventeen Atelurinae known from the
   Oriental Region. All previously described Atelurinae from Malaysia are
   known as strictly termitophilous and share the existence of complete
   praetarsus (2 claws plus one smaller unguiform empodium).

TI New species of the family Heptageniidae (Ephemeroptera) from Borneo and
   the Philippines.
AU Braasch, Dietrich (d.braasch@t-online.de) 
SO Deutsche Entomologische Zeitschrift
VL 58
IS 2
PS 201-219
PD 2011
PY 2011
LA English
U1 0
U2 1
AB Afronurus webbi sp. n. ([male]), A. sarawakensis sp. n. ([male]) and
   Epeorus boonsoongi sp. n. (larva) are described, and details and new
   records are provided for Atopopus tarsalis ([male], larvae), Atopopus
   sp. A and Thalerosphyrus sp. A ([female]) from Borneo (East Malaysia).
   Afronurus freitagi sp. n. ([male]- La), A. lantuyanensis sp. n.
   ([male]), A. leytenensis sp. n. ([male]), A. mindanaoensis sp. n.
   ([male]) and A. panayensis sp. n. ([male]) are described from the
   Philippines. Afronurus philippinensis Flowers & Pescador, 1984, A.
   sibuyanensis Mol, 1987 are reported from new localities and Asionurus
   sp. A for the first time from the Philippines. The taxonomic position of
   several controversial species like Ecdyonurus illotus Navas, 1933,
   Epeorella borneonia Ulmer, 1939, Thalerosphyrus torridus (Walker, 1853),
   T. sumatranus (Ulmer, 1939) and some zoogeographic viewpoints are
   discussed. Compsoneuria (Palawaneuria) cabayuganensis Braasch & Freitag,
   2008 is considered as species incertae sedis.

TI Revision of the genus Bardunia Stal (Hemiptera, Fulgoroidea, Issidae).
AU Gnezdilov, Vladimir M. (vmgnezdilov@mail.ru) 
SO Deutsche Entomologische Zeitschrift
VL 58
IS 2
PS 221-233
PD 2011
PY 2011
LA English
U1 0
U2 4
AB The Oriental genus Bardunia Stal, 1863 is revised. The genus comprises 8
   species 6 of which are new: B. curvinaso sp. n. from Vietnam, B.
   brevinaso sp. n. from Laos, B. angustinaso sp. n. and B. duboisi sp. n.
   from Java, B. celebensis sp. n. from Sulawesi, and B. papua sp. n. from
   New Guinea. B. nasuta Stal, 1863 and B. rugifrons (Melichar, 1906) are
   redescribed.

DT Article
TI Celebenna thomarosa gen. n., sp. n. (Hemiptera, Fulgoromorpha, Cixiidae,
   Bennini) from Indonesia: Sulawesi with notes on its ecology and
   behaviour.
AU Hoch, Hannelore (hannelore.hoch@mfn-berlin.de) 
   Muehlethaler, Roland
   Wachmann, Ekkehard
   Stelbrink, Bjoern
   Wessel, Andreas
SO Deutsche Entomologische Zeitschrift
VL 58
IS 2
PS 241-250
PD 2011
PY 2011
LA English
U1 0
U2 9
AB A new species of the cixiid tribe Bennini from Sulawesi is described and
   a new genus is erected to accommodate it. This is the first record of a
   Bennini from Sulawesi and the first discovery of this group in a
   subterranean environment. We report preliminary observations of its
   ecology and behaviour. According to the ecological parameters of its
   habitat and its morphological configuration, Celebenna thomarosa is
   ecologically classified as an exapted eutroglophile accidental.

DT Article
TI Two new species of Bennaria Melichar, 1914 (Hemiptera, Fulgoromorpha,
   Cixiidae, Bennini) from Papua New Guinea.
AU Hoch, Hannelore (hannelore.hoch@mfn-berlin.de) 
   Dem, Francesca
SO Deutsche Entomologische Zeitschrift
VL 58
IS 2
PS 251-257
PD 2011
PY 2011
LA English
U1 0
U2 6
AB Species of the cixiid tribe Bennini are characterized by a pair of
   lateral rod-like appendages at the base of the abdomen which are present
   in both sexes. Hitherto, 22 Bennini species have been described in the
   genera Benna, Bennaria and Celebenna from throughout Southeast Asia, two
   of which occur in New Guinea. Recent field studies carried out in native
   forest ecosystems in Madang Province, East Papua New Guinea, provide
   evidence that the number of Bennini species is - as in many other insect
   taxa - higher than previously assumed. Here, we describe two new
   Bennaria species from Papua New Guinea and give preliminary notes on
   their ecology.
C1 Hoch, Hannelore; Museum fur Naturkunde, Leibniz Institute for Research
   on Evolution and Biodiversity at the Humboldt University Berlin,
   Invalidenstrasse 43, 10115 Berlin, Germany, Germany.
EM hannelore.hoch@mfn-berlin.de
OI Hoch, Hannelore/0000-0001-6439-9645

SN 0012-0073

   Australasia

DT Article
TI The Inocelliidae of Southeast Asia: A review of present knowledge
   (Raphidioptera).
AU Aspoeck, Ulrike
   Liu, Xingyue (liu_xingyue@yahoo.com.cn) 
   Rausch, Hubert
   Aspoeck, Horst
SO Deutsche Entomologische Zeitschrift
VL 58
IS 2
PS 259-274
PD 2011
PY 2011
LA English
U1 0
U2 5
AB Four new species of snakeflies of the family Inocelliidae: Inocellia
   longispina, I. bilobata, I. striata, and I. cornuta, spp. n. from
   Thailand are described and illustrated. A synthesis of the known species
   of Inocelliidae from Southeast Asia is presented. The questionable
   heuristic value of the classification of Inocellia, which advocates an
   I. fulvostigmata group and an I. crassicornis group, is discussed. The
   detection of four new partly syntopic species of Inocelliidae occurring
   within a small geographic range comes as a great surprise and infers
   that Southeast Asia is a hitherto unknown important evolutionary center
   of the family.
C1 Liu, Xingyue; Dartment of Entomology, China Agricultural University,
   Beijing 100193, China, China.
EM liu_xingyue@yahoo.com.cn
RI Liu, Xingyue/A-3019-2013; Aspock, Horst/O-1990-2017
OI Liu, Xingyue/0000-0002-9168-0659; Aspock, Horst/0000-0001-9407-3566

SN 0012-0073

DT Article
TI The Trichoptera of Vanuatu.
AU Johanson, Kjell Arne (kjell.arne.johanson@nrm.se) 
   Wells, Alice
   Malm, Tobias
   Espeland, Marianne
SO Deutsche Entomologische Zeitschrift
VL 58
IS 2
PS 279-320
PD 2011
PY 2011
LA English
U1 0
U2 5
AB The Trichoptera diversity of Vanuatu is reviewed based on earlier and
   recently collected material. Altogether, 20 species in 12 genera and 8
   families are now recognized for the country, of which 12 species are
   described as new to science in the families Hydrobiosidae (1 species),
   Hydroptilidae (5 species), Philopotamidae (3 species) and Leptoceridae
   (3 species). The previously known species from Vanuatu are re-described
   with illustrations and photographs. A key to adults of the Trichoptera
   fauna of Vanuatu is provided.

PT J
AN ZOOR14912062788
DT Article
TI New taxonomic synopses and revision of the scombroid fishes
   (Scombroidei, Perciformes), including billfishes, from the Cenozoic of
   territories of the former USSR.
AU Monsch, Kenneth A. (kenneth.monsch@naturalis.nl) 
   Bannikov, Alexandre F.
SO Earth and Environmental Science Transactions of the Royal Society of
   Edinburgh
VL 102
IS 4
PS 253-300
PD 2011
PY 2011
LA English
U1 0
U2 12
AB We present an overview of all known fossil scombroid fishes
   (Scombroidei, Perciformes) of the former USSR, many taxa of which are
   described in a language other than Russian for the first time. Also new
   is the application of a cladistic framework for these taxa. For each
   taxon, short taxonomic synopses with the most relevant characteristics
   (synapomorphies, meristic counts) are presented in a form useful for
   future cladistic analysis. As an exception, we present an extensive
   systematic description of the billfish [dagger]Hemingwaya sarissa
   Sytchevskaya & Prokofiev, because we disagree with earlier
   interpretations. The 'gempylid' [dagger]Hemithyrsites maicopicus
   Daniltshenko retains its generic name, which is considered the valid
   name of what is also known as Promethichthys Gill. A new tribe,
   [dagger]Eocoelopomini, is erected to contain the genera
   [dagger]Eocoelopoma Woodward, [dagger]Palaeothunnus Bannikov, and
   [dagger]Micrornatus Monsch. It is questioned whether species previously
   described as belonging to Thunnus South should be classified in that
   genus. A new species of tribe Scomberomorini, [dagger]Neocybium
   parvidentatum, is described from the Bartonian of W Kazakhstan. A
   specimen of [dagger]Auxides (questionably Maastrichthian, Iran), also
   reported here, possibly extends the radiation of [dagger]Auxides, and
   scombroids as a whole, further back in time. The fossil record of the
   Blochiidae is probably extended downwards to the Thanetian.
C1 Monsch, Kenneth A.; Nat Biodivers Ctr, Dept Geol, POB 9517, Leiden,
   NL-2300 RA, Netherlands, Netherlands.
EM kenneth.monsch@naturalis.nl
RI Bannikov, Alexander F./P-9902-2015
SC Zoology; Evolutionary Biology
BD Systematics; Nomenclature; New taxa; Type genus; Description; Available
   name; Taxonomy; Taxonomic position; Evolution; Land zones; Palaearctic
   region; Eurasia; Asia; Geological time periods; Caenozoic; Tertiary;
   Palaeogene
DE Eocoelopomini [Caenozoic /  / New tribe]. 
   Neocybium parvidentatum [Kazakhstan /  / new species] [Eocene /  / ]. 
   Scombroidei [Phylogeny /  / Systematics; overview] [Eurasia / Former
   USSR / stratigraphical distribution] [Caenozoic /  / ]. 
TN Chordates; Fish; Vertebrates
ST Animalia, Chordata, Vertebrata, Pisces, Osteichthyes, Actinopterygii,
   Perciformes, Gempylidae, Hemingwayidae, Scombridae
OR Micrornatus - Monsch 2005 (Perciformes): [Referred to, New tribe
   Eocoelopomini, p. 277; Fossil]. 
   Scombroidei (Perciformes): [Fossil]. 
   Hemithyrsites - Sauvage 1873 (Gempylidae): [Valid name, P. 263; Fossil].
   
   Hemithyrsites maicopicus - Daniltshenko 1960 (Gempylidae): [Valid name,
   P. 263; Fossil]. 
   Hemingwaya sarissa - Sytchevskaya & Prokofiev 2002 (Hemingwayidae):
   [Redescription, P. 294; Fossil]. 
   Eocoelopoma - Woodward 1901 (Scombridae): [Designated type genus for new
   tribe, Eocoelopomini, p. 277; Fossil]. 
   Eocoelopomini (Scombridae): [Tribe nov, Of subfamily Scombrinae, Type
   genus Eocoelopoma Woodward 1901, p. 277, Caenozoic; Fossil]. 
   Neocybium parvidentatum (Scombridae): [Sp nov, Kazakhstan, Eocene, P.
   288; Fossil]. 
   Palaeothunnus - Bannikov 1978 (Scombridae): [Referred to, New tribe
   Eocoelopomini, p. 277; Fossil].

PT J
AN ZOOR14709069983
DT Article; Meeting paper
TI New dinosaur species from the Upper Triassic Upper Maleri and Lower
   Dharmaram formations of Central India.
AU Novas, Fernando E. (fernovas@yahoo.com.ar) 
   Ezcurra, Martin D.
   Chatterjee, Sankar
   Kutty, T.S.
SO Earth and Environmental Science Transactions of the Royal Society of
   Edinburgh
VL 101
IS 3-4
PS 333-349
PD 2010(2011)
PY 2011
LA English
U1 1
U2 15
AB The beginning of dinosaur evolution is currently known based on a
   handful of highly informative Gondwanan outcrops of Ischigualastian age
   (late Carnian-early Norian). The richest Triassic dinosaur records of
   the southern continents are those of South America and South Africa,
   with taxonomically diverse faunas, whereas faunas from India and central
   Africa are more poorly known. Here, the known diversity of Gondwanan
   Triassic dinosaurs is increased with new specimens from central India,
   which allow a more comprehensive characterisation of these dinosaur
   assemblages. Five dinosauriform specimens are reported from the probable
   late Norian earliest Rhaetian Upper Maleri Formation, including two new
   sauropodomorph species, the non-plateosaurian Nambalia roychowdhurii and
   the plateosaurian Jaklapallisaurus asymmetrica, a guaibasaurid and two
   basal dinosauriforms. The Lower Dharmaram Formation, probably latest
   Norian Rhaetian in age, includes basal sauropodomorph and neotheropod
   remains, providing the second record of a Triassic Gondwanan
   neotheropod. The currently available evidence suggests that the oldest
   known Gondwanan dinosaur assemblages (Ischigualastian) were not
   homogeneous, but more diverse in South America than in India. In
   addition, the Upper Maleri and Lower Dharmaram dinosaur assemblages
   resemble purported coeval South American and European beds in the
   presence of basal sauropodomorphs. Accordingly, the current available
   evidence of the Triassic beds of the Pranhita-Godavari Basin suggests
   that dinosaurs increased in diversity and abundance during the late
   Norian to Rhaetian in this region of Gondwana.
C1 Novas, Fernando E.; Museo Argentino Ciencias Nat, Lab Anat Comparada &
   Evoluc Vertebrados, Angel Gallardo 470 C1405DJR, Buenos Aires, DF,
   Argentina, Argentina.
EM fernovas@yahoo.com.ar
RI Chatterjee, Sankar/A-3801-2016
OI Chatterjee, Sankar/0000-0002-1065-0782

   Oriental region; Eurasia; Asia; India; Geological time periods; Mesozoic
DE Dinosauria [Phylogeny /  / systematics] [Fossil assemblages /  / ]
   [Andhra Pradesh / Pranhita-Godavari Basin / ] [Triassic / Upper Triassic
   / ].

AN ZOOR14805032929
DT Article; Meeting paper
TI MOLECULAR AND CULTURE ANALYSIS OF BACTERIA FROM EARTHWORM MIDDEN OF
   DIFFERENT TROPICAL FOREST SOILS OF RANCHI.
AU Kumari, Suruchi
   Saha, Priyanka
   Sinha, M.P. (m_psinha@yahoo.com) 
SO Ecoscan
SU Special Issue Vol 1
PS 27-33
PD 2011
PY 2011
LA English
U1 0
U2 0
AB Important physicochemical characters and bacterial biomass in earthworm
   midden from three different forest (Eucalyptus, Acacia and mixed) soil
   sample have been studied over on incubation period of 42nd day.
   Earthworm midden from acacia forest indicated enhanced pH, organic C, N,
   P and K with respect to eucalyptus and mixed forest midden. In acacia,
   bacterial population (number/g midden) was gradually decreased from
   55.5[plus or minus]0.88X109 to 19.60[plus or minus]0.818X109 on 0 to
   42nd day. Initial bacterial population was 19.4[plus or minus]0.503X109
   and 39.5[plus or minus]0.850X109 in eucalyptus and mixed forest
   respectively, which was gradually increased up to 28th and 21st day
   (38.7[plus or minus]0.873X109 and 55.2[plus or minus]1.123X109 ) and
   thereafter that population were declined 21.1[plus or minus]0.65X109 and
   22.8[plus or minus]0.702X109 on 42nd of observation in midden of
   eucalyptus and mixed forest respectively. Punctiform and irregular shape
   colonies were dominant colonies found in the earthworm midden. One more
   colony i.e. circular in shape and pink in color which was found only in
   the midden of eucalyptus forest. Molecular based analysis identified the
   bacteria Aeromonas punctata strain JM10, Bacillus cerus probio-32 and
   Kocuria sp. HO-9042, based on 16SrDNA probe. The paper deals in detail
   molecular analysis of bacteria found in midden of different forest
   soils.
C1 Sinha, M.P.; Department of Zoology, Ranchi University, Ranchi 834008,
   India, India.
EM m_psinha@yahoo.com
SC Zoology; Environmental Sciences &Ecology; Forestry; Agriculture
SN 0974-0376
BD Ecology; Habitat; Terrestrial habitat; Land zones; Oriental region;
   Eurasia; Asia; India
DE Oligochaeta [Impact on habitat / Bacteria in midden / ] [Forest and
   woodland / Forest soil / ] [Soil habitat /  / ] [Jharkhand / Ranchi / ].
   
TN Annelids; Invertebrates
ST Animalia, Annelida
OR Oligochaeta (Annelida). 
UT ZOOREC:ZOOR14805032929
DA 2020-09-17

PT J
AN ZOOR14805032930
DT Article; Meeting paper
TI MANAGEMENT OF NELAPATTU BIRD SANCTUARY AND CONSERVATION.
AU Nanda Kumar, N.V. (venkatananda-7@rediffmail.com) 
   Nagarjuna, A.
   Reddy, D.C.
   Mallikarjuna Rao, C.
   Chalapathi Rao, P.V.
SO Ecoscan
SU Special Issue Vol 1
PS 35-44
PD 2011
PY 2011
LA English
U1 0
U2 1
AB Vertical gradient and resource partitioning of migratory birds on
   Barringtonia trees and Prosopis juliflora in Nelapattu bird sanctuary is
   observed. A gradual and natural domination of Open bill storks resulted
   in new colonization on northern side of Athigunta on Prosopis juliflora
   by Pelicans. Management of western, north western and northern side of
   Athigunta requires deweeding Ipomea sp water weeds and restoration of
   Eragrostis tenella where water waders habitat exist. Prosopis juliflora
   are time tested roosting site of Pelicans and requires plantation along
   with Barringtonia at Neredugunta with specified distance. Plantation of
   Subabul trees [long dash] A nesting material for Open bill storks. Algal
   bloom at Athigunta or Eutrophication should be prevented. Irrigation
   water in the tank should be present only up to May/June 1st week and
   management and regulation of Telugu ganga feeder. Monitoring monsoon
   rainfall and chronobiology of Pelican migration to Nelapattu and feeding
   grounds of Bay back waters of Pulicat Lake.

PT J
AN ZOOR14801005788
DT Article
TI Systematic dismantlement of Lichenostomus improves the basis for
   understanding relationships within the honeyeaters (Meliphagidae) and
   the historical development of Australo-Papuan bird communities.
AU Nyari, Arpad S. (arpinyari@gmail.com) 
   Joseph, Leo
SO Emu
VL 111
IS 3
PS 202-211
PD 2011
PY 2011
LA English
U1 0
U2 9
AB Evaluations of relationships among honeyeaters (Passeriformes :
   Meliphagidae) have used dense taxon and nucleotide sampling. Here we
   focus on the systematically contentious meliphagid genus Lichenostomus.
   We use data from two molecular markers that were common to two major
   recent studies, the mitochondrial protein-coding gene ND2 and the
   nuclear intron Fib5. Based on complete species-level sampling of
   Lichenostomus, we confirm the recent finding that Lichenostomus is not
   monophyletic. We recover seven distinct lineages dispersed within the
   meliphagid assemblage. Two uniform and unadorned species, the
   White-gaped (L. unicolor) and Yellow (L. flavus) Honeyeaters, were
   sister species close to some other taxa currently placed in
   Lichenostomus. The only two mangrove specialists, the Varied (L.
   versicolor) and Mangrove (L. fasciogularis) Honeyeaters from
   north-eastern and central-eastern Australia respectively, were not
   sister-species, but the former was sister to the pair comprising
   Mangrove Honeyeater and the widespread Singing Honeyeater (L.
   virescens). Two endemic New Guinean species, the Obscure (L. obscurus)
   and Black-throated (L. subfrenatus) Honeyeaters, are a sister pair to
   the Yellow-faced Honeyeater (L. chrysops) of eastern Australia. We
   suggest a revised generic nomenclature for the species recently placed
   in Lichenostomus and erect one new genus-group name, Bolemoreus, to
   include two species that have been previously grouped in Caligavis.
C1 Nyari, Arpad S.; The University of Kansas, Biodiversity Institute, 1345
   Jayhawk Boulevard, Dyche Hall, Lawrence, KS 66045, USA, USA.
EM arpinyari@gmail.com
RI Joseph, Leo/F-9235-2010
OI Joseph, Leo/0000-0001-7564-1978
SC Zoology; Genetics &Heredity; Evolutionary Biology
SN 0158-4197
BD Systematics; Nomenclature; New taxa; Type species; Combination;
   Taxonomy; Taxonomic position; Genetics; Evolution; Land zones;
   Australasian region
DE Lichenostomus [Molecular genetics / Nuclear & mitochondrial markers /
   taxonomic implications] [Phylogeny / Cladistics / ] [Australasia /  / ].
   
TN Birds; Chordates; Vertebrates
ST Animalia, Chordata, Vertebrata, Aves, Passeriformes, Meliphagidae

   Ramsay 1875, p. 207]. 
   Bolemoreus frenatus - (Ramsay 1875) (Meliphagidae): [Comb nov,
   Transferred from Lichenostomus, p. 207]. 
   Bolemoreus hindwoodi (Meliphagidae): [Comb nov, Transferred from
   Lichenostomus, p. 207].

PT J
AN ZOOR15507046631
DT Article
TI Description of Electrognostus intermedius, the first spider beetle from
   Dominican amber with implications on spider beetle phylogeny (Coleoptera
   Ptinidae).
AU Philips, T. Keith (keith.philips@wku.edu) 
   Mynhardt, Glene
SO Entomapeiron Paleoentomology
VL 4
IS 2
PS 37-51
PD 2011
PY 2011
LA English
U1 0
U2 0
AB A new genus and species of spider beetle and the first documented from
   Dominican amber, Electrognostus intermedius n. gen. n. sp., is described
   from the fossilized remains of two specimens. This species bears
   characters that make it potentially very useful for phylogenetic study;
   morphological traits include those seen in both a more typical ptinid
   such as Ptinus and the New World myrmecophilous spider beetle genus
   Gnostus. We also discuss the significance and possible phylogenetic
   relationships of this new taxon, particularly with regards to the
   evolution of characters related to myrmecophily (ant-associated
   behavior).
C1 Philips, T. Keith; Western Kentucky University, Department of Biology,
   1906 College Heights Blvd., Bowling Green, KY 42101, USA, USA.
EM keith.philips@wku.edu

   Biology

   zones; Neotropical region; Central America; West Indies; Geological time
   periods; Caenozoic; Tertiary; Neogene

DT Article
TI A review of the subfamily Arctiinae (Lepidoptera: Arctiidae) from the
   Philippines.
AU Cerny, Karel
SO Entomofauna
VL 32
IS 3
PS 29-92
PD 3 Jaenner 2011
PY 2011
LA English
U1 0
U2 0
AB The subfamily Arctiinae of the tigermoths (Arctiidae) from the
   Philippines is revised. 49 species are discussed. Lemyra praetexta sp.
   n., Spilosoma trikenzana sp. n., Spilosoma mollis sp. n., Spilosoma
   brechlini sp. n., Spilosoma harlequina sp. n., Spilosoma victorina sp.
   n., Spilosoma unmaeroides sp. n., Spilosoma niahaplaga sp. n., Spilosoma
   vi gulae sp. n., Spilosoma caloscopiami sp. n., Spilosoma fidelia sp.
   n., Spilosoma daltonica sp. n., Baroa peniculata sp. n. and Baroa oryza
   sp. n. are described as new species. Baroa siamica maramaga ssp. n. is
   described as a new subspecies. Spilosoma vandepolli ROTHSCHILD,
   Spilosoma grogane HOLLOWAY, Spilosoma hlpogopa HAMPSON and Spilosoma
   accensa SWINHOE are recorded for the first time from the Philippines.
C1 Cerny, Karel; Tiergartenstr. 27/310, A-6020 Innsbruck, Austria, Austria.

DT Article
TI [Collection of Calliphoridae Described or reviewed (Insecta, Diptera).]
FT Recueil De Calliphoridae Decrits ou Revus (Insecta, Diptera).
AU Lehrer, Andy Z. (azl_diptera@yahoo.fr) 
SO Entomologica (Bari)
VL 43
PS 3-275
PD 2011
PY 2011
LA French
U1 0
U2 0
AB In the present paper 147 species which are distributed in 8 subfamilies
   and 39 genera are reported. Among them 3 subfamilies, 13 genera, a new
   species (Hemigymnochaeta tumbukana n. sp.) and 83 species were
   established and described by the author. At the same time, the more
   recent synonymous which caused many taxonomic confusion in various
   zoogeographical areas are included beside the male genitalia for all
   species except for Fainia giriama Lehrer, 2007, that was described on a
   holotype female. For some species a re-description and male genitalia
   are reported. The references of this monograph is limited in particular
   to the author's papers.
C1 Lehrer, Andy Z.; Tel Aviv Univ, Dept Zool, Rh Hanasi 49-1,POB 7049,
   Maalot, IL-21029, Israel, Israel.
EM azl_diptera@yahoo.fr

AB Eccinetus Muesebeck&Walkley, 1956 (Belytinae) from China is revised,
   with two species described and illustrated as new species: E.
   flatiscapus sp. nov. and E. yunnanensis sp. nov. Three species were
   recorded for the first time from China: E. hardyi Buhl, 1998, E.
   rectinervis (Kieffer, 1913) and E. seticornis Buhl, 1998. A key to the
   world species of this genus is provided. The types of new species are
   deposited in the Hymenoptera Collection of South China Agricultural
   University (SCAU).

TI Two new species of the genus Telephata Meyrick (Lepidoptera,
   Lecithoceridae) from Papua New Guinea with notes on T. nitens
   (Daikonoff), comb. nov.
AU Park, Kyu-Tek (ktpark02@gmail.com) 
SO Entomological Science
VL 14
IS 1
PS 82-86
PD January 2011
PY 2011
LA English
U1 0
U2 1
AB Two new species of the genus Telephata Meyrick which has been known to
   be monotypic, T. melanista, sp. nov. and T. ferruginula, sp. nov., are
   described from Papua New Guinea. A known species from the island,
   Lecithocera nitens Daikonoff, is transferred to this genus; Telephata
   nitens (Diakonoff), comb. nov. Keys to the species of Telephata, based
   on external and genital characters are given, along with illustrations
   of adults, wing venations, and male genitalia.

   32611, USA, USA.

AB Sclerodepsa granulosa gen. et sp. n., a new genus and species of
   lanternflies (Fulgoridae) of the subfamily Cladyphinae is described from
   Brazil and Paraguay based on the brachypterous adult and larva IV
   (penultimate instar). Relationship with Dichopterinae is confirmed,
   similarity with Issidae and Caliscelidae is shown and discussed.

PT J
AN ZOOR14710071821
DT Article
TI Three new genera of Scythridids (Lepidoptera, Scythrididae) from deserts
   of Middle Asia, with remarks on the evolution of the family.
AU Falkovitsh, M.I.
SO Entomologicheskoe Obozrenie
VL 90
IS 1
PS 208-215
PD 2011
PY 2011
NT Serial normally translated cover to cover in: Entomological Review.
LA Russian
U1 0
U2 0
AB As a result of analysis of morphological and biological peculiarities of
   the family Scythrididae the conclusion was drawn, that the main
   evolutionary tendency of this family is based on sharp changes in the
   structure of copulatory apparatus. The cause of such changes is found in
   its initial complexity, which resulted in appearance of a great number
   of monotypic genera. Three new monotypic genera from the Kyzylkum Desert
   are established, descriptions of their type species are given.
   Novuncaria gen. n. Type species Scythris nanophyti Falkovitsh, 1979.
   Wings with banded pattern, but in contrast to other genera with banded
   wing pattern, that have pale bands on the dark background, the new genus
   has pale background of wings with dark bands. Uncus functionally
   substituted by nearly straight, bifurcate apically pseudouncus. Anellus,
   aedeagus and juxta have a unique structure and are strongly diminished.
   Postvinculum gutter-shaped. Sternite VIII large, its caudal prominence
   long, with rami fused at base. Furcuncaria gen. n. Type species Scythris
   fasciata Falkovitsh, 1969. Fore wings dark brown with two whitish bands.
   Uncus very long, nearly straight, biramose. Valve petal-shaped,
   unusually poorly sclerotized, postvinculum submembranous. Sternite VIII
   with Y-shaped rami. Belophora gen. n. Type species Scythris astragali
   Falkovitsh, 1979. Fore wings white with reduced pattern consisting of
   indistinct brownish gray stokes along anterior and posterior wing
   margins, brown stroke at wing base (dorsal to fold), and elongate brown
   speckle near wing middle. Uncus very long, nearly straight, narrowing
   toward subacuminate apex. Gnathos and postvinculum wanting, vinculum in
   form of simple strip. Valva thickened, as if swollen, rounded apically.
   Sternite VIII thickened, gutter-shaped, without rami.
SC Zoology
SN 0367-1445
BD Systematics; Nomenclature; New taxa; Type species; Combination
TN Arthropods; Insects; Invertebrates; Lepidopterans
ST Animalia, Arthropoda, Insecta, Lepidoptera, Glossata, Heteroneura,
   Gelechioidea, Scythridae
OR Belophora (Scythridae): [Gen nov, Of family Scythrididae, Type species
   Scythris astragali Falkovitsh 1969, p. 213]. 
   Belophora astragali - (Falkovitsh 1969) (Scythridae): [Comb nov,
   Transferred from Scythris, p. 213]. 
   Furcuncaria (Scythridae): [Gen nov, Of family Scythrididae, Type species
   Scythris fasciata Falkovitsh 1969, p. 212]. 
   Furcuncaria fasciata - (Falkovitsh 1969) (Scythridae): [Comb nov,
   Transferred from Scythris, p. 212]. 
   Novuncaria (Scythridae): [Gen nov, Of family Scythrididae, Type species
   Scythris nanophyti Falkovitsh 1979, p. 211]. 
   Novuncaria nanophyti - (Falkovitsh 1979) (Scythridae): [Comb nov,
   Transferred from Scythris, p. 211]. 
   Scythris astragali - Falkovitsh 1969 (Scythridae): [Designated type
   species for new genus, Belophora, p. 213]. 
   Scythris fasciata - Falkovitsh 1969 (Scythridae): [Designated type
   species for new genus, Furcuncaria, p. 212]. 
   Scythris nanophyti - Falkovitsh 1979 (Scythridae): [Designated type
   species for new genus, Novuncaria, p. 211].

DT Article
TI Review of species of the genus Oobius Trjapitzin, 1963 (Hymenoptera,
   Encyrtidae) - egg parasitoids of jewel beetles, longhorned beetles
   (Coleoptera, Buprestidae, Cerambycidae) and robber flies (Diptera,
   Asilidae).
AU Trjapitzin, V.A.
   Volkovitsh, M.G.
SO Entomologicheskoe Obozrenie
VL 90
IS 1
PS 226-234
PD 2011
PY 2011
NT Serial normally translated cover to cover in: Entomological Review.
LA Russian
U1 0
U2 6
AB The review contains diagnosis of the genus Oobius Trjapitzin, 1963
   (Hymenoptera, Encyrtidae), key to females of its 9 species described in
   the world fauna and synopsis of them with data on distribution and
   hosts. Special attention is paid to an economically important species
   Oobius agrili Zhang et Wang, 2005 introduced from China into USA and
   Canada for biological control of the emerald ash borer Agrilus
   planipennis Fairmaire (Coleoptera, Buprestidae), very dangerous pest of
   ashes (Fraxinus spp.). Recently this buprestid penetrated also into
   Russia, thus urgent necessity of introduction of its egg parasitoid O.
   agrili arises. Coccidencyrtus pinicola Mercet, 1921 from Spain is
   transferred to the genus Oobius, hence the new combination O. pinicola
   (Mercet), comb. n. is proposed. The lectotype of Tyndarichus rudnevi S.
   Nowicki, 1928 (type species of the genus Oobius) is designated in the
   collection of National Museum of Natural Sciences in Madrid and this is
   formally fixated in the present review. Material of Oobius has been
   studied in depositories of St. Petersburg, Warsaw, Madrid, and Monterrey
   (Mexico).
SC Zoology; Environmental Sciences &Ecology; Parasitology
SN 0367-1445

   Taxonomic position; Key; Animals and man; Control; Parasites diseases
   and disorders; Parasites; Insect parasites; Hosts; Insect hosts;
   Zoogeography; Dispersal; Means of dispersal; Land zones; Nearctic
   region; Palaearctic region; North America

PT J
AN ZOOR14711078354
DT Article
TI Improved tribal delimitation of the subfamily Dictyopharinae and
   description of new genera and new species (Homoptera, Fulgoroidea,
   Dictyopharidae).
AU Emelyanov, A.F.
SO Entomologicheskoe Obozrenie
VL 90
IS 2
PS 299-328
PD 2011
PY 2011
NT Serial normally translated cover to cover in: Entomological Review.
LA Russian
U1 0
U2 1
AB Ten new genera, five new subgenera, and five new species are described
   in the family Dictyopharidae. Three generic names are synonymized. New
   name is proposed for generic homonym. Dictyophara kazeruna Dlabola is
   transferred to the genus Callodictya Melichar. The genus Sinodictya
   Matsumura, with type species Sinodictya tukana Matsumura, is
   redescribed. A new key for identification of the tribes of the subfamily
   Dictyopharinae is given. Composition and characters of the tribes
   Taosini and Lappidini are revised. All genera of the subfamily
   Dictyopharinae are listed according to their tribal position. New
   records are given for some interesting species.
C1 Emelyanov, A.F.; Russian Acad Sci, Inst Zool, St Petersburg, 199034,

TI New and little known planthoppers of the subfamily Ommatidiotinae
   (Homoptera, Fulgoroidea, Caliscelidae) from Madagascar and South Asia.
AU Gnezdilov, V.M.
SO Entomologicheskoe Obozrenie
VL 90
IS 2
PS 329-334
PD 2011

NT Serial normally translated cover to cover in: Entomological Review.

LA Russian
U1 0
U2 1
AB Cano merinus gen. et sp. n., belonging to the tribe Augilini Baker, is
   described from Madagascar. Tubilustrium typicum Distant, 1916 is
   transferred from the tribe Ommatidiotini Fieber to the tribe Augilini.
   Lasonia kirkaldyi Melichar, 1903 is transferred from the family Issidae
   to the tribe Adenissini Dlabola of Caliscelidae. A key to the tribes of
   the subfamily Ommatidiotinae is provided.

TI To the knowledge of the leaf-beetle tribe Nodinini (Coleoptera,
   Chrysomelidae, Eumolpinae) from Philippines and Borneo.
AU Moseyko, A.G.
SO Entomologicheskoe Obozrenie
VL 90
IS 2
PS 358-374
PD 2011
PY 2011
NT Serial normally translated cover to cover in: Entomological Review.
LA Russian
U1 0
U2 1
AB Three new species of the genus Tricliona are described from the
   Philippines and Borneo: T. bakeri sp. n., T. sandakana sp. n. and T.
   philippina sp. n. Stethotes aedilis Weise is transferred to the genus
   Cleoporus, and Ste thotes ferruginea Weise, to Tricliona. Typophorus
   quadripustulatus Baly is transferred to Cleoporus, and C. cruciatus
   Lefevre is synonymized with it. A redescription of the genus Coniomma
   Weise is given. For each species figures of the genitalia are provided.
   Species of Cleoporus from the Philippines and all species of the
   Tricliona ferruginea group are keyed.
C1 Moseyko, A.G.; Zoologicheskii Institut RAN, Sankt-Peterburg, Russia,
   Russia.
RI Moseyko, Alexey/R-5297-2016

DT Article
TI Review of the Palaearctic species of the genus Hadrodactylus Foerster
   (Hymenoptera, Ichneumonidae, Ctenopelmatinae) with description of 5 new
   species.
AU Kasparyan, D.R.
SO Entomologicheskoe Obozrenie
VL 90
IS 2
PS 388-415
PD 2011
PY 2011
NT Serial normally translated cover to cover in: Entomological Review.
LA Russian
U1 0
U2 0
AB 30 Palaearctic species of Hadrodactylus are considered. 2 species-group
   with 6 subgroups are distinguished. 5 new species from Eastern
   Palaearctic are described: Hadrodactylus arkit sp. n. (Kyrgyzstan), H.
   caucasicus sp. n. (Caucasus), H. nitidus sp. n., H. sibiricus sp. n. and
   H. taigensis sp. n. (Eastern Siberia and Far East of Russia). A new
   combination and a new synonymy Xenoschesis incarnator Aubert, 1985
   (recte Hadrodactylus, comb. n.) = Hadrodactylus fugax almator Aubert,
   1996, syn. n. are established. Annotated list of species is given with
   data on distribution in Russia and adjacent territories. A key for
   identification of 30 Palaearctic species is given.
SC Zoology
SN 0367-1445
BD Systematics; Nomenclature; New taxa; Combination; Synonymy; Taxonomy;
   Taxonomic position; Key; Zoogeography; Land zones; Palaearctic region;
   Eurasia; Asia

   [Palaearctic region /  / Key to species] [ /  / biology; distribution].

   Hadrodactylus caucasicus [Eurasia /  / New species]. 
   Hadrodactylus nitidus; Hadrodactylus sibiricus; Hadrodactylus taigensis
   [Russia /  / New species]. 
TN Arthropods; Hymenopterans; Insects; Invertebrates
ST Animalia, Arthropoda, Insecta, Hymenoptera, Apocrita, Terebrantia,
   Ichneumonoidea, Ichneumonidae
OR Hadrodactylus - Foerster 1869 (Ichneumonidae): [Key to species,
   Palaearctic region, P. 406]. 
   Hadrodactylus arkit (Ichneumonidae): [Sp nov, Kyrgyzstan, P. 391]. 
   Hadrodactylus caucasicus (Ichneumonidae): [Sp nov, Eurasia, P. 393]. 
   Hadrodactylus incarnator - (Aubert 1985) (Ichneumonidae): [Comb nov,
   Transferred from Xenoschesis, p. 399; Syn nov, Hadrodactylus fugax
   almator Aubert 1996, p. 399]. 
   Hadrodactylus nitidus (Ichneumonidae): [Sp nov, Russia, P. 400]. 
   Hadrodactylus sibiricus (Ichneumonidae): [Sp nov, Russia, P. 402]. 
   Hadrodactylus taigensis (Ichneumonidae): [Sp nov, Russia, P. 404].

DT Article
TI Genus Chelonus Jurine (Hymenoptera, Braconidae, Cheloninae) in the fauna
   of Russia and adjacent territories. Ch. olgae Kok. species group.
AU Tobias, V.I.
SO Entomologicheskoe Obozrenie
VL 90
IS 2
PS 416-438
PD 2011
PY 2011
NT Serial normally translated cover to cover in: Entomological Review.
LA Russian
U1 0
U2 0
AB The Ch. olgae species-group is established in the genus Chelonus
   characterized by the narrowing apically (much more strongly than to
   base) metasomal carapace not or weakly bent ventrally. This group is
   analogous to the M. retusus group of the allied genus Microchelonus,
   although some differences in the carapace structure emphasize parallel
   development of these morphological features in the two genera. New
   species are described as following: Ch. borisi sp. n. (Russia: Leningrad
   Prov.), Ch. cardui sp. n. (Russia: Voronezh Prov.; Moldova), Ch.
   kokoujevi sp. n. (Russia: Belgorod and Chelyabinsk provinces), Ch.
   speijeri sp. n. (Spain), Ch. ubsunuricus sp. n. (Russia: Tuva), Ch.
   yurii sp. n. (Kazakhstan). Chelonus subannulatus Abdinbekova,
C1 Tobias, V.I.; Russian Acad Sci, Inst Zool, St Petersburg, 199034,
   Russia, Russia.
SC Zoology
SN 0367-1445

   zones; Palaearctic region; Eurasia; Asia; Europe

   systematics].

   New species].

   Chelonus chrysostigma [Russia / Tuva / New record]. 
   Chelonus olgae species group [Eurasia / Russia & adjacent territories /
   Key to species]. 
   Chelonus speijeri [Spain /  / New species]. 
   Chelonus yurii [Kazakhstan /  / New species]. 
TN Arthropods; Hymenopterans; Insects; Invertebrates
ST Animalia, Arthropoda, Insecta, Hymenoptera, Apocrita, Terebrantia,
   Ichneumonoidea, Braconidae
OR Chelonus - Jurine 1801 (Braconidae). 
   Chelonus borisi (Braconidae): [Sp nov, Russia, P. 425]. 
   Chelonus cardui (Braconidae): [Sp nov, Moldova, P. 425]. 
   Chelonus chrysostigma (Braconidae): [New record]. 
   Chelonus kokoujevi (Braconidae): [Sp nov, Russia, P. 428]. 
   Chelonus olgae species group (Braconidae): [Key to species, Eurasia,
   Russia & adjacent territories, P. 416]. 
   Chelonus speijeri (Braconidae): [Sp nov, Spain, P. 433].

   subannulatus Abdinbekova 1971, p. 434].

TI A new species of the genus Coccophagus Westwood (Hymenoptera,
   Chalcidoidea, Aphelinidae) inhabiting ants' nests (Hymenoptera,
   Formicidae) in Malaysia.
AU Sugonyaev, E.S.
SO Entomologicheskoe Obozrenie
VL 90
IS 2
PS 439-441
PD 2011
PY 2011
NT Serial normally translated cover to cover in: Entomological Review.
LA Russian
U1 0
U2 0
AB Coccophagus brachypterus sp. n. is described from Malaysia. The new
   species differs from the closely related C. silvestrii Compere in the
   black hind femur and blackish largest part of hind tibia. The specific
   character of the new species also are shortened fore wings with apices
   not reaching the apex of abdomen.
C1 Sugonyaev, E.S.; Russian Acad Sci, Inst Zool, St Petersburg, Russia,
   Russia.
SC Environmental Sciences &Ecology; Zoology; Parasitology
SN 0367-1445
BD Systematics; Nomenclature; New taxa; Associations; Parasites diseases
   and disorders; Parasites; Insect parasites; Hosts; Insect hosts; Land
   zones; Oriental region; Eurasia; Asia
DE Coccidae [Associations / Formicidae (Hymenoptera) / Myrmecophily; hosts
   of Hymenoptera] [Hymenopteran parasites / Coccophagus brachypterus / New
   parasite species] [Malaysia /  / Hymenopteran associates] [ /  / New
   hymenopteran parasite species]. 
   Coccophagus brachypterus [Hemipteran hosts / Coccidae / New parasite
   species] [Malaysia /  / New species from hemipteran host]. 
   Formicidae [Associations / Coccidae (Hemiptera) / Myrmecophily]

AB The genus Rhinogaster Fennah, 1949 is recorded from the Afrotropical
   Region for the first time. Rhinogaster stilleri sp. n., well
   distinguished from other species of the genus by the shape of process of
   5th abdominal tergite, is described from the Republic of South Africa. A
   key to all species of Rhinogaster is provided.

PT J
AN ZOOR14805036097
DT Article
TI A new genus and a new species of tachinids (Diptera, Tachinidae) from
   Wrangel Island.
AU Richter, V.A.
SO Entomologicheskoe Obozrenie
VL 90
IS 4
PS 913-916
PD 2011
PY 2011
NT Serial normally translated cover to cover in: Entomological Review.
LA Russian
U1 0
U2 2
AB Aesia gen. n. with the type species Aesia acerbiana sp. n. is described
   from the Wrangel Island (Chukchi Autonomous Area). The new genus belongs
   to the tribe Blondeliini (as indicated by a short prealar bristle of
   mesonotum and separated from each other in apical 0.4 cerci). It is not
   similar to any Palaearctic genus of tachinids. In the key to the species
   of Blondeliini of North and Central America and West Indies (Wood, 1985)
   it runs to the genus Eucelatoria Town-send but differs from it in having
   eyes covered with long and dense hairs, lower facial margin protruding
   forward and well visible in lateral view, proboscis with elongate
   prementum, and abdomen of the female not modified, without a keel and
   piercer. Aesia acerbiana sp. n. is reared from a larva of a tiger moth
   (Arctiidae), Acerbia alpina Quensel, collected in the tundra landscape.
   The holotype is in the collection of the Zoological Institute of the
   Russian Academy of Sciences, St. Petersburg.
C1 Richter, V.A.; Russian Acad Sci, Inst Zool, St Petersburg, 199034,
   Russia, Russia.
SC Zoology; Parasitology
SN 0367-1445
BD Systematics; Nomenclature; New taxa; Parasites diseases and disorders;
   Parasites; Insect parasites; Hosts; Insect hosts; Land zones;
   Palaearctic region; Eurasia
DE Acerbia alpina [Dipteran parasites / Aesia acerbiana / New parasite
   species] [Russia /  / New dipteran parasite species]. 
   Aesia acerbiana [Lepidopteran hosts / Acerbia alpina / New parasite
   species] [Russia /  / New species from lepidopteran host]. 
TN Arthropods; Insects; Invertebrates; Lepidopterans; True Flies
ST Animalia, Arthropoda, Insecta, Diptera, Brachycera, Cyclorrhapha,
   Tachinidae, Lepidoptera, Glossata, Heteroneura, Noctuoidea, Arctiidae
OR Aesia (Tachinidae): [Gen nov, Of tribe Blondeliini, Type species Aesia
   acerbiana, p. 913]. 
   Aesia acerbiana (Tachinidae): [Sp nov, Russia, Parasite of Acerbia
   alpina (Lepidoptera), p. 915; Parasite]. 
   Acerbia alpina (Arctiidae): [Host].

TI A new species of the genus Cyphon PAYKULL, 1799 from China and notes to
   the Cyphon puncticeps-subgroup (Coleoptera, Scirtidae).
FT Eine neue Art der Gattung Cyphon PAYKULL, 1799 aus China und Anmerkungen
   zur Cyphon puncticeps-Untergruppe (Coleoptera, Scirtidae). (167. Beitrag
   zur Kenntnis der Scirtidae)
AU Klausnitzer, B. (klausnitzer.col@t-online.de) 
SO Entomologische Nachrichten und Berichte
VL 55
IS 2-3
PS 103-107
PD 2011
PY 2011
LA German
U1 0
U2 0
AB A new species of the genus Cyphon PAYKULL, 1799 from China and notes to
   the Cyphon puncticeps-subgroup (Coleoptera, Scirtidae). - From China is
   described Cyphon helmutsteueri n. sp. It is compared with the species of
   the Cyphon puncticeps-subgroup, especially with cyphon montipanus
   YOSHITOMI, 2009. The new species is characterized by the penis (basal
   structure of the prosthems), the rod-shaped base of the 9th sternite and
   the narrow, trapezoidal plate of the 9th tergite, with is provided along
   the edges with sharp appendages.
C1 Klausnitzer, B.; Mitglied Senckenberg Deutsch Entomol Inst, Lannerstr 5,
   Dresden, D-01219, Germany, Germany.
EM klausnitzer.col@t-online.de
SC Zoology

   Palaearctic region; Eurasia; Asia; China

PT J
AN ZOOR14808056061
DT Article
TI Coleophora paeltsaella Palmqvist & Hellberg, 1999 a junior synonym of
   Coleophora derasofasciella Klimesch, 1952.
AU Palmqvist, Goran
   Landry, Jean-Francois
   Johansson, Roland
SO Entomologisk Tidskrift
VL 132
IS 4
PS 225-230
PD 2011
PY 2011
LA English
U1 0
U2 0
AB Coleophora paeltsaella was described in 1999 with the type locality
   Piiltsa, the northern-most mountain in Sweden. However, it soon became
   obvious that the species showed similarities with Coleophora
   derasofasciella Klimesch, 1952, distributed in the Alps. They also share
   the same host plant. Additional examination of the genitalia morphology
   of the two species complemented with bionomic and DNA studies stronly
   suggest that they belong to the same species, and that Coleophora
   derasofasciella Klimesch, 1952 is the valid name.
C1 Palmqvist, Goran; Vattumannens gata 126, SE-136 62 Haninge, Sweden,
   Sweden.
SC Anatomy &Morphology; Zoology; Biochemistry &Molecular Biology; Genetics
   &Heredity
SN 0013-886X
BD Systematics; Nomenclature; Synonymy; General morphology; Biochemistry;
   Genetics; Land zones; Palaearctic region; Eurasia; Europe
DE Coleophora paeltsaella [General morphology /  / taxonomic implications]
   [Nucleic acids / DNA barcodes / ] [Molecular genetics /  / ] [Sweden /
   Paltsa / biology]. 
TN Arthropods; Insects; Invertebrates; Lepidopterans
ST Animalia, Arthropoda, Insecta, Lepidoptera, Glossata, Heteroneura,
   Gelechioidea, Coleophoridae
OR Coleophora derasofasciella - Klimesch 1952 (Coleophoridae): [Syn nov,
   Coleophora paeltsaella Palmqvist & Hellberg 1999, p. 229]. 
   Coleophora paeltsaella - Palmqvist & Hellberg 1999 (Coleophoridae). 
UT ZOOREC:ZOOR14808056061
DA 2020-09-17

PT J
AN ZOOR14808056066
DT Article
TI Review of the unicolorous species of the subgenus Blastotere
   (Lepidoptera, Argyresthiidae) with descriptions of Argyresthia svenssoni
   sp. n. and A. kulfani sp. n.
AU Bengtsson, Bengt A. (bengt.a.bengtsson@gmail.com) 
   Johansson, Roland
SO Entomologisk Tidskrift
VL 132
IS 4
PS 257-274
PD 2011
PY 2011
LA English
U1 0
U2 0
AB The unicoloured species of the subgenus Blastotere in the family
   Argyresthiidae are reviewed. Two new species, Argyresthia svenssoni
   sp.n. and A. kulfani sp.n.,,are described and compared with closely
   related species. The biology of A. svenssoni seems to be essentially
   identical with that of A. glabratella, and the two species have a
   similar distribution pattern. However, when dissecting female specimens
   from north and south Sweden two different types emerged displaying
   totally different signa, which led to the conclusion that two good
   species were involved. Argyresthia svenssoni is so far recorded only
   from a few European countries, from Italy in the south to north of the
   Polar Circle in the north of Europe. Argyresthia tatrica Baraniak,
   Kulfan&Patocka, 2003, the description of which was based on material
   from Slovakia, is judged to be a junior synonym of A. illuminatella
   Zeller, 1839. The larva feeds on Larix decidua and possibly other
   species of Larix. The type material of A. illuminatella has been studied
   and a lectotype is designated. The status of Argyresthia amiantella
   (Zeller, 1847) is discussed and as the type material seems to be lost a
   neotype is designated. Also the type material of the Blastotere species
   reared from Abies alba is apparently lost and the taxon seems to have
   been misinterpreted. Subsequently, as it has no name the species is
   described here as Argyresthia kulfani sp.n. A recently described
   species. A. uralensis Baraniak&Junnilainen, 2011, has not been studied
   but the original description indicates that it might be a synonym of A.
   illuminatella but is not formally synonymized.
C1 Bengtsson, Bengt A.; Lokegatan 3, S-386 93 Farjestaden, Sweden, Sweden.
EM bengt.a.bengtsson@gmail.com
SC Zoology; Reproductive Biology
SN 0013-886X
BD Systematics; Nomenclature; New taxa; Type material; Synonymy; Taxonomy;
   Key; Reproduction; Reproductive system; Land zones; Palaearctic region;
   Eurasia; Europe
DE Argyresthia (Blastotere) [Genitalia / Genitalia morphology / Taxonomic
   revision; unicolored species] [Europe /  / biology; distribution]. 
   Argyresthia (Blastotere) kulfani [Germany /  / New species] [Slovakia / 
   / ]. 
   Argyresthia (Blastotere) svenssoni [Finland /  / New species] [Italy / 
   / ] [Norway /  / ] [Slovakia /  / ] [Sweden /  / ]. 
TN Arthropods; Insects; Invertebrates; Lepidopterans
ST Animalia, Arthropoda, Insecta, Lepidoptera, Glossata, Heteroneura,
   Yponomeutoidea, Argyresthiidae
OR Argyresthia (Blastotere) - Ratzeburg 1840 (Argyresthiidae): [Key to
   species, Unicolorous species, male & female genitalia keyed separately,
   p. 261]. 
   Argyresthia (Blastotere) illuminatella - Zeller 1839 (Argyresthiidae):
   [Syn nov, Argyresthia tatrica Baraniak, Kulfan & Patocka 2003, p. 270]. 
   Argyresthia (Blastotere) kulfani (Argyresthiidae): [Sp nov, Germany, P.
   269]. 
   Argyresthia (Blastotere) svenssoni (Argyresthiidae): [Sp nov, Sweden, P.
   261]. 
   Argyresthia illuminatella - Zeller 1839 (Argyresthiidae): [Lectotype
   designated, P. 271]. 
   Blastotere amiantella - Zeller 1847 (Argyresthiidae): [Neotype
   designated, P. 272].

AN ZOOR14710075568
DT Article
TI Western Palaearctic Cryptinae (Hymenoptera: Ichneumonidae) in the
   National Museums of Scotland, with nomenclatural changes, taxonomic
   notes, rearing records and special reference to the British check list.
   Part 5. Tribe Phygadeuontini, subtribe Phygadeuontina, with descriptions
   of new species.
AU Schwarz, M.
   Shaw, M.R.
SO Entomologist's Gazette
VL 62
IS 3
PS 175-210
PD 2011
PY 2011
LA English
U1 0
U2 0
AB Distributional, phenological and, in many cases, rearing data are given
   for 72 species of western Palaearctic Phygadeuontina (sensu Townes)
   (Hymenoptera: Ichneumonidae, Cryptinae), based on about 1100 specimens
   in the National Museums of Scotland. Twenty species are recorded from
   Britain for the first time, among them seven species that are newly
   described (Tropistes scoticus sp. nov., Orthizema francescae sp. nov.,
   Stibeutes blandi sp. nov., Theroscopus horsfieldi sp. nov., Theroscopus
   mariae sp. nov., Theroscopus naninae sp. nov. and Phygadeuon palus sp.
   nov.). Keys are provided for the females of western Palaearctic species
   of Tropistes, and macropterous females of European Orthizema and
   (separately) Theroscopus species. Boleslawia Sawoniewicz is newly
   synonymised under Tropistes Gravenhorst, and Theroscopus rotundator
   Aubert under T. ochrogaster (Thomson). Tropistes burakowskii
   (Sawoniewicz) and Phygadeuon melanopygus (Gravenhorst) are new
   combinations.

TI [Contribution to the knowledge of Neotropical Arctiidae VII. Description

   francaise avec un curieux cas de mirnetisme (Lepidoptera Arctiidae
   Arctiinae).
AU Laguerre, Michel (mlaguerre@wanadoo.fr) 
SO Entomologiste (Paris)
VL 67
IS 1
PS 33-38
PD janvier-fevrier 2011
PY 2011
LA French
U1 0
U2 1
AB A new species of neotropical Arctiinae is described from french Guyana.
   Even if it is not entirely satisfactory, this species is described
   within the genus Trichromia Huebner under the name Trichromia insperata
   n. sp. During collecting of this species, a strange mimetism was noticed
   involving an unidentified leafhopper. Habitus of the new species is
   illustrated including its male and female genitalia and pictures of the
   leafhopper are provided.

AB NARANJO N, MONTERO DAV, SAENZ APONTE A. 2011. First record of infection
   by entomopathogenic nematodes of the grass bug Collaria scenica Stal
   (Hemiptera: Miridae). ENTOMOTROPICA 26(3): 117-125. The study was aimed
   to test the pathogenicity of Steinernema sp. and Heterorhabditis sp. in
   Collaria scenica. The effect of different concentrations of infective
   juveniles (IJ) were tested on nymphs and adults of C. scenica. For this
   purpose, the bugs were inoculated with 5 000 JI of each nematode species
   in a factorial design (3x2), and seven concentrations were tested in a
   JI factorial design (7x2x2). The bugs showed 100% mortality and symptoms
   of pathogenicity. Infection was found with both species of nematodes and
   penetration was assumed to be through the spiracles and anus. A higher
   capacity of pathogenicity was observed with Steinernema sp. Based on the
   results Heterorhabditis sp. and Steinernema sp. could constitute an
   efficient tool to control populations of C. scenica in pastures.
C1 Naranjo, Natalia; UNESP, FCAV, Jaboticabal, SP, Brazil, Brazil.

   Respiratory System; Parasitology

   Hosts; Insect hosts; Ecology; Population dynamics

TI Record of Tetrastichus howardi (Hymenoptera: Eulophidae) parasitizing
   Diatraea sp (Lepidoptera: Crambidae) in sugarcane crop in Brazil.
AU Vargas, Elizangela Leite (plpastori@ufc.br) 
   Pereira, Fabricio Fagundes
   Tavares, Marcelo Teixeira
   Pastori, Patrik Luiz
SO Entomotropica
VL 26
IS 3
PS 143-146
PD 2011
PY 2011
LA English
U1 0
U2 4
AB VARGAS EL, FAGUNDES PEREIRA F, TEIXEIRA TAVARES M, PASTORI PL. 2011.
   Record of Tetrastichus howardi (Hymenoptera: Eulophidae) parasitizing
   Diatraea sp. (Lepidoptera: Crambidae) in sugarcane crop in Brazil.
   ENTOMOTROPICA 26(3): 143-146. Biological control has been considered a
   viable alternative for pest control and new research is being carried
   out constanly to find new natural enemies or improve the efficiency of
   known ones. We record Tetrastichus howardi (Olliff, 1893) (Hymenoptera:
   Eulophidae) parasitizing larvae and pupae of Diatraea sp. (Lepidoptera:
   Crambidae). Diatraea sp. pupae parasitized by T. howardi were collected
   in sugarcane fields in Dourados, Mato Grosso do Sul State, Brazil and
   has been maintained on D. saccharalis pupae in laboratory. Data on
   parasitism of D. saccharalis larvae in laboratory by T. howardi are
   presented. These results indicate that T. howardi parasitizes and
   develops in Diatraea sp. larvae and pupae and the potential as a
   biocontrol agent should be investigated.

PM 20965631
DT Article
TI Assessing the nature of the combined effects of copper and zinc on
   estuarine infaunal communities.
AU Fukunaga, Atsuko (a.fukunaga@auckland.ac.nz) 
   Anderson, Marti J.
   Webster-Brown, Jenny G.
SO Environmental Pollution
VL 159
IS 1
PS 116-124
PD Jan 2011
PY 2011
LA English
U1 0
U2 28
AB Elevated levels of copper and zinc in sediment have been shown to
   adversely affect estuarine infauna. We investigated the additivity of
   the combined effects of copper and zinc on infaunal recolonisation
   through a manipulative field experiment in Orewa estuary, New Zealand,
   using defaunated sediment discs treated with these metals. The nature of
   their combined effects varied among infaunal taxa and the particular
   variables being examined. Additive effects were detected for species
   richness, for the mean log abundances of the polychaetes Prionospio sp.
   and Scoloplos cylindrifer and for the multivariate response of the
   community as a whole. Antagonistic effects were detected for the mean
   log abundances of total infauna and the polychaete Heteromastus sp.
   Characterising the potentially interactive nature of the combined
   effects of multiple heavy metals is essential in order to build
   predictive models of future environmental impacts of metal accumulation
   in estuarine sediments. (C) 2010 Elsevier Ltd. All rights reserved.
C1 Fukunaga, Atsuko; Univ Hawaii, Hawaii Inst Marine Biol, POB 1346,
   Kaneohe, HI, USA, USA.
EM a.fukunaga@auckland.ac.nz

   Jenny/0000-0001-9665-871X

DT Article
TI Delapparentia turolensis nov. gen et sp., a new iguanodontoid dinosaur
   (Ornithischia: Ornithopoda) from the Lower Cretaceous of Galve (Spain).
FT Delapparentia turolensis nov. gen et sp., un nuevo dinosaurio
   iguanodontoideo (Ornithischia: Ornithopoda) en el Cretacico Inferior de
   Galve.
AU Ruiz-Omenaca, J.I. (jigruiz@unizar.es) 
SO Estudios Geologicos (Madrid)
VL 67
IS 1
PS 83-110
PD 2011
PY 2011
LA Spanish
U1 0
U2 4
AB An ornithopod dinosaur postcranial skeleton from the Early Cretaceous of
   Galve (Teruel province, Spain), assigned to Iguanodon bernissartensis by
   the French paleontologist Albert de Lapparent in 1960, is redescribed.
   It comes from La Maca 3 locality, early Barremian in age (Camarillas
   Formation) and it is made of several cervical vertebrae, fragmentary
   remains of the dorsal and sacral series, several caudal vertebrae,
   fragments of cervical, dorsal and sternal ribs, fragments of chevrons
   and ossified tendons, and an incomplete left hip. It has been identified
   as an "iguanodontid" (i.e., a non-hadrosaurid iguan- odontoid) by the
   presence of a deep prepubic blade and the absence of antitrochanter on
   ilium. The skeleton represents a new iguanodontoid taxon, Delapparentia
   turolensis nov. gen et sp., characterized by the following
   autapomorphies: 1) posterior dorsal ribs with long, parallel and unfused
   capitulum and tuberculum, 2) ossified sternal ribs, and 3) straight and
   lateromedially expanded preacetabular process of ilium (convergent in
   Zalmoxes). It also presents a combination of anterior dorsal ribs with a
   pneumatic foramen, and a ischium of big size in relation to ilium.
C1 Ruiz-Omenaca, J.I.; Museo del Jurasico de Asturias (MUJA), E-33328
   Colunga, Spain, Spain.
EM jigruiz@unizar.es
RI Ruiz-Omenaca, Jose Ignacio/D-6107-2011
OI Ruiz-Omenaca, Jose Ignacio/0000-0001-8791-9287

SN 0367-0449

   Eurasia; Europe; Geological time periods; Mesozoic

   Delapparentia turolensis [Spain /  / new species] [Cretaceous /  / ].

   Delapparentia turolensis, p. 87, Cretaceous; Fossil]. 
   Delapparentia turolensis (Ornithopoda): [Sp nov, Spain, Cretaceous, P.
   87; Fossil].

TI A new species of Adelpharctos (Mammalia, Carnivora, Ursidae) from the
   late Oligocene of the 'Phosphorites du Quercy' (France).
AU de Bonis, L. (louis.debonis@univ-poitiers.fr) 
SO Estudios Geologicos (Madrid)
VL 67
IS 2
PS 179-186
PD 2011
PY 2011
LA English
U1 0
U2 5
AB The genus Adelpharctos was known until now through the species A. mirus
   by a unique mandible (p2-m2) from the old collections of the Quercy
   whose geological age was unknown. New material coming from the locality
   of Pech-du-Fraysse completes our knowledge of the genus particularly for
   the maxilla and upper teeth. Adelpharctos belongs to the sub-family
   Hemicyoninae in the family Ursidae. It differs from the middle Miocene
   hemicyonines which have more massive molars and from the group
   Cephalogale-Phoberogale by some morphological characters. It seems to be
   a branch coming from the ancestral stem group of the sub-family.

DT Article
TI Musteloidea (Carnivora, Mammalia) from the Late Miocene of Venta del
   Moro (Valencia, Spain).
AU Montoya, P. (pmontoya@uv.es) 
   Morales, J.
   Abella, J.
SO Estudios Geologicos (Madrid)
VL 67
IS 2
PS 193-206
PD 2011
PY 2011
LA English
U1 0
U2 6
AB The purpose of the present work is to describe the Musteloidea from the
   Late Miocene locality of Venta del Moro (Valencia, Spain). We have
   identified the following species: Martes ginsburgi nov. sp., Lutra
   affinis Gervais, 1859, Plesiogulo monspessulanus Viret, 1939 and
   Promephitis alexejewi Schlosser, 1924. Besides Plesiogulo monspessulanus
   which was already described in this locality and in Las Casiones (MN 13,
   Teruel Basin), we are approaching an unedited Musteloidea assemblage
   from the Miocene of the Iberian Peninsula. The m1 of Martes ginsburgi
   nov. sp. is similar in size and morphology to the Asian species of the
   genus, M. anderssoni and M. zdanskyi, but it differs in having a very
   wide M1 with a developed lingual platform. The presence of Lutra affinis
   is the third register of this species in the fossil record, since it was
   only previously known from the Pliocene of Montpellier (France) and the
   terminal Miocene of Maramena (Greece). Promephitis alexejewi is the
   first appearance of this species in Europe, which has been only
   registered until now in several localities of Mongolia and China. It
   differs from the rest of Promephitis species in the possession of a
   narrower m1, with a very sectorial trigonid.
C1 Montoya, P.; Univ Valencia, Dept Geol, Doctor Moliner 50, Burjassot,
   E-46100, Spain, Spain.

DT Article
TI A new genus and species of Felidae (Mammalia) from Rusinga Island,
   Kenya, with notes on early Felidae of Africa.
AU Werdelin, L. (werdelin@nrm.se) 
SO Estudios Geologicos (Madrid)
VL 67
IS 2
PS 217-222
PD 2011
PY 2011
LA English
U1 0
U2 4
AB The lower Miocene (Burdigalian) deposits of the Hiwegi Fm., Rusinga
   Island, Kenya, have yielded a single specimen of a small felid. This
   specimen, here identified as the holotype of a new genus and species, is
   of the size of the smallest living Felidae. It shows some features of
   primitive, "Pseudaelurus-grade" cats, but also features of both
   morphology and metrics that are intermediate between this grade and
   modern Felidae, suggesting a transitional taxon. This is in contrast
   with Diamantofelis and Namafelis from Namibia, which, though aberrant,
   are more clearly of "Pseudaelurus-grade". The Rusinga specimen is the
   most derived felid specimen of the lower Miocene.
C1 Werdelin, L.; Swedish Museum Nat Hist, Dept Palaeozool, Box 50007,
   Stockholm, SE-10405, Sweden, Sweden.
EM werdelin@nrm.se

TI Rhizomastix biflagellata sp nov., a new amoeboflagellate of uncertain
   phylogenetic position isolated from frogs.
AU Cepicka, Ivan (ivan.cepicka@centrum.cz) 
SO European Journal of Protistology
VL 47
IS 1
PS 10-15
PD Jan 2011
PY 2011
LA English
U1 0
U2 6
AB The genus Rhizomastix contains five species of amoeboflagellates with a
   single anterior flagellum, which live as intestinal symbionts of insects
   and amphibians. Though established in 1911, Rhizomastix has been
   neglected for decades and its phylogenetic position is uncertain. This
   paper describes the morphology of the first cultivated strain of
   Rhizomastix. The organism was isolated from an argentine horned frog and
   differs from the known Rhizomastix species by the presence of
   biflagellate cells. The isolate is described as Rhizomastix biflagellata
   sp. nov. A possible relationship of Rhizomastix to Archamoebae is
   discussed. (C) 2010 Elsevier GmbH. All rights reserved.
C1 Cepicka, Ivan; Charles Univ, Dept Zool, Vinicna 7, Prague, Czech
   Republic, Czech Republic.

DT Article
TI Oramoeba fumarolia gen. nov., sp nov., a new marine heterolobosean
   amoeboflagellate growing at 54 [degree]C.
AU De Jonckheere, Johan F. (johan.dejonckheere@uclouvain.be) 
   Baumgartner, Manuela
   Eberhardt, Silvia
   Opperdoes, Fred R.
   Stetter, Karl O.
SO European Journal of Protistology
VL 47
IS 1
PS 16-23
PD Jan 2011
PY 2011
LA English
U1 0
U2 7
AB An amoeba strain was isolated from marine sediment taken from the beach
   near a fumarole in Italy. The trophozoites of this new marine species
   transforms into flagellates with variable numbers of flagella, from 2 to
   10. The strain forms round to oval cysts. This thermophilic
   amoeboflagellate grows at temperatures up to 54 [degree]C. Molecular
   phylogenetic analysis of the small subunit ribosomal DNA (SSU rDNA)
   places the amoeboflagellate in the Heterolobosea. The closest relatives
   are Stachyamoeba sp. ATCC50324, a strain isolated from an ocean sample,
   and Vrihiamoeba italica, a recent isolate from a rice field. Like some
   other heterolobosean species, this new isolate has a group I intron in
   the SSU rDNA. Because of the unique place in the molecular phylogenetic
   tree, and because there is no species found in the literature with
   similar morphological and physiological characteristics, this isolate is
   considered to be a new genus and a new species, Oramoeba fumarolia gen.
   nov., sp. nov. (C) 2010 Elsevier GmbH. All rights reserved.
C1 De Jonckheere, Johan F.; De Duve Inst, Trop Dis Res Unit, Brussels,
   Belgium, Belgium.
EM johan.dejonckheere@uclouvain.be

AN ZOOR14706045010
PM 20971620
DT Article
TI Cotterillia bromelicola nov gen., nov spec., a gonostomatid ciliate
   (Ciliophora, Hypotricha) from tank bromeliads (Bromeliaceae) with de
   novo originating dorsal kineties.
AU Foissner, Wilhelm (wilhelm.foissner@sbg.ac.at) 
   Stoeck, Thorsten
SO European Journal of Protistology
VL 47
IS 1
PS 29-50
PD Jan 2011
PY 2011
LA English
U1 0
U2 8
AB Cotterillia bromelicola nov. gen., nov. spec. was discovered in the
   tanks of the Mexican bromeliad Tillandsia heterophylla. Its morphology,
   ontogenesis, and 18S rDNA were studied with standard methods.
   Cotterillia has many cirral rows on both sides of the body. Uniquely,
   and thus used to diagnose the new genus Cotterillia, it has dorsal
   kineties originating de novo, producing neokinetal waves where the
   parental dorsal kineties reorganize to "combined rows", consisting of
   dorsal bristles anteriorly and of cirri posteriorly. Thus, up to four
   generations of bristles and cirri occur on the dorsal body surface.
   Cotterillia bromelicola has a gonostomatid body and adoral zone of
   membranelles, while the dense ciliature and the neokinetal waves
   resemble kahliellid hypotrichs. However, the de nova origin of anlage 1
   and the molecular analyses show convincingly that Cotterillia belongs to
   the Gonostomatidae Small and Lynn, 1985, for which an improved diagnosis
   is provided. Thus, neokinetal waves originated several times
   independently. The molecular differences between Trachelostyla,
   Gonostomum, and Cotterillia are small (<=5%) compared to their distinct
   morphologies and ontogeneses, suggesting that the 18S rDNA
   underestimates generic diversity. Our study emphasizes the need of
   combined morphological, ontogenetic, and molecular investigations to
   unravel the complex phylogeny and evolution of hypotrich ciliates. Crown
   Copyright (C) 2010 Published by Elsevier GmbH. All rights reserved.
C1 Foissner, Wilhelm; Salzburg Univ, FB Organism Biol, Hellbrunnerstr 34,
   Salzburg, Austria, Austria.
EM wilhelm.foissner@sbg.ac.at
SC Zoology
SN 0932-4739
BD Systematics; Nomenclature; New taxa; Diagnosis; Land zones; Nearctic
   region; North America
DE Cotterillia bromelicola [Mexico /  / New species]. 
TN Protozoans
ST Protozoa, Ciliophora, Polyhymenophorea, Spirotrichia, Hypotrichida
OR Cotterillia (Hypotrichida): [Gen nov, Of family Gonostomatidae, Type
   species Cotterillia bromelicola, p. 31]. 
   Cotterillia bromelicola (Hypotrichida): [Sp nov, Mexico, P. 31]. 
   Gonostomatidae - Small & Lynn 1985 (Hypotrichida): [Emended diagnosis,
   P. 49]. 
DI 10.1016/j.ejop.2010.08.003
UT ZOOREC:ZOOR14706045010
OA Green Accepted
DA 2020-09-17

AN ZOOR14706045011

TI Updated hypothesis on the evolution of oligotrichid ciliates
   (Ciliophora, Spirotricha, Oligotrichida) based on somatic ciliary
   patterns and ontogenetic data.
AU Agatha, Sabine (sabine.agatha@sbg.ac.at) 
SO European Journal of Protistology
VL 47
IS 1
PS 51-56
PD Jan 2011
PY 2011
LA English
U1 0
U2 3
AB The two recently established genera Apostrombidium Xu et al., 2009 and
   Varistrombidium Xu et al., 2009 and the analysis of ontogenetic data in
   Strombidium constrictum, S. montagnesi, S. wilberti, Omegastrombidium
   elegans, and Paratontonia gracillima necessitated a revision of the
   hypothesis about the somatic ciliary pattern evolution in oligotrichid
   ciliates. As a consequence, the species-rich genus Strombidium was
   split, establishing two genera for species with a horizontal girdle
   kinety posterior to the oral primordium: Opisthostrombidium nov. gen.
   with the extrusome attachment sites along the anterior margin of the
   girdle kinety and posterior to the oral primordium and Foissneridium
   nov. gen. with the extrusome attachment sites distinctly apart from the
   girdle kinety and anterior to the oral primordium. The ontogenetic data
   revealed that the [OMEGA]-shaped girdle kinety pattern evolved
   convergently from the Pseudotontonia pattern with its horizontal girdle
   kinety in the tailed genus Paratontonia and from the Novistrombidium
   pattern with its dextrally spiralled girdle kinety in the tailless genus
   Omegastrombidium. The somatic ciliary pattern of the latter genus
   probably gave rise to the patterns of Apostrombidium and
   Varistrombidium. (C) 2010 Elsevier GmbH. All rights reserved.
C1 Agatha, Sabine; Salzburg Univ, Dept Organism Biol, Hellbrunnerstr 34,
   Salzburg, Austria, Austria.
EM sabine.agatha@sbg.ac.at
OI Agatha, Sabine/0000-0003-3083-9782
SC Zoology; Cell Biology; Developmental Biology; Evolutionary Biology
SN 0932-4739
BD Systematics; Nomenclature; New taxa; Type species; Combination;
   Taxonomy; Taxonomic position; Cytology; Protoplasm; Organelles; Life
   cycle and development; Evolution
DE Oligotrichida [Cilia / Somatic ciliary pattern / taxonomic implications]
   [Development / Ontogeny / ] [Evolution /  / ]. 
TN Protozoans
ST Protozoa, Ciliophora, Polyhymenophorea, Spirotrichia, Oligotrichida
OR Oligotrichida (Spirotrichia). 
   Conocylis constricta - Meunier 1910 (Oligotrichida): [Designated type
   species for new genus, Foissneridium, p. 55]. 
   Foissneridium (Oligotrichida): [Gen nov, Of family Strombidiidae, Type
   species Conocylis constricta Meunier 1910, p. 55]. 
   Foissneridium constrictum - (Meunier 1910) (Oligotrichida): [Comb nov,
   Transferred from Strombidium, p. 55]. 
   Opisthostrombidium (Oligotrichida): [Gen nov, Of family Strombidiidae,
   Type species Strombidium montagnesi Xu, Song & Warren 2006, p. 54]. 
   Opisthostrombidium montagnesi - (Xu, Song & Warren 2006)
   (Oligotrichida): [Comb nov, Transferred from Strombidium, p. 54]. 
   Opisthostrombidium wilberti - (Song 2005) (Oligotrichida): [Comb nov,
   Transferred from Strombidium, p. 55]. 
   Strombidium constrictum - (Meunier 1910) (Oligotrichida): [Referred to,
   New genus Foissneridium, p. 55]. 
   Strombidium montagnesi - Xu, Song & Warren 2006 (Oligotrichida):
   [Designated type species for new genus, Opisthostrombidium, p. 54]. 
   Strombidium wilberti - Song 2005 (Oligotrichida): [Referred to, New
   genus Opisthostrombidium, p. 55].

TI New Antarctic stenothoids sensu lato (Amphipoda, Crustacea).
AU Krapp-Schickel, Traudl (traudl.krapp@uni-bonn.de) 
SO European Journal of Taxonomy
VL 2
PS 1-17
PD 2011
PY 2011
UR http://web-ejt.nhm.ac.uk/index.php/ejt/article/view/56/8
AW http://web-ejt.nhm.ac.uk/index.php/ejt/article/view/56/8
LA English
U1 0
U2 0
AB Three stenothoid species are reported from recent Antarctic collections.
   Two of these are new to science (Prometopa cedrici sp. nov. and
   Antatelson claudei sp. nov.). A few character states of Antatelson
   walkeri are discussed. Keys are provided for Prometopa as well as for
   Antatelson.
