DT Article
TI On two subspecies of Mesobuthus eupeus (C. L. Koch, 1839) in Turkey
   (Scorpiones: Buthidae).
AU Kovarik, Frantisek
   Yagmur, Ersen Aydin
   Fet, Victor
   Novidpour, Shahrokh
SO Euscorpius
VL 109
PS 1-15
PD January 2011
PY 2011
UR http://www.science.marshall.edu/fet/euscorpius/p2011_109.pdf
AW http://www.science.marshall.edu/fet/euscorpius/p2011_109.pdf
LA English
U1 0
U2 0
AB Examination of 268 specimens of Mesobuthus eupeus eupeus (C. L. Koch,
   1839) and 1765 specimens of M. eupeus phillipsii (Pocock, 1889) from 163
   localities, 92 of them in Turkey, has enabled us to establish
   distribution of the two subspecies and limits of their ranges in
   southeastern Turkey. A map of distribution of these subspecies in Turkey
   and a key to Turkish Mesobuthus species and subspecies are provided.
   Buthus eupeus philippovitschi Birula, 1905 is synonymized with
   Mesobuthus eupeus eupeus, and Buthus eupaeus mesopotamicus Penther, 1912
   is synonymized with Mesobuthus eupeus phillipsii.
C1 Kovarik, Frantisek; P. O. Box 27, CZ-145 01, Praha 45, Czech Republic,
   Czech Republic.
SC Zoology
SN 1536-9307
BD Systematics; Nomenclature; Synonymy; Taxonomy; Key; Zoogeography; Land
   zones; Palaearctic region; Eurasia
DE Mesobuthus [Turkey /  / Key to species]. 
   Mesobuthus eupeus eupeus; Mesobuthus eupeus phillipsii [Zoogeography / 
   / Systematics] [Turkey /  / distribution]. 
TN Arachnids; Arthropods; Chelicerates; Invertebrates
ST Animalia, Arthropoda, Arachnida, Scorpiones
OR Mesobuthus - Vachon 1950 (Scorpiones): [Key to species, Turkey, P. 12]. 
   Mesobuthus eupeus eupeus - (Koch 1839) (Scorpiones): [Syn nov, Buthus
   eupeus phillippowitschi Birula 1905, p. 2]. 
   Mesobuthus eupeus phillipsii - (Pocock 1889) (Scorpiones): [Syn nov,
   Buthus eupeus mesopotamicus Penther 1912, p. 5].

TI Corrections to the second edition of the "Catalogue of butterflies of
   the former USSR".
AU Korb, S.K.
   Bolshakov, L.V.
SO Eversmannia
VL 27-28
PS 3-6
PD 2011
PY 2011
LA Russian
U1 0
U2 0
AB Some corrections are listed to the second edition of "A catalogue of
   butterflies of the former USSR" (Korb, Bolshakov, 2011). Two erroneously
   listed species are excluded from this fauna, nomenclatural and factual
   mistakes are corrected, actual comments are updated. It is shown that
   nomenclatural act of [Balint et al., 2001] (choosing spelling of the
   generic name Plebejus Kluk, 1780 instead of Plebeius Kluk, 1780 using
   the first reviser rights) is invalid according to the Art. 24.2 of ICZN;
   valid spelling is Plebeius Kluk, 1780 according to the first reviser
   action (Tutt, 1906).

   Russia, Russia.

DT Article
TI To the knowledge of systematics of Palaearctic satyrids from the genus
   Coenonympha Hubner, (1819) (Lepidoptera: Satyridae).
AU Korb, S.K.
   Bolshakov, L.V.
SO Eversmannia
VL 27-28
PS 7-21
PD 2011
PY 2011
LA Russian
U1 0
U2 0
AB A review of genera of Coenonymphina, based on male and female genitalia
   as well as molecular analysis of ??I and Ef1a genes is given, with a
   brief overview of generic structure of Palaearctic Coenonymphina and an
   identification key. Treatment of Coenonympha "extra lato" (sensu
   Kodandaramaiah, Wahlberg, 2009) is considered unjustified, with outer
   position of morphologically distinct Triphysa Zeller, 1850. Considering
   the paraphyly of Coenonympha + Lyela cluster, generic status of Lyela
   Swinhoe, 1908 is preserved, with Coenonympha Hubner, [1819] (s.l.) split
   into 3 genera: Coenonympha (s.str.) (monotypic, with type species
   Papilio geticus Esper, 1794), Disommata, gen.n. (monotypic, with type
   species Coenonympha nolckeni Erschoff, 1874) and Chortobius [Dunning et
   Pickard], 1858, stat. rest. (all other species, with type species
   Papilio pamphilus Linnaeus, 1758). It is supposed that the North
   American C. haydenii (Edwards, 1872) and Chinese Sinonympha amoena Lee,
   1974 may belong to either nominate or their own subgenera of
   Coenonympha.
C1 Korb, S.K.; g. Nizhnii Novgorod, Russkoe entomologicheskoe obshchestvo
   (Nizhnegorodskii otdelenie), Russia, Russia.

DT Article
TI A review of the subgenus Maculinea van Eecke, 1915 of the genus
   Phengaris Doherty, 1891 (Lepidoptera: Lycaenidae) of the Palaearctic
   fauna.
AU Korb, S.K.
SO Eversmannia
VL 27-28
PS 22-46
PD 2011
PY 2011
NT Separate unpaginated plates.
LA Russian
U1 0
U2 1
AB In the present message a review of blue butterflies of the subgenus
   Maculinea van Eecke, 1915 of the genus Phengaris Doherty, 1891 of the
   fauna of Palaearctic region is given. This subgenus includes 8 species.
   The data on biology, distribution, variability and subspecific structure
   of each species is presented. The lectotypes of Phengaris (Maculinea)
   alcon monticola (Staudinger, 1901), Ph. (M.) teleius obscurata
   (Staudinger, 1892), Ph. (M.) t. euphemia (Staudinger, 1887), Ph. (M.)
   cyanecula (Eversmann, 1848), Ph. (M.) arionides (Staudinger, 1887), Ph.
   (M.) arion bashkiria (Krulikovsky, 1897) and neotypes of Ph. (M.) alcon
   ((Denis et Schiffermuller), (1775)), Ph. (M.) cyanecula sauron (Korb,
   2003) are designated. A new subspecies, Ph. (M.) cyanecula arven,
   ssp.n., with the type locality "China: Nan-Shan, eastern limit" is
   described. Ph. (M.) teleius (Bergstrasser, 1779) for the first time
   recorded from Tian Shan (Suusamyr valley). Taxa daisensis and hosonoi
   syninymized with kazamoto by the type localities (all three taxa are
   described from Honshu island): Phengaris (Maculinea) teleius kazamoto
   (Druce, 1875) = Ph. (M.) t. daisensis Matsumura, 1926, syn.n.; = Ph.
   (M.) t. hosonoi Takahashi, 1973, syn.n. The new data about myrmecophily
   in this subgenus are given: Ph. (M.) cyanecula with Myrmica lacustris
   Ruzsky, 1905, Ph. (M.) alcon with M. tenuispina Ruzsky, 1905 in Kirghiz
   Mts. (North Tian-Shan).
C1 Korb, S.K.; g. Nizhnii Novgorod, Moskovskoe obshchestvo ispytatelei
   prirody, Russia, Russia.

   (Lepidoptera) / Myrmecophily; new record] [Kyrgyzstan / Kirgiz Ridge,

   (Lepidoptera) / Myrmecophily; new record] [Kyrgyzstan / Kirgiz Ridge,

PT J
AN ZOOR14805031990
DT Article
TI Additions and corrections on the fauna and ecology of Kaluga province
   Lepidoptera. 3.
AU Bolshakov, L.V.
   Alekseev, S.K.
   Anikin, V.V.
   Piskunov, V.I.
SO Eversmannia
VL 27-28
PS 104-114
PD 2011
PY 2011
LA Russian
U1 0
U2 0
AB Additions and corrections to the list of Lepidoptera of Kaluga Province
   are presented based on collections material of 2006-2011 and the
   analysis of published data. An annotated list of 60 species is
   presented, with 48 species being recorded as new to the Province,
   including Swammerdamia pyrella (de Villers, 1789), Bedellia
   somnulentella (Zeller, 1847), Agonopterix pallorella (Zeller, 1839),
   Protocryptis sp. pr. sibiricella (Falkovitsh, 1965), Perygra
   taeniipennella (Herrich-Schaffer, 1855), Apatetris sp. pr. kinkerella
   (Snellen, 1876), Scrobipalpa ocellatella (Boyd, 1858), Prolita
   sexpunctella (Fabricius, 1794), Acanthophila latipennella (Rebel, 1937),
   Acleris kochiella (Goeze, 1783), Cydia illutana (Herrich-Schaffer, 1851)
   and Isauria dilucidella (Duponchel, 1836) - as new to Central Russia,
   the rest being local, rare or demanding further investigation.
   Additionally, recent records are reported for several species previously
   known from material collected more than 30 years ago, occurence of
   Zygaena loti ((Denis et Schiffermuller), 1775) and Scopula ornata
   (Scopoli, 1763), previously recorded only in the early XX-th century is
   confirmed.
C1 Bolshakov, L.V.; g. Tula, Russkoe entomologicheskoe obshchestvo (Tulskoe
   otdelenie), Russia, Russia.
SC Zoology
BD Land zones; Palaearctic region; Eurasia
DE Acanthophila latipennella; Acleris kochiella; Agonopterix pallorella;
   Bedellia somnulentella; Cydia illutana; Isauria dilucidella; Perygra
   taeniipennella; Prolita sexpunctella; Scrobipalpa ocellatella;
   Swammerdamia pyrella [Russia / Central / New record].

PT J

PM 20619262
DT Article
TI Theileria ovis discovered in China.
AU Li, Youquan
   Guan, Guiquan
   Ma, Miling
   Liu, Junlong
   Ren, Qiaoyun
   Luo, Jianxun
   Yin, Hong (yinhong@public.lz.gs.cn) 
SO Experimental Parasitology
VL 127
IS 1
PS 304-307
PD January 2011
PY 2011
LA English
U1 0
U2 7
AB A polymerase chain reaction (PCR) using 989/990 primers was conducted to
   identify a newly isolated Theileria sp. in Xinjiang Province of China.
   The target DNA fragments of the complete 18S rRNA gene were cloned and
   sequenced. The phylogenetic relationship of newly isolated Theileria
   spp. was inferred based on the 18S rRNA gene. The results showed that
   the new Theileria sp. belonged to the cluster of Theileria ovis.
   Moreover, the findings were confirmed by T. ovis species-specific PCR.
   An expected 520 bp fragment of T. ovis DNA was obtained from 25 out of
   320 (8%) field blood samples, and blood of an experimental sheep
   infested by Hyalomma anatolicum anatolicum collected in Xinjiang. The
   infection rate of T. ovis was 78% (25/32) in Xinjiang province. The
   investigation did not find T. ovis positive samples from the field
   samples collected from the other twelve provinces. This study indicates
   that T. ovis is prevalent in Xinjiang province of China and its
   transmission vector is H. anatolicum anatolicum. (C) 2010 Elsevier Inc.
   All rights reserved.
C1 Yin, Hong; Chinese Acad Agr Sci, Lanzhou Vet Res Inst, Lanzhou, China,
   China.
EM yinhong@public.lz.gs.cn
RI Yin, Hong/AAC-5784-2020
SC Zoology; Parasitology; Genetics &Heredity; Evolutionary Biology
SN 0014-4894

   Transmission; Land zones; Palaearctic region; Eurasia; Asia; China
DE Hyalomma anatolicum anatolicum [Protozoan parasites / Theileria ovis /
   New record; parasite discovery & vector identification; transmission]
   [Mammalian hosts / Ovis aries / prevalence] [Transmission of parasites /
   Theileria ovis (Protozoa) / ] [Xinjiang Uygur /  / ].

   parasite discovery & vector identification; transmission] [Phylogeny /

   / ] [Transmission of parasites / Hyalomma anatolicum anatolicum
   (Arachnida) / ] [China /  / ] [Xinjiang Uygur /  / ].

PT J
AN ZOOR14708060086
DT Article
TI Diaspididae (Insecta: Hemiptera: Coccoidea).
AU Henderson, R.C. (HendersonR@LandcareResearch.co.nz) 
SO Fauna of New Zealand
VL 66
PS 3-271
PD 2011
PY 2011
LA English
U1 0
U2 3
AB The adult females of all 49 species of Diaspididae (Hemiptera:
   Coccoidea) known from New Zealand, except the tribe Leucaspidini, are
   described and illustrated. The 1st- and 2nd-instar nymphs of all the
   endemic species and of 4 Australian species that are of systematic
   interest are also described and illustrated. Four new genera, Anzaspis,
   Pellucidaspis, Pseudodonaspis, and Serenaspis and seven new species are
   described. Two genera, Fusilaspis and Symeria, are reinstated and
   redescribed. Hence there are twenty endemic species in ten genera and
   eight Australasian species in six genera. In addition, there are
   twenty-one cosmopolitan adventive species in fourteen genera.
   Nomenclatural changes are as follows: Chionaspis angusta Green and
   Pseudaulacaspis cordylinidis (Maskell) are transferred to Anzaspis
   n.gen.; Pseudaulacaspis phymatodidis (Maskell) is transferred back to an
   earlier combination as Fusilaspis phymatodidis (Maskell) and
   Pseudaulacaspis dubia (Maskell) is a new junior synonym of F
   phymatodidis; Pseudaulacaspis epiphytidis (Maskell) becomes the senior
   synonym of Andaspis asteliae (Green) and is transferred to Pellucidaspis
   n.gen; Lepidosaphes lactea (Maskell) is transferred to Poliaspis Maskell
   and P argentosis Brittin becomes a junior synonym of P. media Maskell;
   Natalaspis leptocarpi (Brittin) is confirmed as Poliaspoides leptocarpi
   (Brittin); Trullifiorinia minima (Maskell) becomes the senior synonym of
   Pinnaspis dysoxyli (Maskell) and is transferred to Serenaspis n.gen.;
   Scrupulaspis intermedia (Maskell) and Eulepidosaphes pyriformis
   (Maskell) are transferred to Symeria Green. In addition, Fiorinia
   drimydis (Maskell) is considered a nomen dubium because the only
   specimens available are 2nd-instar male nymphs of an unidentifiable
   Leucaspis species. Keys to allow separation of adult females of all
   genera and species are included. Earlier work carried out on the
   Diaspididae in New Zealand is briefly reviewed. Biology and life cycle,
   scale cover formation, natural enemies, distribution, host plant
   associations including galls, and economic importance are discussed.
   Methods are given for slide-mounting Diaspididae as used in the New
   Zealand Arthropod Collection. Morphology and terms are detailed for
   adult females, male and female 2nd-instar nymphs, and 1st-instar nymphs.
   Lists of plant hosts, material examined, and georeferenced collection
   localities are included as appendices.
C1 Henderson, R.C.; Landcare Res, Private Bag 92170, Auckland, New Zealand,
   New Zealand.
EM HendersonR@LandcareResearch.co.nz
SC Zoology; Parasitology; Anatomy &Morphology
